address: Largo Doutor Jose Rodrigues, Coimbra 3000-236 Portugal
name: Museu Nacional de Machado de Castro
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: The best of Coimbra walking tour
photo/caption: Museu Nacional de Machado de Castro, Coimbra.
ranking: #2 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #2 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
This is a not to be missed attraction that seems to be overlooked due to its location - near to the famous university.
The museum is built on the site of a Roman forum. You start your tour by exploring the ancient infrastructure. The extent of what has been maintained is staggering. The highlight of the museum for me was the extensive collection of sculptures from the Roman to the Renaissance periods. To see the progression from Roman elegance to the primitive Medieval to the magnificence of the Renaissance was fascinating.
This museum should not be missed.
As an added bonus the museum has a wonderful look out over Coimbra and serves reasonably price food and beverages .
reviews/0/title: Not as appreciated as it should be
reviews/1/text:
In this museum you can find the most beautiful collections of sculpture,
 and jewellery, but what makes it absolutely unique is the absolutely extraordinary Roman cryptoportico, which supports the Museum itself. Unforgetable!.
reviews/1/title: a museum of excellence | UM MUSEU DE EXCELÊNCIA
reviews/2/text:
To answer the question I couldn't find with a quick search - this museum focuses on art throughout history of the Coimbra and central Portugal region of every medium

This museum is much larger than expected and some exhibits are better curated than others. The museum poorly lays out the path they expect you to take between the exhibits and they rudely direct you where they expect you to start which is going. It starts by going down 2 floors to the roman ruins under the museum which they do not warn is well ill-suited for people with mobility concerns and no elevator access. After going back up the 2 stories to the main entry, they put you on the elevator up two stories to the main exhibit which is laid out how they want you to traverse it and separated into art based on material - stone, statues, paintings, metal, pottery, textiles, and misc. furniture and dumps you out into the gift shop... with a carriage off to the side. Primarily the art is of Christian focus but most everything has descriptions in Portuguese and English.

Most important lesson - If you see a bathroom, use it then for the museum workers will not permit you to go backwards through the exhibit to reconnect with your party who are still browsing! To make it more difficult - There aren't many places to rest through this very long winding museum and the floor is in poor shape.
reviews/2/title: Long museum that disconnects you from your group.
reviews/3/text: We spent about 3 hours here (which includes taking lots of pictures) and could have easily spent more time browsing everything. The Roman ruins are fascinating, sculptures/paintings are beautiful, and altarpieces quite unique. The audio guide provides a lot of information in English, and there's a decent collection of furniture as well.
reviews/4/text:
This is a magnificent museum for both its collection and its presentation. The highlights are the sculptures going back to the 11th century and with a large array of works by Jean de Rouen, and the ecclesiastical treasures that have been amazed from local monasteries and churches each presented in perfect lighting in individual "boxes". There is also a selection of some fine Flemish and Portuguese paintings and lots more including church robes, carpets, ivory from Goa etc.
The museum was surprisingly empty so the viewing was first class. You should visit Coimbra if you have the chance and then you must come here.
reviews/4/title: One of the best museums in Portugal. Do visit. Not crowded.
reviews/5/text: Lots of sculpture both in wood and stone. Its not your typical art museum,  but worthwhile nonetheless. You can learn a lot about Portuguese history if you focus and read the labels. A decent cafe too with a great overview of Coimbra.
reviews/6/text: As you enter the museum you are directed down some stairs into areas that were built in roman times to even up the hillside for the forum. The engineering skills etc are quite outstanding there are no mosaics but the area is large and very interesting particularly where subsequent generations have reused the brickwork for stables and the foundation of the bishops palace. The rest of the museum has galleries of sculpture and portuguese religious art all of which are well worth seeing. There is a fantastic view over the lower city and the river from the restaurant terrace.
reviews/7/text: This museum walk begins with a tour through the original Roman ruins beneath several later Christian churches.  Upstairs, the collections are very well displayed and include mostly religious relics saved from churches and other sites in Portugal and Coimbra over the centuries. They cover sculpture, painting, wood carving, terra cotta, ceramic and precious metal work. There is also a restaurant and a gift shop.
reviews/8/text: The external view of this museum is best described as unassuming. However, when you enter the museum you will understand that the museum has had to protect its 2000 years of history in a special way. Starting from the Roman base the museum reflects the importance of Coimbra through the Visigoth-Suevi, Moorish and late medieval periods. The exchanges of the Portuguese Empire are also represented. The museum includes stone and wood carvings, textiles, glass and ceramics, gold and silver work and wonderful paintings.
reviews/9/text: The museum is well done and was a bit over priced in my opinion but I have seen many Roman ruins before and frankly religious artwork just doesn't interest me. So that probably influences my review However there were some very lovely pieces, and I enjoyed most of the museum. It is very specific to the area but had some breadth to it as well. I'm glad I went in and saw everything (even if it was a quick glance as I walked by).
reviews/10/text: a pity that the staff spoil the experience by being incredibly directive and treating the visitors like children... But worth the visit nevertheless. Magnificent sculptures and extremely interesting roman remains
reviews/11/text:
We spent an afternoon here and learned more than I ever thought possible about ceramics, sculpture, painting, furniture, and precious metals.... but you could spend much less time and still have a wonderful experience.  The building has its own unique historical significance, which makes it even more fun.  

If you visit any time in the near future (I'm writing this in mid-August 2021), don't miss the photography exhibit by Jorge Baceras, which depicts "his people" in rural areas in the style of Renaissance paintings.  Incredibly compelling!
reviews/12/text: A beautiful building and setting.  Check out the views from their cafe.  The collections are extensive.  But note that the focus is Roman antiquities and religious art, and gauge for yourself whether this collection is of interest to you.
reviews/12/title: Go here if you are interested in Roman antiquities and religious art
reviews/13/text: It is a very nice place and close to the University and Old Cathedral so you can place your route accordingly. Apart from lots of nice pieces of art, you can also visit the cryptoportic. The visit takes at least 1 hour.
reviews/14/text: This is such an amazing museum one wonders why it is not better known.  It is a very odd mixture of art, architecture and history.  The bottom two floors are an excavated, Roman forum from 2000 years ago.  The museum is built on top on the Roman forum because it is housed in a palace that was built on the Roman ruins.  I have no idea how they were able to excavate the Roman ruins with a building on top of it, but it is amazing.  The forum has two levels of similar sized rooms, at least 20 or 30 rooms plus long halls.  It is like a maze.  The main museum is three floors above the Roman ruins.  It has an excellent collection of sculptures over many centuries, with excellent collections from the 15th and 16th centuries.  There is a sublime collection of medieval and more recent metal work.  There are some very fine religious paintings and some decorative arts including tapestries.  Much of the art was not familiar to me.  We were entranced.  There is also a nice cafe with seating on the outdoor terrace.  It mainly has drinks and snacks.  It has great views over the city.  We spent two hours here and felt like we could have spent more.  It's that good.
reviews/15/text:
It was a rainy day so we popped in here and were pleasantly entertained.  Some of the artwork was interesting, as were some of the more than a few of the statues....but the part we enjoyed the most was strolling through the old Roman Ruins upon which this place was built.  Pretty amazing stuff to see and consider.

And if none of this impresses you, there are free and clean WC's here.....so keep that in mind as you stroll past : )
reviews/16/text: We didn’t have high expectations for this museum in Coimbra, having been to archaeological sites and art museums in Italy, Great Britain and France. It blew us away! From our first turn into the entrance courtyard, with its gorgeous vista overlooking rooftops of the lower city and the river, we were gob-smacked. The collection is fantastic from the extensive and fascinating ruins of a Roman forum to the gorgeous collection of medieval church art and the porcelains- Asian and Moorish - it is impressive and beautifully curated. Titles and signage are in Portuguese and English. And don’t skip the lunch buffet! It was well-prepared, fresh and delicious.
reviews/17/text:
If I had to pick one thing to see in Coimbra, I would see this museum over the university any day.

We loved the Roman ruins & have seen many Roman ruins in Italy, Israel, Croatia, & Turkey. We were the only ones in the ruins at the time & it was creepy but enjoyable.

We loved the rest of the museum also. The artwork was really impressive.

Museum security allowed me to use the elevator since I use a cane- I really appreciated that.

We were there for 1.5 hours & could have used more time.

If you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more.
reviews/18/text: Lunch was very good with everything plus a glass of wine and the espresso included for a very reasonable price. The view is stunning and the atmosphere was warm and inviting on a cold day. The museum was depressing, sparse, claustrophobic and you were not allowed to view the paintings without not one, but two, subterranean trips to the catacombs.  Couldn't wait to get out of there.
reviews/18/title: Stop here for lunch but maybe not the museum
reviews/19/text: the collection hare has unexpected treasures, including whole chapels and temples. the museuem is built on top of amazing double story roman foundations which are worth a visit on their own.  The cafe ont he roof has one of the best views of Coimbra.
reviews/19/title: Excellent collection, extraordinary roman crypt and the best view of Coimbra

address: Rua de Quebra Costas n 7, Coimbra 3000-340 Portugal
description: Fado ao Centro is a Cultural Association of Fado from Coimbra, opened from Monday to Sunday (10am to 7pm). Located in the historical center of Coimbra (Rua Quebra Costas),the entrance to the photo exhibition about Coimbras University tradition & informations are for free. Also have Fado shows everyday, with a recreation of a Live Serenade, that everyone can experience for a small amount of money! A magical space with a unique atmosphere were you can find the most genuine and traditional Fado from Coimbra everyday from 10:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Only the best musicians of the city play in Fado ao Centro and they are selected according to the highest standards of this 160 year old tradition. Even if you can't witness the concert, don't miss the oportunity to visit our space and get to know a little bit more about Fado from Coimbra. There are always musicians playing and rehearsing so you can change experiences and learn more about the Portuguese Guitar and this unique musical tradition. Bewtween 4:00 p.m. and 5:30 p.m. we have the "Afternoon Rehearsals" with our regular musicians. You can always pass by, watch them play and anyone that want's to bring their own instrument is also welcome to join! At 6:00 p.m. we start our daily 50 minute long concert of Fado from Coimbra. If you are interested in attending our concert, we strongly advise you to make a reservation in order to ensure your seat. We don't serve any kind of food, so we are totally committed to the concert itself, enabling a genuine atmosphere and unique cultural and musical experience in Coimbra! Following the work that has been held by this Cultural Association, you'll find different exclusive editions of books, CDs and DVDs related to Fado from Coimbra. Fado ao Centro(R) is, undoubtedly, a place to visit in Coimbra!
name: Fado ao Centro
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: The best of Coimbra walking tour
photo/caption: リスボンのファドより情感があって実に良かった
ranking: #1 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #1 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: Fabulous one hour show with Portuguese & English explanations of songs, style and performers. Enjoyed speaking with guitarist afterwards. Beautiful introduction to this music.
reviews/1/text: Seeing Fado performed by former students in an intimate setting was wonderful.  One of the best things we did on our trip to Portugal.  Don't miss Casa Fado Ao Centro.
reviews/2/text: We went to a 7 pm show on a Saturday.  The audience was largely mature people like ourselves. The presentation was multimedia,  with historical video, two guitarists and two singers ( all male) The group was engaging, Speaking in Portuguese and English.  The traditional Portuguese Guitarist was the highlight of the experience
reviews/3/text: Enjoyable experience to learn about and appreciate a unique musical genre. Good explanation of fado helps one understand a little more about history . I really liked getting to chat with the performers afterwards over a glass of port.
reviews/4/text: A very professional music production with amazing guitarists and singers performing old Portuguese ballads. Performance lasted 50 minutes followed by a meet and greet with the performers.  A perfect thing to do before heading to dinner. Most likely need a reservation which our hotel did for us.
reviews/5/text: Absolutely fantastic! Very friendly staff, amazing music and singers, and a nice touch to offer some port to try after the concert. The history of fado in Coimbra was really well explained and it felt very authentic to present everything in Portuguese before translating to English. We loved to opportunity to hear more of the beautiful Portuguese language both spoken and sung.
reviews/6/text: Loved this short introduction to Combra fado with the singers, guitarists and orator.  Not knowing what to expect, we were all very happy to experience the 50 minute show and help to keep this tradition alive.  We booked online in advance.
reviews/7/text: Awesome experience! Well worth doing when in Coimbra. It is scheduled for 50 minutes - which I initially thought was a long time, but the time really flies by. The music is fantastic and you also receive some information about the history of fado. A very unique thing to do while in Portugal and very memorable.
reviews/8/text: This nightly show (1800 for 50 minutes) is a very good introduction to Coimbra Fado. The guitarists are excellent and the two male singers also very good. It is located in a pedestrian area close to the old cathedral.
reviews/9/text: This 50 mins performance gives a good review of Fado of Coimbra. Frankly a bit more info that I really cared about but someone with more appreciation of music likely would be happy to have that. The music was well done, the men are talented, and they give a wide sampling of the types of music they do. Entry fee was 12 euros and I just purchased one right before the show started on a Saturday night.
reviews/10/text: This was a lovely experience.   Some traditional local Fado sung by students with excellent guitar accompaniment and a great explanation of the significance of the local style, all in a simple theater.  Great way to start an evening and in a beautiful square.
reviews/11/text: Exactly what we hoped for. Very good singing, we were touched. And the guitarists, maybe even better... The information concerning the music and its background came fast and in a natural way. A perfect hour to kick off the evening!
reviews/11/title: What a pleasant introduction to fado!
reviews/12/text: No wonder this is #1 activity in Coimbra. The visit exceeded my expectations. The musicians and singer were incredibly talented. Show is 50 minutes - perfect length. You also get descriptions in Portuguese and English of the song / its meaning and a couple nice video clips about history of Fado. The music is incredible and envelops you like the black capes they wear. Mesmerizing!
reviews/13/text: Due to the small venue, our hotel made reservations ahead of our stay in Coimbra.  To get a front row seat be sure to arrive early. Because of Covid, masks were required. The singers & musicians were wonderful and shared the history of Fado in the program.  A historical film played simultaneously behind the performers which added depth to the presentation. After the concert, guests were invited to stay for port and conversation. A lovely evening for an affordable cost.
reviews/14/text: Best €12 ever spent. This was a very very beautiful concert and we also learned a lot about the history of Fado music. After the concert there was a small port wine tasting where we also got the chance to talk to the artists. I highly recommend Fado ao Centro!
reviews/14/title: Fado ao Centro is a must
reviews/15/text: An excellent way to spend an hour or so, and to learn a little about Fado. Music that you love or hate. Because of COVID numbers are limited, and our performance was booked out. Suggest you reserve your seat in advance. Worthwhile.
reviews/16/text: The concert was great. It was my first Fado concert ever and just loved it. What made it especially nice is that because it was in this Centro, which is quite small, the group was quite small as well (13 persons). Therefore it became quite personal.
reviews/17/text: Our hotel recommended we see this show, and we are very happy they did. This is more than two instrumentalists and two singers; it is a lesson in the history, the heart and the soul of Coimbra Fado that is performed by some impressive musicians you expect to be hearing in considerably larger performance venues. At €12, this is a memorable experience and remarkable value all in one. Highly recommended.
reviews/17/title: These guys are really, really good
reviews/18/text: Frankly, I was a bit intimidated about seeing Fado in Lisbon- either felt too serious and time consuming (few hours) and usually the required dinner was not the best option. We lucked into finding this place in the center of Coimbra. We discovered that Coimbra is one the centers of Fado with its own unique history and style. The Fado ao Centro is very professional and expert but also designed as an easy sampler for visitors- about 1 hour, small place, with good explanations for every piece you hear. Highly recommended if you are in Coimbra.
reviews/18/title: Great introduction to experience the unique Fado of Coimbra
reviews/19/text: We  sat in the most beautiful church and was sung to by a nightingale and 2 very experienced musicians it felt comfortable and welcoming. Loves the experience.

reviews/0/text: The cathedral was a beautiful building and courtyard (gorgeous stone work). At 2.5 euros, the entrance fee was very reasonable.
reviews/1/text: The old cathedral of Coimbra was built in the 12th century when the capital of Portugal was in this city. In Romanesque style, this cathedral probably replaced an earlier cathedral of which nothing is known, and was used for the coronation of the king of Portugal. From the time of the Reconquista to now little has been changed with modest additions in the Renaissance style that have not altered the original style. Like the cathedral of Lisbon, this too has a fortress-like appearance perhaps determined by the situation of long-standing belligerence existing in those times. Even the hundreds of sculptured capitals, all without human figures, are a clear consequence of that period in which Christianity and Islam fought but also influenced each other.
reviews/1/title: A well-preserved cathedral of the time of the Reconquista
reviews/2/text: We wished we had had more time to explore this beautiful cathedral. So much history and beauty! I loved the exterior and the cloister.
reviews/2/title: So much to see, not enough time to do it all.
reviews/3/text: Beautiful space that is rich in history. The corridors and space is lovingly preserved and work a visit.
reviews/4/text: A nice place if you have less than an hour to kill (which includes taking lots of pictures). Similar to Lisbon's somewhat plain cathedral, there isn't a whole lot to take in, but there are some pretty chapels to see. There's English descriptions scattered around the church and a small cloister.
reviews/5/text: Beautiful exterior/ entrance. Big stone construction. Cloisters is wonderful. We found it by accident and then found it was on our walk. If you go to see the University this is on the way down to City Center.
reviews/6/text: We ran into this beautiful cathedral as we were going through the town-  glad we did as it was so stunning.  Especially loved the courtyard!
reviews/7/text: The Old Cathedral in Coimbra looks rather like a fort on the outside, probably because it was built at a time of Moorish incursions. Inside there are some very fine works of art, foremost amongst which is the spectacular main altar, a work by the Flemish artists Olivier de Gand and Jean d'Ypres (Flemish painters were an important influence at that time), and the Chapel of the Blessed Sacrament, a work of the French sculptor Jean de Rouen (he was a major influence on Portuguese sculpture). While it has been remodeled, there are still Romanesque influences, notably the capitals and there is beautiful end 13th century Cloister. A must see for any visitor to Coimbra
reviews/7/title: A must see for its artworks and the cloisters
reviews/8/text: The old cathedral was built for defence and to last it does not have the extravagant decoration of later churches but it has many features that make it well worth a visirt
reviews/9/text: Truly awesome architecture that really has to be seen to undersand how grand it is. Did not expect to be this impressed with a cathedral.
reviews/9/title: Must be seen to be appreciated.
reviews/10/text:
Likewise the capital's Se, this is the oldest Cathedral in Coimbra. It's set beneath the University square plateau. However the first appearance was bad due to heavy construction works going on all around it.
It's a 12c Romanesque edifice with a fortress like exterior. Interiors, paying a few Euros are interesting to see, but skippable if you saw the Lisbon's as are pretty much the same.
reviews/11/text: This place was a nice old cathedral. I like some of the others in Batalha and Alcobaca better but this one is good too. A lovely cool place to cool off in the heat was its main attraction that day but it is well worth the entry price. There is a lot of construction around the outside currently but I don't recall anything in the interior. I much enjoyed the details in the cloister.
reviews/12/text: Buy ticket, see around and be impressed by a millenium watching on you. Beautiful cloisters next by.
reviews/13/text:
I saw this after the Library, coming down to the city center. At the beginning I was not very attracted but as I entered the curch and then the cloister I was left breathless.
Devote some time for a visit.
reviews/14/text: The austere Romanesque cathedral is very old and worth the visit.  But don't miss the cloisters that are linked to it and they are splendid and very romantic.  Some very ancient burials here.
reviews/15/text: Everyone says you must visit Coimbra , well we did and that’s about all I have to say! Overrated there are far better places to visit .
reviews/16/text: Really nice architecture. So bad it was closed as many places we tried to visit in Coimbra. Also, it was impossible to take a nice picture of the Facade because everything was full of cars.
reviews/17/text: Old Cathedral of Coimbra was built in 1162 and is one of the most characteristic monuments of Romanesque architecture in Portugal. From the outside, it looks like a fortress. The cathedral has been preserved almost intact to this day. On the other hand, the beautiful renaissance gate added to the northern wall of the temple is rather heavily damaged. A gem of architecture. It's definitely worth seeing while in Coimbra.
reviews/18/text: The cathedral reminded me of the churches of southern France. There, too, you won`t understand: the church in front of you or still a fortress. By the way, maybe that's why the cathedral was quickly built on the site of the church destroyed by the Moors: starting in 1164 and ending in 20 years. a very short time for cathedrals. It should be understood that Portugal didn`t have personnel at that time and the cathedral was built by French architects Robert and Bernard. Moreover, Robert also worked on the Lisbon Cathedral. It's like a conveyor belt. But the Cathedral of Coimbra remained the only Portuguese Romanesque cathedral, unlike Lisbon and others, thoroughly rebuilt. The main feature of the Romanesque style of the cathedral is the large number (300) of capitals (tops of columns). If Romanesque artists under the influence of Byzantium did not use plant and geometric images in the capitals, but tried to depict animals and people, then here on the contrary. This is due to the fact that mozarabe (converted Christians) were building the Cathedral. They are not used to portraying people, because it is forbidden in Islam. The cathedral has not escaped subsequent influences, but they are present in fragments. Gothic is present in several tombs and most importantly in the cloister. The cloister is very large and part of the hillside was demolished to build it. Renaissance elements are also present in the cathedral. The Gate of Hope-Porta Especiosa was built in the 1530s by the French sculptor Joao de Rouen. He also created a magnificent retable with the image of Jesus and the apostles in the southern apse 30 years later. And, of course, the decoration of the cathedral is the main Renaissance altar created from 1498 to 1502 by Flemish artists Olivier de Gand and Jean d'Ypres.
reviews/18/title: The only Portuguese unrebuilt Romanesque cathedral,
reviews/19/text: A very nice romanesque cathedral. It really deserves a visit and it is a key part of the city. It also has a very nice Renassaince door in the lateral façade. Only downside is that it is too much surrounded by other buildings so you have to take care to appreciate in detail

address: Paco das Escolas, Coimbra 3000-370 Portugal
description: The Tourism Circuit of the University of Coimbra unfolds in different centers: - The Palace of Schools where you can visit the Royal Palace that includes the Grand Hall of Acts, the Private Exam Room and the Armillary Room; The Royal Chapel of Saint Michael and the Joanine Library where you can visit the Noble Floor, the Middle Floor and the Academic Prison (with limited access for the preservation of the building). - The Science Museum where you can visit the 18 th and 19 th Century Physics Cabinets, the Natural History Galleries and the Chemistry Laboratory. - The Botanic Garden where you can travel around the world through botanic.
name: University of Coimbra

reviews/0/text:
Spent a few hours in the town - it has a botanical garden and a university and a very good looking building for a penitentiary. We climbed the 100 plus university steps to the top and observed many students dressed in black. It was their uniform for special occasions - they were part of a Tuna music group and various chapters from around Portugal get together.

Coimbra was just a stop on our way to Obidos and did not spend much time here
reviews/1/text:
We did a 2 day roadtrip between Porto and Lisbon and decided to stop at Coimbra to see the famous library. Note: We did not plan ahead which is not our style but luckily it worked out for us (probably because it was January and not high tourist season). Arrived and found a parking space and made our way to the University. Asked some students and we were pointed in the direction of the ticket office. As luck would have it, we were able to get 3 tickets for a 12:45 entry to the library. This was key because all the buildings close from 1-2 for lunch. We made our way over to the library entrance and promptly admitted at 12:45. Able to have our 15-20 minutes admiring and then sown out. 
The university did close but we were able to find a nearby popular lunch spot that had one table for 3. Once we finished lunch - headed back to see some of the other buildings at 2. The entire entrance courtyard area was filled with people for the 2pm entry. They allow about 60 people every 20 minutes so keep this in mind in the summer. 
We explored some of the other buildings and continued our road trip.
If you can pre plan and buy your tickets ahead of time, this would be encouraged during the high tourist season. There were a few students with the black cloaks and they were very kind - and proud - to allow people to take photos of them. This is a beautiful university - highly recommend you read about the library and student life before you visit. learn about the uniform ( ribbon colors) and the bats that help keep the books preserved in the library.
reviews/1/title: Lovely few hours exploring this campus
reviews/2/text:
The university of coimbra is a precious jewel of portuguese heritage. In addition to everything you normally visit, I highly recommend the Cabinet of Curiosities and the Physics Laboratory. The Cabinet of Curiosities was recently set up and is a unique experience. 
«Imagine a world without telephones, TVs, mp3 players, computers, and phones. How would you entertain your guests after dinner without the aid of any of these devices? Cabinets of curiosities were the aristocrat’s answer for those who sought to enliven the opulent but dimly lit parties thrown during the Italian Renaissance.»
In this Cabinet of Curiositiesall the arts and all studies are mixed, from anthropology, to ethnology, passing through painting, decorative arts, astronomy or biology. I spent an hour looking at all the details. And if I could I would stay there longer. Coming back!
reviews/2/title: Gabinete de Curiosidades e Laborátório de Física da Universidade,
reviews/3/text:
Our family bought tickets which we were unable to use due to an error (not on our behalf). 
In addition, the ticketing system is almost impossible, and the sign posting of the locations is very confusing.

What we did see was - I hate to say it - nothing overly special. We would not go out of our way again. 

The worst part , was the communication from Tânia at the “customer service”. Utterly rude,
it’s clear she has little regard for travelers and tourists. 

The whole experience was underwhelming and left a bad taste in our mouths.
reviews/4/text:
Portugal's oldest university was founded in Lisbon in 1290 and moved here when it was built in 1634. It occupies most of the center of the old city overlooking the new and the Mondego river.

It has the clock and bell tower built in the 18th century, one of Coimbra's most famous landmark . Also one of the finest libraries in the world, Biblioteca Joanina.

If in Coimbra, you must visit.
reviews/5/text: We visited the university on September 28th. We bought tickets for the Royal Palace and the Chapel. We decided not to visit the library because you are not allowed to take pictures. The highlight is definitely the chapel. We were lucky enough to get in without a guided group so we could admire the chapel at our pace.
reviews/6/text: Classic bldg. and former palace of the King of Portugal. The central part of campus is nice and spreads out further down the hill.
reviews/7/text: In consideration of the fact that it is located in the upper part of Coimbra, we reached the university using a public bus that goes up through the botanical garden. Arriving at the university we had to ask to reach the ticket office which we discovered to be far from the university and close to the old Chemical Laboratory at the end of Rua Estudos. Since the most famous part to visit is the Joanina Library, when you buy the ticket you also get the time at which you can access the library where the visit is guided. The visit to the university must then be defined on the basis of the time of access to the library. We first visited the Royal Palace where the Great Acts Room (former Throne Room) and the Private Exam Room are very interesting. Then through the University of Law corridors we arrived at the Capela de S. Miguel. The visit to the library starts from a side door of the Palace of Schools which is reached by going down a staircase. This guided tour begins in the not very interesting Academic Prison, then continues in the Intermediate Floor (a space which is used as a repository for less important books and documents that do not have space in the Library) and finally goes up to the Noble Floor of the Library. Here you can stop for a few minutes and you can't take pictures. The Science Museum is relatively interesting with its old science equipments. Very interesting to visit even if below expectations.
reviews/8/text:
I was initially excited to visit, but soon learned it’s not a ‘must do”.
It was very disorganised - hard to buy tickets. The Website doesn’t work properly. The Cabinet of Curiosities is temporarily closed. The chemistry lab was “okay”, but certainly missable.
In hindsight, I would have skipped it and spent more time somewhere else. 
Better customer service may have made things better, but it’s shamefully bad. They just don’t care.
reviews/9/text: Very much torn between a 4 and a 5 for this place. The library, grand hall and chapel are beautiful; the cabinet of curiosities/science museum were quite dated and plain. We spent about 2 hours here in total; you can very much spend more time roaming around if you want to read/go through everything in the science museum. Note that NO photos are allowed in the library, which is frustrating. The grand hall has plenty of information in English and you can go at your leisure to all the buildings, except the library.
reviews/9/title: The library, grand hall and chapel are beautiful
reviews/10/text:
From the outside, the buildings looked very good, but as we were on a coach travelling from Lisbon to Porto, we sadly didn't have a chance to see the interior of all of the lovely buildings.
The students, in their distinctive uniforms, were entertaining.
reviews/10/title: Saw it Whizzing Past on a Coach!
reviews/11/text: Take a morning hike up the winding streets of Coimbra to the University of Coimbra. Good exercise and well worth it. You can take tours or go on your own, as we did. A beautiful and historic university with outstanding views of the city below.
reviews/12/text: This is a beautiful campus and has some beautiful places to explore.  Loved the rooftop catwalk overlooking Coimbra, and the Grand Hall.
reviews/13/text: Late in the afternoon, we visited Coimbra University at a time when the 'freshers' were finding their way around. The University building are extensive and spread out. We visited the library, the Chapel and the building that was once the palace of the King of Portugal when Coimbra was its capital. The visit was interesting but we wouldn’t rush back.
reviews/13/title: OK but I wouldn't rush back
reviews/14/text: Almost like in every city in Portugal the streets are steep. A pleasant university city, we arrived on the opening day of the studies, the atmosphere of the "old" students (second year and above) marching the young students in the first year plus a beautiful library, a beautiful view of the city from the university area. The mobility in the city is incredibly easy with the help of the relatively cheap Uber service.
reviews/14/title: A university city with a beautiful library
reviews/15/text: Library was interesting to look at.  Rest was typical Portugal.  Not sure worth the price of admission.
reviews/16/text: This University started in 1290 and has been operational ever since.  Love exploring the Chemistry Building where they studied matter & energy, and components of water.  If you love learning, you will appreciate visiting this university.
reviews/17/text:
Fascinating visit. 

We did a small group tour with Renan. He added so many details we would have otherwise missed. 

Best way to see the university is with a tour.
reviews/18/text: €12.50 to see small chapel, three rooms in the palace, library and science display. TOWER NOT INCLUDED these have to be bought from the gift shop. Main tickets need to be bought near the chemistry building. Science museum closed 1300 to 1400. Tower closes at 1300. This was not explained when tickets were bought or in the information leaflet. We did not have enough time to go up the tower as our library visit was at 1220. The science museum and library were good but the visit didn't feel like good value.
reviews/19/text:
Coimbra University is one of the oldest in Europe dating back to late 13 century, and still the biggest one in Portugal.
Visiting it's grounds is the best thing you can do in this town. There're several types of tickets, depending how much you want to see.
We found the basic ticket (around 12 Euros) to be more than sufficient as it includes the Chemical laboratory, University Palace (which served as seat of power in 12-13 c when Coimbra was a capital), as well the astonishing Sao Miguel Chapel and Joanina Library.
BEWARE you cannot buy tickets on the spot at the University square. Tickets for the entire University complex are sold across the Chemical Laboratory which is around the corner of the new Se Cathedral (some 10 min walk from the University square itself). Very illogical, but that's it - do that first to avoid double walking like we did. Count on around 2-3 hours for entire visit.
subcategory_ranking: #10 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Rua das Parreiras, Coimbra 3040-266 Portugal
name: Mosteiro de Santa Clara-a-Velha
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Tour Coimbra - 1 Day from Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Tomar / Coimbra Private Tour * Private Tours *
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Full Day Fátima and Coimbra Private Tour from Porto
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: City of Students - Coimbra Private Tour from Lisbon
ranking: #8 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #8 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: We were able to sneak in here briefly as there was a wedding to take place, but what we saw was lovely.  Part of the university area.
reviews/1/text: This is definitely worth a visit... you can walk around the outside and see the Mosteiro building, but it is worth it to go into the site and museum to learn more about the history and get a closer view. The actual Mosteiro is currently closed to the public, as they are doing some repairs, but you can still see a lot of ruin and the museum has additional artifacts. The staff is super helpful and will explain some of the history.
reviews/2/text: This monastery is connected to the Se, but requires an entrance fee.  The architecture and decorations are old, classic and lovely.
reviews/3/text:
To visit the monastery, you can leave your car in a guarded car park, who is located just after the bridge of Santa Clara and walk about 10 minutes to the monastery, which unfortunately cannot be visited due to works and for an indefinite period of time!
What you can see is an exhibition and a 15-minute film, the monastery itself is just to be seen from the outside, from the street.
The Santa Clara Monastery was built in 1314 by D. Isabel de Aragon, the Holy Queen, replacing a small convent of Clarissa nuns founded in 1286. The temple was completed in 1330. At the end of the 20th century, extensive restoration work was carried out, which uncovered the structures and a vast and diversified estate. Once again open to visits, the Monastery offers a leisure area in a wide open-air route that includes the church and the restored archaeological structures. In the Interpretative Centre, in addition to the exhibition of the objects found here, structured according to the monastic experience, audiovisual means are used to present the history of the place and its requalification.
reviews/4/text: Very helpful staff and beautiful building.  The church has so much history.  The views from the grounds are stunning.  Well worth the walk up the hill.
reviews/5/text:
4 eur entrance fee. 
In June is still closed to the public. We visited on the outside and is still worth it.
reviews/6/text:
Although the site was almost completely destroyed with the consecutive floods over a period of 150 years, it has been restored through the past few years. Of the former monastery only the foundations remain but the church is reasonably restored.
It is for me a favourite due to the oddity in its configuration. Although it's called a monastery, it was in fact a convent and presents the main lateral entrance as it should. The rest of the building is different and surprising. The fact that some floors are missing left the rib vaults completey exposed adding to the experience of visiting a building that dates from the XIV century and was almost completely destroyed up to a few decades ago.
reviews/7/text: We stumbled on the ruined Convent of Santa Clara-a-Velha late on our first afternoon in Coimbra, after walking along the Mondego river and visiting the gardens of the Quinta das Lágrimas. This 13th-century convent was strongly associated with Portugal's saintly queen, Santa Isabel, and was an important pilgrimage site during the medieval period and beyond, until it had to be abandoned in 1677 due to the river's constantly rising floodwaters. After painstaking archeological and restoration work, the ruins can now be visited. You first make your way through the small museum/information centre, with many interesting artifacts and a great deal of information (unfortunately, the explanatory notes are only in Portuguese at the moment, but if you persevere you can understand enough to get the gist). There is an absorbing documentary video shown in the auditorium and if you can catch one with English subtitles (ours was at 5.30pm) it is well worth watching, as it sets everything in a richer historical context. Then you make your way out into the ruins of the convent church and cloisters, where the explanatory notices, though few in number, are in both Portuguese and English. It is a quiet, contemplative and evocative sacred space.
reviews/8/text:
It is marvellously evocative and atmospheric. Built many centuries ago, unfortunately it was located on the river's floodplain so suffered from regular flooding.

Eventually abandoned and its replacement was designed on much higher ground. What remains is captivating. It was great walking around the nave in ruins and looking through open windows. 

Columns and vaulted ceilings that are still extant are most impressive.
reviews/8/title: Never build a monastery on a river's floodplain
reviews/9/text: We were on our way to the top of the hill to look at the new Monastery and just viewed it without entering which i dont think you need to do.  Its beautiful and commisioned by Queen Elizabeth in 1314 to house some Nuns.  Due to the amount of floods from the river Mandego it was finally abandoned in 1677.  You can see the problem yourself as the bottom steps are below the river level.  You also get some nice views back across the river towards Coimbra
reviews/10/text: The whole museum complex is well laid out and worth the visit. There is an introductory video that plays in the auditorium with English subtitles that gives a good overview and an exhibition of archeological artifacts related to the monastery. An english booklet is given to explain the pieces of the exhibition, but the numbers given in the booklet don't seem to be present next to the pieces, so at times it took some figuring out to know which aspect we were reading about. The ruins itself are interesting with good walkways around it.
reviews/11/text: This is a very elegant and artistic chapel. The sculptures and paintings are unique and extremely beautiful. You absolutely have to see it!
reviews/12/text: Somewhat confusing entrance. To get to the church you must enter through the museum and use the walk-ways. We were not the only ones lost. Fascinating structure that remains.
reviews/13/text: This was a functioning monastery for centuries. The bottom was flooded by the river but it still persisted. The museum has a nice collection of relics that explain the history of the place. The building is mostly a shell but you still get a good feeling about what it must have been like.
reviews/14/text: There is a fascinating visitors centre explaining the history of the convent, its frequent flooding and life in a convent from the 14th century. A visit to the remaining church is a must, particularly as it gives you access to the upper areas which normally are not accessible
reviews/14/title: Save half a day for this visit
reviews/15/text: A step back in time to relive some history. A must see for anybody visiting coimbra, beautiful architecture, stunning art and dramatic backdrop of ancient tombs & crypts. Take the time to discover this monument at your own pace but beware of street sellers inside who tell you that your purchase is for the restoration work. Not true.
reviews/16/text: Went here and paid 4 euros to get in, you start by looking at a few displays with an informative book telling the history of the place and items that they have found. You then go out side and you can walk around the kitchen garden befor you go to the ruins of the church and the attached convent. Very interesting and worth the money.
reviews/17/text: It is well worth the 4 euros to take a tour of these ruins. It is quite an awe-inspiring experience to be standing inside them....a bit creepy....a bit mysterious....and a lot cool!
reviews/18/text: If you are interested in church architecture this place could interest you, as it has the graves of the first kings of Portugal and nice elements from several architectural periods.
reviews/18/title: A veey nice place woth visitig
reviews/19/text: You can visit the remains of the old cloistre, visit collection of artecats and see a short movie about the Moseiro. Now what I recommend is that you first see the movie (15 minutes) and after that visit the remains outside. The movie shows the history of the Mosteiro, from the foundation untll the time the sisters abandoned the place and the river destructed it. It makes your walk around in the ruins much more directed and the whole place comes more alive that way.
reviews/19/title: impressive remains of the medieval Mosteiro
subcategory_ranking: #8 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Calcada Martim de Freitas Coimbra University, Coimbra 3000-456 Portugal
name: Jardim Botanico
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Discovering the charms and places of Coimbra
ranking: #14 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #14 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: We visited this garden as the sun was setting.  We only spent about 30 min. But it was wonderful.  The fountains, ponds, trees, and sounds of nature.  My favorite part was the bamboo pathway!
reviews/1/text: After visiting the University, we strolled through the botanical garden.  It is in need of some repair, however it remains beautiful and impressive with its fountains and ponds.  Has hints of royal gardens.  Was build by the King to be used by the University to study botany.
reviews/2/text: Beautiful tranquil gardens. A lovely route down from the university area to the riverside. Spectacular bamboo forest, atmospheric fountain and many different trees. Best of all it is free.
reviews/2/title: A green oasis in the city
reviews/3/text: Nice gardens (including a tropical glasshouse) with labelled trees  from Portugal and overseas. Good place to let the children play and enjoy themselves. Can be quite hot in summer so take some water.
reviews/3/title: Nice place if you have children in your group
reviews/4/text: Peaceful and spectacular. Bamboo forest so special. Formal areas beautiful too,. Special part of city, lovely even in Winter.
reviews/5/text: This walk is a challenge with all the up hill climbing, but so worth it! It’s quiet, lovely and you can hear the birds sing. Very few tourists and best of all it’s free! My wife & I climbed it several times and found it to be a convenient access to the University. For a while this path makes you forget you are in a city!
reviews/5/title: A quiet path to the entrance of the historic University...
reviews/6/text: An easy place to access.  Part of the University and a place to go to stroll or do nothing but relax.
reviews/6/title: An Everyday Getaway in the Middle of Coimbra
reviews/7/text:
I liked this botanical garden because it was very green and well kept. Also, there was a lot of security and they would make sure that people kept the masks on. 
Open clean bathrooms
Clean entrance
reviews/8/text: Going to Coimbra for most visitors the University is a must, mainly the University Library. Quite close to it one may find the Botanical Garden; in my opinion it is worth to plan some time to visit it as well. Don’t forget that Portugal was an Empire and from the four corners of the Globe were brought plants to the Garden. Enjoy!
reviews/9/text: My wife and I decided to walk down to the lower town from the university via the botanical garden and were pleased we did. Not a lot was blooming in February but there was still plenty to see.  There were some huge and obviously extremely old camellia trees and a very attractive formal garden at the top.  We then walked down via a bamboo grove almost as big as those I've had the pleasure to see in Japan.  There were some parts of the garden which were overgrown and others where the ground had been churned up presumably by tractors and it certainly seemed a bit neglected in places. Nevertheless a very pleasant way to walk from the upper town down to the river.
reviews/9/title: Very enjoyable if rather neglected looking garden
reviews/10/text: A rather average garden which offers the benefits of shade and peace away from the bustle of the rest of the town. Some lovely spots to picnic or just sit.
reviews/11/text: A visit to the Botanic Garden is like travelling around the planet earth without leaving the city. The plant collections which occupy every corner of the Garden take us on a journey to distinct latitudes and regions of the world, thus transforming the Garden into a living museum.
reviews/12/text: Such a wild surprise in the middle of Coimbra. The garden is a mixture of order and wildness. I would have loved to spend more time wandering but we were almost locked in at 5.00 (winter) and had to hurry to a gate upon hearing a ringing bell. This free access garden is definitely worth a visit.
reviews/13/text: We were with family visiting from the States and took the Hop On Hop Off bus and walked from there to another hop on. We stayed until the park closed but killed some time there.
reviews/13/title: Beautiful, will try for spring colors next year.
reviews/14/text: It was a great pleasure to walk through this garden in order to pass through a part of the city in order to reach University area. It has old trees and gorgeous fountain.
reviews/15/text:
Founded in 1772-1774, considered one of the most beautiful of Europe, occupies 13 hectares can be divided in two parts.

The first part, located at the top of the valley, constitutes the most formal area and it is divided in terraces. The second part of the garden, including the valley where once a small stream flowed, is the arboretum.

Tips about Coimbra, starting from ‘’Down to Top’’ or as our hotel concierge said ‘’da Baixa para a Alta’’:

- Visit the ‘’Largo da Portagem’’ or Portagem Square: use that opportunity to take some pictures from Santa Clara Bridge and to eat some typical regional sweets on ‘’Briosa’’.
- Go all the way up, from the downtown part to the university: go from street Ferreira Borges, passing by on ‘’Arco da Almedina’’, continue to go up to find ‘’Fado ao Centro’’ if you want to listen to Coimbra Fado (it is different from Lisboa Fado) or get a glass of wine on ‘’Quebra o’galho’’ (tapas/bar). After running up the ‘’Quebra Costas’’ which means in english ‘’back breaker’’ (it is just a super old staircase),  you will find ‘’Sé Velha’’ (the old church) and in within 5 more minutes you will arrive to Coimbra University, on that area you can look for the Law School (the one with the beautiful tower, that you can visit) and look for ‘’Biblioteca Joanina’’ (the one with Bat’s).
- Botanic Garden – just do not miss it, it is not that big and it is super close from the University. 😊
- On your way down to the car just go to ‘’Praça da Republica’’/’’Republic Square, where you can find ‘’Cartola’’ the most iconic college bar in Coimbra, where you can ask for a ‘’fino’’/ craft beer.
- Follow the road then turn left: As we said, just go down on that road feel watching the gardens, pass over the ‘’Mercado’’ and turn left on the City Hall, and you will find Square 8th of may and Sta. Cruz Curch, after that you only need to to go all the way on street Ferreira Borges again until you find your car.
- Just a few restaurants in case you start to get hungry: Dux, Zé Manel dos Ossos, Restaurante O Nacional, Praxys and Restaurante Joaquim dos Leitões (the speciality is Suckling Pig, literally one of the best if not the best thing you can try in Portugal).
reviews/15/title: Beautiful curated botanical garden - worth a walkthrough before or after visiting the University
reviews/16/text: Despite reconstruction work taking place late September 2019, it's still worth visiting. Beautiful trees, arches and views. The greenhouse was closed for refurbishment. The aqueduct at one of the exits is great but trying to get a photo without the busy traffic is  impossible. Highly recommend visiting.
reviews/17/text: This is a lovely, tranquil garden near the University. The recent hurricane caused a lot of damage, but the staff are doing a fabulous job bringing it back to a its former state. A great place to gather oneself after a long day of touring.
reviews/18/text: This was a really beautiful garden with a wide variety of botanicals. Unfortunately a heave windstorm came through a couple of years ago and broke large limbs of trees. The glass houses were especially hard hit and are all closed. Nonetheless, we enjoyed a quiet walk together in a pleasant setting.
reviews/18/title: Nice place for a quiet walk
reviews/19/text: A storm in 2018 had affected the garden, but there is no evidence of any attempt to restore it. The glasshouse seemed to be undamaged but was firmly closed, as were several areas of the garden. Even those parts that were open were full of weeds, with no sign of any care being taken of what could be a beautiful space.
subcategory_ranking: #14 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Largo da Porta Ferrea Universidade de Coimbra, Coimbra 3000-447 Portugal
name: Biblioteca Joanina
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: University of Coimbra guided tours without queue
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Coimbra Exclusive Walking Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Coimbra and Aveiro small group tour from Porto with river cruise
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Aveiro and Coimbra private tour from Porto
ranking: #4 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #4 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
While the library was beautiful, it was not worth the entrance fee to only get 10 min to see with absolutely no relevant information.  I did read through their handout which mostly spoke about how bats were used for pest control.  You couldn’t get any information about the book collection due to security.
I’ve seen libraries just as interesting or more in other European and American universities.  
They may not have been as old but they showcased their collection and history.
Also, we were interested in only seeing the library but you couldn’t buy a library option only.
reviews/1/text: Paid  €13.50 to visit the library, Chapel, Royal Palace, chemistry lab and Botanical Gardens.  Duly turned up at 16.20 and were shown the Baroque library which of course is stunning and worth a visit.  Left in there for 10mins with just a sheet for info so we looked up some more info on our mobiles.  It would be better to have a guide to talk about the library and point out all the interesting features.  We felt we were just shut in there for 10mins and when our time was up, a door was opened and we were unceremoniously shown out back into the square.  From there, we had no idea how to get to any of the other places listed on our ticket so we headed to the gift shop to ask.  We were given directions to the Chapel (again, stunning and worth a visit),  and after a quick look around, we asked the staff member how to get to the Royal Palace only to be told it closed at 16.45!  We didn't bother going to the chemistry lab as we had no idea how to get there and assumed it would be closed too.  As it was raining heavily, we didn't visit the botanical gardens.  We headed back to shop to have a look round about 16.50pm to be told by the staff member that it was shut.  All in all, I feel the signage is poor and was shocked that they offer tickets at 16.40 on the website when thst only gives you time to visit the library and nothing else! Perhaps there is the option to go to the other items on the ticket before the library - but this is not made clear - there is NO info whatsoever about this.  We felt disappointed and ripped off - this could be done better....
reviews/2/text: Magical place to visit in Coimbra university. You can not enter from the main door because they prevent books with certain temperature and light limits. You are slowed to stay only 10 minutes.
reviews/3/text: This is an historical site that cannot be disregarded. It is a must-see. There is timed entry and I think that there was an entry fee. But it is one of the oldest libraries in Europe, and it is beautiful!
reviews/4/text: This is an interesting tour of three different spaces, including the Academic prison, the intermediate space, and finally the beautiful historic library. Nice information sheets available in different languages. Best to buy tickets online in advance to avoid waiting in line or being disappointed. Of all the nice things we did in Coimbra, this was the most expensive and rushed, in that they told us we only had 10 minutes in the library (apparently standard). Highly recommended nonetheless.
reviews/5/text: amazing and beautiful library!  must be part of a guided tour although the visit is brief (less than an hour maximum).  no photography allowed.
reviews/6/text: If you haven't already purchased your ticket online, when you buy the ticket at the Coimbra University ticket office at the end of Rua Estudos, you also get the time at which your guided tour to the library starts. It follows that the visit to the different parts of the University must be organized and divided keeping in mind this time. For example we had the time to visit the Royal Palace with the Great Acts Room (former Throne Room) and the Private Exam Room leaving the rest until after the library visit. The entrance to the library (a side door of the Palace of Schools) is accessed by going down a staircase located at the right end of the square looking at the Mondego river. The guided (but not informative) tour begins with ticket checking and then you are directed without explanation to an area immediately to the left of the access door. A series of unfurnished and insignificant rooms which we later discovered were the Academic Prisons (we don't know for whom). After about ten minutes uselessly spent here, the guided tour continues in the Intermediate Floor (a space which is used as a repository for less important books and documents that do not have space in the Library). Here we took the only photos because we were told that photography was prohibited on the next floor. After another ten minutes we were able to go up to the Noble Floor of the Library.  Here without any explanation we remained about ten minutes in the central corridor from which we could see the shelves with precious books, the reading tables and the refined furnishings of the walls and ceiling. Certainly, given the distant date of foundation of the University of Coimbra, the books contained here will be of inestimable value and it is right that they are preserved by controlling the environment and optimizing the visits, but perhaps the procedures of this tour should be completely reconsidered.
reviews/6/title: A tour whose procedures should be reconsidered
reviews/7/text:
It may be controversial to say… but this is nothing special. Europe is full of amazing things, and this is over hyped. 
By all means, go if you have some spare time. But you don’t need to go out of your way.

Difficulty booking online and poor directions and communication, also make it just an average experience.
reviews/8/text: One of the most beautiful libraries in the world, this baroque library built in the early 18th century in on the campus of the Universidade de Coimbra. The craftsmanship is unparalleled. There are three halls with books from floor to ceiling. We were told that most of the books can be requested from their archives on computer.
reviews/9/text: This is a spectacular library and very much worth visiting. It is part of the palace which is the old centre of the University of Coimbra.
reviews/10/text: This library is a gorgeous space at the University of Coimbra and former palace of the King of Portugal.
reviews/11/text: We booked the university and library tour directly with the university office but were disappointed that it was not really a tour but just allowing you to walk around the areas on your own.  The library was beautiful but no one tells you anything and the handouts they have there explaining things were hard to come by in English.  There were only a few.  Same can be said for the chapel, palace etc.  It would have been much more enjoyable and interesting if some one would have acted as a tour guide.
reviews/12/text:
My wife & I found the University of Coimbra Library a worthwhile experience. We did have difficulty finding the ticket office about 2 blocks from the library. If you take a taxi make sure you ask for the ticket office not the library !
We did not wait for the English language tour but most of the guides explained the history & significance of the building in both Portuguese & English. This is one of the oldest libraries in the world and when it was in use students had to pay to read the books. But again some the books are pre-printing press. We highly recommend this tour. The building is interesting by itself.
reviews/13/text: Very impressive old bibliography, but 12,5€ and it is not allowed to take fotos, and even worse there are no further information to it. Even though we booked the tour we just got out with the knowledge, that there are old books.
reviews/13/title: Too expensive, no fotos allowed, no information
reviews/14/text:
The Portuguese are very friendly and welcoming, so I wonder where they picked up the staff at the Joanina Library.
The guy at the entrance door tells us in an annoyed tone that we have to climb the stairs to buy the tickets since the online system does not work (wrong: it works, we bought our tickets online) and that there are no toilets on the premises (wrong: there are toilets, read further on). Then, when a group of 20-30 people are gathered outside the entrance door, he graciously herds us all into the first room, the academic prison, and graciously locks us in. BTW: we were stuck there for ten minutes with 20-30 people and my husband I were the ONLY people wearing a mask (ours were FFP2 masks). After ten minutes of waiting (no explanation provided, only sticky papers if you dare to touch them, or qrcode that do not work since there is no connection in there), a white door opens and a young woman ushers us to the second room (a sort of 'new library') welcoming us with a series of 'don't'. We are locked again between two doors. No way back, no way forward. And, again, no explanation provided. Other ten minutes of waiting and then the young woman opens another door and, after climbing a very steep staircase, we are finally admitted to the sancta sanctorum of the Joanina Library. Beautiful and interesting: ancient books, painted woods, and trompe l'oeil. Beautiful and interesting library but not so rare I would say, if you know other ancient libraries - there are so many around Europe, and in most of them you can even sit and study!! Can you imagine that?? Again, other ten minutes stuffed in a locked room with people with no masks. We try to move to reach the exit but the man there says he cannot open the door because the light would ruin the books. EXcuse me??? Other equally ancient libraries around Europe have adopted more sophisticated systems to prevent the book decay than locking up 20-30 people in the same room. When we are finally out, we move towards the attached chapel where we are welcomed by a smiling lady (finally!), we are able to visit it and to get out at our convenience - at the exit door, another smiling man. The toilets are on the left when you leave the chapel - can anyone inform the guy at the entrance, please?
A final note. After a few days, my husband and I are not feeling well. To cut it short, we got both positive. Is this a legacy of being stuck for so long in crowded rooms in the Joanina Library? It's a good thing taking care of books, but I would also say that taking care of people is an equally good thing. And, if you can't imagine a more rational system of a visiting path, at least ask everyone to wear a mask. Icing on the cake: the ticket costs 12.50 per person - 25 euros for two is a huge price for such an awful experience.
reviews/14/title: Worst visting experience EVER!! Very impolite staff and terribly organized path.
reviews/15/text: Amazing, fantastic and incredible. These are just a few words that come to mind to describe this Library. We were not planning to go to Coimbra and ended up there and were so glad we did. the town/city and University were amazing and this library has to be seen!
reviews/16/text: This was an interesting tour that didn’t have a lot to see but walking into this library was breathtaking-  I haven’t seen anything like it!  I wish we were allowed to take pictures and you have 10 min time limit, but it was a very beautiful place to look around.
reviews/17/text:
The Joanine Libray in the Old Univeristy of Coimbra is not to be missed as it is both a unique repositary of ancient books and a magnificent artistic achievement. We were told there would be a tour but in fact there were only a few explanations on sheets. Nevertheless it left a moving and marvellous memory. Book in advance.
P.S. no photography allowed.
reviews/17/title: Magnificent but delicate and no explanation given (we were told it was a tour)
reviews/18/text: After reading all the reviews, we were excited to tour this library on our brief stay in Coimbra.  Sadly, we did not.  Portuguese is not our primary language and trying to find this building - even asking locals for directions - took nearly 1 hour, only to find we had to purchase our tickets in another place on the campus.  The campus signage is not the best.  Unfortunately, all the tours were booked out for the day.   If going, be sure to download the map of the university, and get your tickets booked well in advance.  We will return and try again to see such a beautiful place.
reviews/19/text: I was amazed when entering this library as it is extremely ornate and led me to wonder what it was like being a college student  800 years ago.
reviews/19/title: This is a "must see" in Coimbra
subcategory_ranking: #4 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Jardim do Portugal dos Pequenitos, Coimbra 3040-202 Portugal
name: Portugal dos Pequenitos
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Aveiro and Coimbra - Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Classic car city tour – Coimbra ride
ranking: #23 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #23 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
The tour is of a modest number of concrete buildings. The majority have QR codes to scan for information with their app - but that app “wasn’t available in our region” (US) so there was little information. 

In total we spent only 20 minutes in the park and found it to be one of the more disappointing experiences in Portugal.  At 14.95/ per ticket wasn’t worth the stop.
reviews/1/text: It is difficult to describe this place ,inside the entrance there are buildings representing portuguese colonies with some interesting facts beyond that there are structures from various regions of Portugal made up of features from buildings from those areas ,some of the features are quite small the structures are not full sized but can be accessed by adults. Beyond the above there are small scale i.e children sized models of mainly rural buildings from different regions beyond that there is a childrens play area. We could not understand why there was no cafe in the children centered area .
reviews/1/title: Our grandchildren would have enjoyed it
reviews/2/text: A disappointing experience that was terribly overpriced. The idea is good and we've been to other miniature villages in Europe, but this one simply did not deliver.
reviews/3/text: I'm not sure how this "park" even reached the top 20 to do list in Coimbra, but it's a complete scam. The atractions are in decay, dirty, fountains in desperate need of new water. The only lesson that I could teach my daughter is about capitalism: you can charge full price for a ticket and have 30% or less of the atractions open.
reviews/3/title: Terrible, not fun and only 30% or less of atractions open.
reviews/4/text:
Portugal dos Pequenitos is as I remember. An old gem. But I more concerned about some of these comments over here. They are absolutely idiotic. 
Some say this theme park is racist… it’s hilarious… this park was found during Estado Novo regime.. so you can expect (unfortunately) some racism on statues and other stuff around..  and you know what? It’s a freaking reminder to not to be racist… to not be like that again… 
You are aware now: you will encounter some stuff racist. 

Other thing to some erudite folks around here: 
At least you know how was the foundation of Portugal? Do you think it was with hugs and kisses? No my friend, it was a bloody mess. They had to kill a lot of “mouros” (North African people)… - you know who you are (the laugh buy from France). 

And if you expect to know more about Portugal, just google it please.. everyone complaining about the lack of digital stuff, but don’t google info… 

Well just go with your kids and see the houses and monuments and enjoy the 2 hours stay. Then, grab a freaking car and visit the real ones… that’s a good trip.
reviews/4/title: Some of these comments are pure laugh
reviews/5/text: Kids love it! It is a wonderful place to spend 3 or 4 hours with your kids. It is highly recommended.
reviews/5/title: Great! Do visit with your kids!
reviews/6/text: A collection of miniatures of buildings from the North to the South of Portugal. Also with the representation of Portugal's presence in the world. Some impressive craftsmanship and a document of classical Portuguese architecture and culture. Kids have great fun going in and out of mini buildings and feeling like a Gulliver.
reviews/6/title: Great fun for the little ones
reviews/7/text: Odd place , adult entry 10 euro which I feel is a bit over priced for what it is . Long ques to get in and personally I don't feel worth it
reviews/8/text: Very expensive tickets, €16.00 per person, badly maintained, ita a Little Portuguese want to be Epcot centre, but falls short. The lakes/fountains don't work everything needs tlc and is not getting it...a fraud for the price; €5.00 would be more adequate
reviews/9/text: Portugal dos Pequenitos is a place out of our time. It was built around 1940 when the dictator Salazar organized the famous "Portuguese World" exhibition in Lisbon to rebuilt the idea of Portuguese colonialism. At that time, the regime propaganda spread the ideology that there was only a Portugal from "Minho to Timor," and the colonial territories became Portuguese provinces. This park for children was meant to teach these ideas. Therefore, one can observe miniatures of the main Portuguese monuments -- Belem Tower, Jeronimos, Batalha, Univerity of Coimbra, etc. -- along with showcase pavilions of all Portuguese colonies from Angola to East Timor. Despite the chance of these pavillions to places for independent Portuguese speaking countries, the old colonial odor is still around. Moreover, the area has not any good restaurant or primary amenities, trying to sell what is old and odd. My kids didn't enjoy it after taking some pictures in miniature houses from Alentejo. We won't return.
reviews/9/title: The nostalgia of Portuguese Salazar colonialism for kids
reviews/10/text: This place is absolutely hilarious, it was built during the fascist regime and you can clearly tell, it’s extremely neglected, maintenance is an absolute disgrace, they probably haven’t done any since the fascist regime 😂 the people who give this place a good review have probably never traveled anywhere. Either way, it’s great for having a laugh, if you are cultured and know your history about fascism, this is an absolute gem, it’s like traveling back in time, everything is absolutely nationalistic and racist as anything during the fascist regime was, there is a statue of the founder of Portugal trampling Arab people with a text which reads “children, remember this figure and this ideology” 😂 it also has dolls with a beard which were used for depicting famous Portuguese people from history 😂
reviews/11/text: This place was created by the Second Republic, the New Regime, the fascist regime, as such has an interesting historical value, but it is dilapidated. Visit it before it crumbles.
reviews/11/title: Quite old, a interesting insight into the "New Regime"
reviews/12/text:
Was a great day in Coimbra for my oldest son who like it very much.
Some souvenirs are also interesting. Do suggest for around 2 hours.
reviews/12/title: Great day for the small ones
reviews/13/text: This is a mid priced attraction at 10 euros per adult. It shows buildings with different styles from Portugal homeland and colonies. It is a fun place, good way to learn about portugal, but more info would be nice at each building. Works nicely for kids.
reviews/13/title: Good way to know Portugal in a hurry
reviews/14/text: It is really fun place for the kids to explore. They loved going around the little houses. Our experience was a little negative at times because of some rude families but that's just bad luck.
reviews/15/text: Quirky and compelling, the park has three sections, the first detailing countries from the Portuguese empire, the second offers a snapshot of portuguese landmarks in miniture, and the third section illustrates typical architecture throughout Portugal, again in miniture. Easily absorbs an hour and a half having a look round. Probably best to go midweek out of season if you can to avoid the crowds. Two tips, one is the ticket window is a tiny window on the right hand side of the main entrance, second is there are some nice cafes just outside. There is ample parking in the multistorey carpark on the other side of the roundabout opposite the entrance.
reviews/16/text: Went here with our 1 year old. At first we thought she was too small, but she had a lot of fun crawling and walking through all the monuments. The first part with the colonies is super weird - no info on them, just a “look what we conquered” nationalistic nonsense - but the rest of the park is great.
reviews/17/text: We visited this park to pass sometime on a “not a beach day” kind of day. I had very low expectations, you can maybe kill an hour here. My six year old lost interest fast, not really engaging and half the houses and windows were closed which is not ideal. There’s a wee train that you can take but otherwise didn’t  hold the attention of my six year old for long and I didn’t relish having to explain about ivory trade and why there was an elephant foot. For the price I would totally give it a pass, to echo what others have said it seems to un-ironically celebrate colonization which is a bit cringe worthy.
reviews/18/text: OK, get any sense of a Model Village or Lego World out of your mind - this is nothing less than a rich person's collection (think Horniman in UK or Eastman in US) from all corners of the ex-Portugese-ruled globe, displayed in miniature buildings that copy the ex-Imperial originals. So while you potter round the East Timor, Macau, African or South American pavilions (or, more entertainingly, the reduced-size Portugese houses of all eras) you get some nice collectables to look over, or a playground, ice cream concession or kids film about Vasco da Gama. It will fill an hour, but not if you're over-12, and, to be frank, celebrates an exploratory past which is questionable, to say the least, and would be better curated in countries more aware of their bloodthirsty imperialist past.
reviews/19/text: It is very nicely done, the replicas are pretty accurate even in their small size, yet, the place is not big, so you can finish in an hour, it is lucking the wow effect...
