reviews/0/text: Beautiful church in the heart of this historic town. Visit the cafe nextdoor  which was a church in itself.
reviews/1/text: Absolutely beautiful church, but pay the €3 and go back to the courtyard, chapel, and sacristy! Full of history and detail! Worth the visit!
reviews/2/text: The church of the monastery was built in the 12th century, much of the church dates from a restoration in the 1500s.
reviews/3/text: We really enjoyed this place. You'll spend a little over an hour here (which includes taking pictures), visiting both the church and convent/cloisters. Definitely some pretty tiles and a crazy relic room. There's both an audio guide in English and plenty of descriptions in English, along with nice art and a gorgeous choir loft.
reviews/4/text: Be sure to walk all the way in the church until you find the entrance into the monastery.  Definitely worth a visit, walk the hallways, visit the chapel where the first king of Portugal is buried along with his son.  I love the architecture and try to imagine living in ancient times.
reviews/5/text: This is a beautiful & very peaceful cathedral with a lovely main church area as well as an upstairs cloister area in which to walk around and enjoy the peace & quiet despite still being within the city. Please note that it, like much of Coimbra, requires walking up steep cobblestone streets.
reviews/6/text: Beautiful historic site.  It is very close to the center of town and definitely worth a visit.  Be sure to go to the upstairs/outdoor courtyard, it is really incredible.
reviews/7/text:
Besides the Coimbra University this Church and Monastery is an absolute must for any tourist visiting Coimbra.
It is located at the end of the main pedestrian street, next door to the City Hall behind an ornate Romanesque-Manuelino facade.
The complex dates back to 12-13 century when Coimbra was the nation's capital, while Manuelino decorations were added later in 16 c.
For a very cheap entry fee of few Euros you can visit the entire complex: Church with amazing Azulejos decorations, Monastery and cloisters, sacristy and elevated choir stalls which were moved on the second floor to make space for tombs of Portuguese first two kings on the ground floor by the altar, part dedicated to St. Anthony who spent part of his life here,...etc
Once again, unmissable and must visit place for any serious traveler.
reviews/8/text: We're so glad we visited the Sacristy of Santa Cruz. The attendant there was very enthusiastic and made sure we made the most of our visit.
reviews/9/text: The tile work is impressive and my favorite part.  The Monastery is a separate area and is beautiful, but you need to buy a ticket.  We were in a hurry and rushed in to see the churct.
reviews/10/text: We had visited this church on our own, and then later while on a guided tour.  As told to us, sometimes the azulejos fall and they have to be replaced as soon as possible so that the rest of the azulejos are not exposed to additional unnecessary humidity.  But how do you replace centuries-old azulejos? Just know that they do!
reviews/11/text: magnificent church and cloister. Friendly staff. beautiful azulejos and interesting stories. We enjoyed our visit
reviews/11/title: Beautiful and worth a visit, if a little run-down
reviews/12/text: Be sure to purchase tickets before visiting the Chapel. Tickets are available to purchase at the ticket office located across the street from the University Chemistry Laboratory. Due to Covid, entrance is restricted to small numbers of visitors. The Chapel is small so we appreciated the restriction of numbers of visitors inside at any one time. The historic chapel is beautiful with a magnificent ceiling.
reviews/13/text: We really enjoyed our visit to the monastery. It was really good value at €3. The inside art, architecture were stunning. I particularly liked the surrounds of the choir stalls and the view from this gallery. The information about each room, accessed by your phone was very informative. I would recommend a visit here.
reviews/14/text: Beautiful church, and well worth the expense to visit the mosterio and cloisters. There's a lot of treasures to see, and the woman at the entrance couldnot have been nicer or more informative!
reviews/15/text: This church is just in the center of the city. Really speacial facade and for me inside it wasn't much.
reviews/16/text: The monastery is worth to visit, it has an interesting collection and churchad. Also with your mobile phone you will have access to the information about the rooms and exhibitions. Also the staff is very friendly and helpfull.
reviews/17/text: The Church of Santa Cruz is located in the center of Coimbra, the historic center, in a very charming place. A very nice church. It was erected in the first half of the  XII century. Lots to see, lots of history. The heart of the Romanesque church is an unusual altar without a statue, and two amazing tombs of Portugal's first rulers: Alphonsus I the Conqueror and Sancho I. The blue azulejos tiles are a characteristic feature of the church. The interior of the temple is decorated with a huge organ with fantastic Japanese works of art. A monastery  is a real gem. A must visit if you are in Coimbra.  Next to it is a square with a number of cafes.
reviews/18/text: The church and Monastery of Santa Cruz is a clear example of the fact that supporters of preserving authenticity are not always right. Reconstruction, carried out on the orders of King Manuel I, went to Santa Cruz in favor. The main facade of the monastery in the Manuelino style of the first third of the XVI century is magnificent. Azulejos on the Bible in the Church, one of the best examples of the genre. In the Main Chapel of the temple there are tombs of the first kings of Portugal Afonso I the Great and Sancho I. The tombs, which combine elements of Gothic and Renaissance, were made in the XVI century by Nicolau Chanterin, who also worked in the old cathedral. The entrance to the church is free, but to visit the sacristy and cloister you need to pay 2.5 euros.
reviews/18/title: When the reconstruction is only good...
reviews/19/text: It is a very nice place with an awesome sacristy and very nice cloister. The style is mixed with many "Manuelino" details (manuelino art was a late Gothic from Portugal). It really deserves a visit to catch a glimpse of the life of monks in Coimbra during old times

name: Torre da Universidade de Coimbra
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Full Day Fátima and Coimbra Private Tour from Porto
ranking: #6 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #6 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: Located on the campus of the Universidade de Coimbra, this 18 th century clock & bell tower rising above the courtyard, is one of Coimbra's most famous landmark. You can tale a guided tour or go by yourself. Amazing views of the city and the Mondego river.
reviews/1/text:
Gorgeous area. Wide open courtyard. Views of the City. Beautiful buildings.
We spent about 1/2 just gazing at it all.
reviews/1/title: Worth the trip up w/out the elevator
reviews/2/text:
Incredible history & architecture! This is definitely worth it- we did a self tour however a guide is better if you are looking for a thorough understanding! 
This literally gave me a understanding of the enlightenment period !
reviews/3/text:
The University tower stands in the corner of the University square between the Sao Miguel Chapel and University Palace.
It is not included in your combo ticket, but with it you pay only 50 cents to climb it.
I must emphasize I climbed many towers all over Europe, and this one by far has the narrowest staircase I've ever seen. In the upper part it is impossible to bypass other visitors, therefore they have staff at the bottom and at the top which communicate when people can go. For that reason people with claustrophobic and mobility issues should avoid it.
Once up, you have amazing views of entire Coimbra and further countryside, as the University plateau is already on top of a hill.
reviews/4/text: This impressive tower, built from 1728-33, is not the reason one would come to this part of the university.  That would be the library and chapel.  However, it is certainly nice to see.
reviews/5/text: This is the belltower in one of the main plazas of the university and very impressive. It is sometimes possible to ascend and get an even more wonderful view of the surroundings of the town but for mobility reasons we did not attempt this. The view from the balusrades of the placa were sufficient.
reviews/5/title: Impresive tower which it is sometimes possible to climb
reviews/6/text: We observed this lovely tower while we were walking around.  It is among the handful of beautiful old buildings on the campus and one of the reasons why you visit.
reviews/7/text: We were a very small walking group tour and arrived by foot. Interesting the buildings and more so the stories behind what one sees. Good views over the city and surrounding areas..
reviews/8/text: Not open to the public at this time. Be sure to check if the Tower  is open prior to your visit. In fact, much of the Square in front of the Tower is under construction.
reviews/9/text: Beautiful building and surrounding areas.  The views are amazing.  Its a good walk up the hill but so worth it.  Would recommend everyone visit
reviews/10/text: This tower was built in the years 1728–1733. You can climb to the top to observe the city and its surroundings. The tower is 32 meters high, 184 steps, no elevator, spiral staircase and is quite narrow so not recommended for people with heart problems, claustrophobia or dizziness. You have a great view of Coimbra. The way to climb is really narrow, so be careful . A place worth visiting.
reviews/10/title: From the tower you can enjoy a breathtaking view
reviews/11/text: After crossing "Porta Férrea" and reaching the stunning "Paço das Escolas" of the "Universidade de Coimbra", you will be almost in front of this awesome clock and bell tower! Built between 1728 and 1733, by Italian architect António Cannevari, it is mostly known, among the University students, as "Torre da Cabra", as one of its four bells is nicknamed as "Sino da Cabra" (literally, the "Goat Bell" in English). The tower has always had an important role in the University life, due to the frequent sign sounds from its four bronze bells. You can even climb to its top! Climbing up may be quite "challenging", but fantastic views of the University campus and of "Rio Mondego" await you! Enjoy!
reviews/11/title: The breathtaking 18th century Torre da Cabra!
reviews/12/text: Wonderful location to visit. The buildings are beautiful and many of the older buildings are well preserved. Highly recommended
reviews/13/text: It is not easy to get up , especially for the elder people but it has a merit : one may view the beautiful surroundings
reviews/14/text: The university is a must on any visit to Coimbra, especially the stunning Biblioteca Joanina, but this review is purely for the university's eighteenth-century bell tower. We climbed it today and were very glad we did, as it was a beautiful day and we were rewarded with a splendid view of the university, Coimbra, the river and the surrounding landscape. For anyone thinking of trying it, however, it is worth knowing beforehand that it is not only a tough climb but also the stone spiral staircase is very narrow and in places a bit claustrophobic. The staff make sure that nobody has to pass each other on the way up or down, which would be impossible, so there is no need to worry about that, but still it would be challenging for anyone uncomfortable in narrow spaces.
reviews/15/text: Just an amazing complex with a stunning massive courtyard that has an infinity edge look down the mountain and river. The Unesco site is amazing with the massive library and its huge wood doors, the royal palace, and the beautiful church. Must visit stop. Top of the mountain with a tough walk up the streets so take a bus or taxi up there and especially when it rains to avoid a catastrophic fall down the steep streets.
reviews/15/title: Highlight of the trip! Amazing buildings and a ton of history!
reviews/16/text:
A focal point of the gorgeous central university square it made for a glorious sight, soaring with a backdrop of the deep azure sky.

We heard it melodiously ringing out the passing time on a number of occasions during our stay.
reviews/17/text: The climb is not for claustrophobic or overweight. The views are not tremendous, but pretty nice. If you have time to spare and enjoy elevated points of view, it is a nice diversion.
reviews/18/text: You can enjoy a full 360° view from this place. Entrance is 2 EUR, but if you see some other stuff at the university (which I also recommend), then it's just 1 EUR. The way up is very narrow though.
reviews/19/text: Definitely not a good option if you're claustrophobic, fear heights or dread steps. Otherwise it'll definitely be the best view of the city you will get. Perfect place for taking pictures in Coimbra!
reviews/19/title: Great Aerial View of the City

reviews/0/text: My husband & I crossed this bridge both during the day and at night. There is a charming park located near the bridge as well as a botanical garden that offers a climb up to the old University. Don't miss the views at night when the historical city & fountain in the river are all lit up! Simply magical!
reviews/0/title: A lovely stroll across this pedestrian bridge...
reviews/1/text: The colorful pedestrian bridge (which lights up at night), the gigantic topiary-like green bear and the water fountain (which changes color at night) in the middle of the Mondego River are enchanting!  Public walkways along the river bring direct access to the river & water fowl. This park provides a quiet respite from the busy streets of Coimbra. It is a favorite with the locals!
reviews/2/text: Great place to walk and relax. This one of the places I liked the most and you can see all the locals relaxing here.
reviews/3/text: This park is in desperate need of uplift and maintenance. The Mondego river crests havoc at time, but it is no excuse for leaving it in the state it is.
reviews/4/text: We took a stroll on Christmas day and walked through this park.  They had just had some terrible storms and flooding, so we saw some of the effects of that.  But still a beautiful place to take a walk.
reviews/5/text: Wonderful park in both margins of the river Mondego. South margin is best for sunbathing, water sports, including kayaks and stand-up paddle for rent and the water is perfectly safe for a bath. There is a pedestrian bridge linking the river margins.
reviews/5/title: Relax, sunbathing and water sports. Great for kids.
reviews/6/text: this is the place to take your shoes off, lay back on the grass, and enjoy the view. There's the town, capped by the jewel of the University, across the river. There are boats, rowing up and down the river. Down the way a local fisherman waits for one of his long, slender poles to dip. Slow down. Breathe. enjoy.
reviews/7/text: We walked along this pretty path after touring around the city. It is a pleasant place to stroll along the river and there was a restaurant that looked like it might be a nice place to relax and grab a little bite to eat. They appear to be working on the park, perhaps fixing it up a bit as there was apparently bad river flooding in 2016 that destroyed much it.
reviews/7/title: Pretty short path along the river
reviews/8/text: This is a nice shady spot along the river. Great for a picnic or a way to get out of the heat. There is food available at a restaurant.
reviews/9/text: After the 2016 winter the bars and restaurants are ruined. They were flooded and never salvaged since that. They are a terrible sign of the City council  dismissal.
reviews/10/text: It is a nice park by the river though it was muddy in spots after the rains.  The benches all seem to face the street rather than the river so that is the direction you will be looking if you decide to sit there.
reviews/10/title: All the benches face away from the river
reviews/11/text:
It's a nice narrow but long park which goes by Mondego river.
After a long walk in the town. It is nice to go here, especially to the bars and catch a few drinks. You have a nice view of the river. You should also go to the bridge. You can have an amazing view of the town from there. I loved it.
reviews/12/text: Nice park, nearby the river for jogging, cycling or simply walk arounf. There's a lack of bars/pubs in this area because of the floods in the Winter, but it's a must go on the Easter/Summer time (from March to September)
reviews/13/text: Excellent place by the river Mondego side. Vast green area with great view. Good choice to spend a sunny day.
reviews/14/text:
The watter is clean, animals like ducks nearby.
Boats to play, coffe, trees, you can play with your family without problems, anda Park near the river.
reviews/15/text: The park is near the center. You can walk both sides of the river. There is a walking bridge across the river. There is a little beach, you can rent boats, there is place for a picnic, there is som shadow, etc.
reviews/15/title: nice park to rest from your visit
reviews/16/text:
Lots of space to relax on a hot day. We came on an overcast day. Lots of benches and places to sit and enjoy a snack or drink.

No cafes or stores here so bring your own stuff.

I would definitely come back.
reviews/16/title: Quiet park steps over the bridge from old town Coimbra, Portugal
reviews/17/text: with various cafes/bars and places to buy ice cream this is where you want to go. It isn't the most special place of the city, it is modern and in sunny days you will find many activities specially for children. While you walkd through it you may see some curious small atractions. It is very green just next to the river of the Mondego.
reviews/17/title: If you want to chill out, go there
reviews/18/text: As nice as the University area was, my favourite part of Coimbra was this park by the river. You get views of the old town, wildlife, fresh air and an absolutely brilliant pedestrian bridge!
reviews/19/text: Peaceful and quiet experience. A must in Coimbra city, an University City, very much attended by students in fair weather.

reviews/0/text: You must allow time to peruse the hilltop university, it is old and beautiful. There is a cafe up there... unimposing,
reviews/1/text: You need to be let out of a taxi opposite the Science Museum in order to get tickets and book the Library "Tour". Then it is a ten minute walk to reach the Old University, made up mostly of the Library (see elsewhere), the fine St Michael's Chapel with its extraordinary organ placed high on the wall, and the so-called Royal Palace, where the very unusual and beautiful Great Hall of Acts is the main interest. During the visit (many steps up and down), there is a fine view over the Old Cathedral and the town beyond.
reviews/2/text: The place is beautiful and full of history, however the logistics and the service are terrible. It seems like the tourist are bothering them. The bathroom were filthy. It is a shame.
reviews/3/text:
Coimbra remains Portugal's main University town and one of Europe's oldest.
So, visiting its University is one of the best things to do for visitors.
However, have in mind the complex is huge, occupying several blocks on a hill. 
The most interesting part is the central part with the Joanina Library, Sao Miguel chapel,...etc around the University square. Other parts you'll see when walking the area towards the square, but they're not of tourist interest and look underwhelming, like Sovietish massive ugly block buildings - that's Salazar legacy.
As many others said buying tickets is very illogical - I'd go step further saying it's idiotic not to find the ticket booth by the main attraction everyone's heading to, but 10 min walk away from it.
reviews/4/text: Come see the portion of the campus that is made up of old buildings, some of which are impressive and decorative.  But much of the campus dates from the mid-20th Century and is full of huge boring architecture in poor condition.  Too bad Salazar left his mark.
reviews/5/text: We started at the bottom part of the city and the walk up, itself, is quite something. The top, the unirversity has some memorable buildins topped with panoramic view of the city and beyond.
reviews/6/text:
The university is stunning and you feel the history. Fantastic views of the city but the experience is spoiled by the horrible ticket process. Of course it is best to buy on line & if you don’t then get ready! 

As you enter the university courtyard then you discover you have to walk another 10 mins outside the university complex to buy a ticket. It is not easy to find. The people selling the tickets are painfully slow explaining every detail of the tours available. 

Portugal works at Portugal pace. Slow. Very  slow!
reviews/7/text: This is a strategic point to understand Coimbra’s geographical reality. Looking inland one gets the notion that the territory is marked by mountains; looking the coastal side one sees that the plains are predominant in the landscape. The river Mondego is the element bringing those two realities together and also, along the centuries, the fluvial road for the products exchange of those two different regions. All around the square the old interesting university buildings façades. Enjoy!
reviews/7/title: Amazing panoramic view and beautiful square
reviews/8/text: As the other parts of this wonderful and beautiful university, the buildings are very impressive and it is really highly recommended to spend time visiting and enjoying the location.
reviews/9/text: That's an amazing place full of history. The library it's a must-see one of the oldest Universities in the world. The buildings are wonderful and there's a lot to visit and to see.
reviews/10/text:
Was made to see the Old University - the ticket of 12 euro includes the St Michael Chapel, the Royal Palace and the Joanin Library and a museum a bit further. All the rest of 3 attractions are in the same place, just you enter trough the Iron gate and have them all. You can visit when ever you want, except the library for which is a specific time slow you have written on your ticket. All 3 visits takes arround 1 1/2 - 2 hours. 
Place is beautiful and worth visiting. In the palace there are still hold classes of the Law Faculty. 
You can take a snack in the cafeteria, but be aware, you can pay by card only if it is issued in Portugal, otherwise they accept only cash.
reviews/11/text: No doubt the inhabitants of Coimbra and - on a larger scale the people of Portugal - are very proud of their university, as far as I am concerned it is architecturally boring.
reviews/12/text: It is the most classic and beautiful part of the University and does not require a ticket. And it also has a view to the town.
reviews/13/text:
Not to be missed. Bring water with you and sunglasses (and camera of course!)
Dont try to bring a motor vehicle unless you wish to have a stressful day.
reviews/14/text: Situated near the top of the campus with outdoor patio city view and upscale fine dining at a very low price.
reviews/15/text: How on earth are run-down shop fronts included? The Alta area including the University is rightly included but inclusion of Rua da Sofia devalues the listing.
reviews/15/title: Rua da Sofia part of UNESCO World Heritage area
reviews/16/text: It is Very Much Worth Wondering Around at the University of Coimbra at Paco das Escolas, Coimbra 3000-240, Portugal. This area includes the plaza itself, the former royal palace, a statue of King John the 5th in the middle of the plaza, the Chapel of St Michael, the Science Museum, other statuary near the ticket office, and the Biblioteca Joanina including its first floor dungeon.
reviews/17/text:
The oldest part of this famous university is in a former Royal Palace. We visited three buildings of it: the Biblioteca Joanina, the Sao Miguel chapel and main building.

In the library both the ancient books and bookshelves were very impressive. Some of the books were open, so the quality of the print could be seen. But there was a spoiler: too many of us were in there, despite the fact that we booked our visit to a predefined time slot. Many of the tourist were just pushing and tossing others...

The Saint Michael chapel, although interesting, was less impressive than most of the magnificent churches we visited in Portugal.

But the main building was indeed worth a visit: the massive stairs leading to the entrance, the Armory, the Great Hall of Acts, they were all fantastic. Our way led us to another building in the corner and behind the tower - it had a nice patio and there were the classrooms.

Outside, in the vast courtyard, we saw a class of joyful, freshly graduated students who were celebrating that milestone in their lives!
reviews/17/title: A university with a great history
reviews/18/text: This place is very, very nice! First university in Portugal, with beautiful laboratories kept like years ago. Be there early  in the morning if you want to see all things around.
reviews/19/text: We planned our trip with a stop in Coimbra to see the university. We were glad we did.....We did do the tour - self guided through the palace and the chapel and the timestamped ticket for the library. We enjoyed it all, the views, the history, and the wonderful library. We were in the library with a separate tour group from a cruise ship and were able to listen in to their guide in the baroque library which was cool.
subcategory_ranking: #7 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Calcada de Santa Isabel Alto de Sta. Clara, Coimbra 3040-270 Portugal
description: From here you have an amazing view over the city of Coimbra. In this church the incorrupt body of Saint Isabel, Queen of Portugal, patron of Coimbra and wife of D. Dinis, the founder of the Portuguese University, rests in a silver tomb. Its cloister is the largest cloister of Portugal with an arcade and gallery. A beautiful statue of Saint Isabel, that is carried in procession during the great festivities, stands at the top of the church. The baroque gilded woodwork, the paintings, the magnificent gothic stone tomb of the Holy Queen and the row of 76 chairs, among other art works are certainly worth a visit. Since we are a private institution and have no help from the government or municipality, the entrance fees cover basic maintenance and pay for the young employees who keep the doors and gates of the churchyard 7 days a week open to visitors. We appeal to your understanding and support, but also to your contribution to the badly needed rehabilitation and conservation interventions.
name: Monastery of Santa Clara-a-Nova

reviews/0/text: This was a wonderful site.  The clerk shared valuable information that added to our experience.  He was a delightful young man.  They are lucky to have him.
reviews/1/text: After an incredible climb, and an expensive fee to have a guiede tour, the guide did not explain anything to us, and rather left us alone in a room without signs or explanations. She never came back, and after we went to look for her, she and her coworker very unfriendly informed us that was the end of the tour!
reviews/1/title: Huge disappointment. Would NOT recommend it. Guide was silent!
reviews/2/text: I went here first thing in the morning and had the cloister part all to myself. It was SO WONDERFUL and peaceful! It was silent and I just sat there in this historic place and enjoyed the peace. It is easy to see why religious people would have found peace and religion in that place. One of my favorite spots in Coimbra!
reviews/3/text:
It was interesting to learn that here was a replacement for the old monastery that had been poorly placed and subject to major floods from the river.

Imposingly on high, it makes for an impressive approach and entrance through the grand gateway. From the grounds we had panoramic views across the river to the university and old town.

Baroque is the predominant style of the fine church. With a grand nave the view is taken to the exquisite altar, highly ornamented in gilt.

The cloisters are delightful. Decorative arches and columns surround a two storey tranquil space with lovely greenery. A soaring sculpture with a holy figure atop embellished with halo is impressive.
reviews/4/text: We climbed up here on foot from the old Monastery and so glad we did as it was exhilarating and an opportunity to take photos on every turn if the road.  The church and the cloisters came as a package of €2 and seemed like a great deal.  Evidence of the amount of restoration work required is visible everywhere.  We started off taking photos of the best view if Coimbra around near the statue Queen Isobel outside.  The church is high ceilinged and the body of Queen Isobel is in a silver casket behind the altar.  Next up are the cloisters which are stunning especially the gardens even at this time of year.  So glad we made the effort to get up here away from the crowds down below.  We were totally alone most of the time.
reviews/5/text:
The building doesn't look much from the outside, but is absolutely stunning once you step inside.  We don't usually like to pay to look around but as this was only  €3  we paid up.  And so glad we did.  Every room is beautiful and the cloisters so nice and peaceful. 
The young lady at the entrance was extremely pleasant and knowledgeable.
reviews/6/text:
Monasterio de Santa Clara
Coimbra, Portugal 

2 Saints...2 Monasteries! 

Santa Clara and Santa Isabel meet here, in history, on this great Monasteries, let's find out how was and why was this encounter:
Coimbra, located in the very heart of Portugal wasn't included in the original schedule of our long-time planned and long gastrotour of (almost) all Spain and north of Portugal. Originally I set our route, from Porto to Seville, via Salamanca, but everything changed when I founded ”Atrio Restaurant & Hotel”, another interesting high-end gastronomic destination, unknown to me, in Caceres. When I was revising, for ”enesima vez”, my homework notes for our route, I found that this ”Atrio” with its alluring 2 Michelin Stars, its great comments on TA and other sources, was a place that can't be overlooked in our agenda...I rerouted, via a mandatory stop in Caceres, our way to Sevilla. 
Then I founded Coimbra, an interesting place that once was Portugal’s capital city, right in our way, from Porto to Caceres...before heading to Sevilla and to Madrid, final destination of our cherished Gastrotour 2018  
So...after visiting all Porto attractions and enjoying its gastronomic adventures, from its fantastic restaurants, we were off to Caceres’s ”Atrio”. As it was a long way, we planned our mid-way stop in Coimbra, but we had a late start on Porto after our great last dinner there...regrettable that circumstance shortened our time to be dedicated to beautiful Coimbra, but that would be a nice excuse to be back soon to better enjoy it  
Within our short time I decided to visit just one of its attractions and we selected the ”Santa Clara Convent” or ”Mosteiro de Santa Clara-a-Nova” in keeping its proper original name in Portuguese. 
The main reason to our selection was its easy access, in and out, in our way to Caceres, but besides it has an interesting and close historic relation connected with the important figure of Santa Isabel of Portugal...that adds 2 Saints there. 

When ”Santa Clara a Velha Monastery” was first built it had difficulties because of its closeness to the Mondego River and the frequent floodings from it. A conditions that worsened throughout the times. Because of those continual floods, King John IV order the construction of a new monastery called ”Santa Clara a Nova”. Most recent, the recovery works, carried out in the building, led to the discovery of many archaeological interesting traces. Because of this finding, this national monument, now has revitalized the space and its History.
Regarding the Creation of Santa Clara Convent itself, the first building of the monastery was founded in 1286, but the Santa Cruz monks opposed to the existence of a new feminine monastic house and it was closed a few years later. However, by early 1300, Isabel of Aragon (burned in Zaragoza Spain) reopened the monastic house and the nuns returned to Coimbra.
Isabel was a Dowager Queen; a widow of a previous ruling King. After king’s D Dinis death, Isabel retired to the monastery, now better known as the ”Monastery of Santa Clara-a-Velha”, which she had founded -in 1314- in Coimbra. Then she joined the Third Order of St. Francis, devoting the rest of her life to the poor and sick. Even during the great famine in 1293, she donated flour from her cellars to the starving people in Coimbra. She was also known for being modest and humble in dressing and conversation, for providing lodging for pilgrims, distributing small gifts and educating the children of poor nobles. All in all Isabel was a great benefactor of the needs in Coimbra. For those qualities, her charitable nature, and her devotion -to her faith- she was canonized -as Saint- in 1626...that close and important is her story and her figure  to that Monastery and the city. 
It had a Consecrated Church, a hospital welcoming poor people, a Manor House, where Queen Isabel resided, like a dowager, and its own cemetery. 
After parking our car on its large parking areas, when we first entered the immediate Square, fronting that complex, the Santa Isabel statue, erected in the left side of that entrance...caught our immediate attention. It's a simple work -as herself- but gracefully dressed all in white, overlooking the river at his beloved city, like protecting and blessing it...as you can see in our pics 
We couldn't access the complex areas itself, as they were closed that day, but we got important info from one of its friendly staff members entering to it. 
We learned that the well-preserved Gothic ruins of the old monastery (a Velha) were nearby, down the road access to this ”newer” (Nova) one. 
The complex seems -to my old architect eyes- as interesting, as the histories involving it. An example of these details was founded by us at its different entrance door...including the one to parking areas (see pics) 
Anyway, Coimbra merits another longer visit, which would be an excuse to return soon to explore its many enchantments. 
Because of Its historical and architectural importance -this Complex- was declared a Portugal National Monument in 1910. 
I need to note -and clarify to avoid confusions- that this complex visited by us was the ”Monastery of Santa Clara-a-Nova” (Mosteiro de Santa Clara-a-Nova...in Portuguese) that was built to replace the mediaeval Monastery of ”Santa Clara-a-Velha”, located nearby, which at those time -as mentioned- was prone to frequent flooding by the waters of the Mondego river. 
”...A Nova” in Portuguese means a New Place or New one 
”...A Velha” in Portuguese means an Old One or the Old one
reviews/7/text: A must visit monastery. Friendly staff, great monument, a lot of history and a great view of the city!
reviews/8/text: Beautiful monastery in an historic location. It only costs a Euro to visit and it’s worth it to see the ornate work everywhere.
reviews/9/text:
Interior of the church is based around the cult of Saint Isabela very bling.
Be sure to visit the large, tranquil cloisters - cool and very peaceful, absolutely no traffic noise fro m the city below
reviews/9/title: Worth the hike up the hill
reviews/10/text: Wonderful monastery without the touristy feel to it. Arrived on the day of the 500th anniversary of the canonization of queen Isabella to sainthood. Place is steeped in history. Hilly area but free parking. Admission required, but feel was very authentic. Kids-comment, courtyard was awesome...it was okay
reviews/10/title: Best bet off the beaten path
reviews/11/text:
The Monastery is located on the hill on the left river’s bank and it's well worth the uphill walk.
you should enter the church to admire Saint Isabel’s silver tomb. The the church has magnificent golden altars all around.
It's a most beautiful space to sit down, meditate and relax.
Don't forget to visit the choir, with the beautiful and original stone tomb, and, next to the church, the huge cloister, the biggest in Portugal, as I read somewhere.
It was a pleasure as I heard mavelous gregorian music in the background. All was quiet and peaceful! I had the whole place for myself. I felt very sorry not having taken the tour...
I will certainly come back here
Outside, in front of the monastery, enjoy the wonderful panoramic view over the city of Coimbra
reviews/12/text:
An absolute masterpiece in Coimbra; it is one of the many sights in Coimbra worth leaving the heart of the city to see. From the outside this doesn't look like very much, apart from the amazing views of Coimbra, but from the inside it is stunning. Its beauty, historical significance and marvelous art and workmanship are just breathtaking.
As I have been told, it is the largest visitable cloister in Portugal. Due to the brutal wildfires their suppliers lost all plants; therefore, they had no flowers in the garden.
The craftsmanship of the upper choir must be magnificent. We had no chance to visit it, because it will not be regularly visitable before April 2018.
Take your time to visit the monastery and enjoy the beautiful and peaceful gregorian music as it seems there are still nuns in the monastery.
One does not need to be a Christian to visit this monastery, but only someone that appreciates a masterpiece of 17th century art.
But if you are a Christian, you may also pay veneration to Queen Saint Isabel, since her both beautiful tombs are here.
reviews/12/title: Well worth a trip. An amazing unmissable treasure
reviews/13/text: Good experience of time travel. the museum is great, with nice interactive resources. Very well preserved. At the end, one can eat delicious conventual pastry.
reviews/14/text: This was a major surprise as we were wandering the river and came across the Old Santa Clara convent and on a whim decided to go in for a look. The video/film shown was very informative and set the scene for an amazing story of strong women versus the clergy, a saint and an amazing but tragic love story. That set us of  to the Santa Clara a Nova to see the coffin of Santa Isabella. The church itself is very interesting as is the silver coffin but do the cloisters as well which is the highlight. The original tomb from the old convent is there behind locked doors as well as documents and artefacts. The cloisters are serene and beautiful. The story concludes with the tragic killing of Ines de Castro at the Park behind the old convent. It is possible to piece together the whole saga by visiting the three sites. As we didn't know anything about this saga before we started it became the highlight of our visit to Coimbra.
reviews/15/text: The church is located on the hill on the other river’s bank. It’s worth a detour for the panoramic view (for free); you should also enter the church (two euros per person) to admire the Saint Isabel’s silver tomb. Enjoy!
reviews/16/text:
Spend some time and see the patron saint of Portugal. Her remains are in the silver encasement in the church here.

The surrounding grounds are beautiful. Lots of space to sit down and relax.

Go to the cloister to walk around the courtyard. It's beautiful on a sunny day.

This was also the first place I found a seashell for pilgrims to purchase.

I would definitely come back here.
reviews/16/title: The new monastery with the remains of Saint Isabela in Coimbra, Portugal
reviews/17/text: Check Portugal History on this: it was built as an option to teh Old Maonastery Santa Clara a Velha, enar Quinta das Lagrimas and Portugal dos pequenitos. The old Monastery was constantly flooded by Mondego River, so this one was built. Directly connecetd with the Portuguese Queen Isabel de Aragão (Saint Isabel of Portugal) spouse of our King. D. Dinis.  Lent to  the Portuguese Army from 1910 thru 2016 as Military Nursing and Medic School.
reviews/18/text: Outside and the entrance not good to see,but when enter the chapel,it's painting on the wall and  the main altar with the tomb of Saint Elizabeth of Portugal is amazing...
reviews/19/text:
While in Coimbra we thought we would visit this monastery so we walked up from our hotel. From the outside it looked quite nice so we proceeded in to the ticket office/shop.
We paid 6.80 euros and then were asked to pay an additional 10 euros for a guide. We were told to enter the main church where the guide would meet us shortly.  The church was nice but I have seen much better. The guide arrived to show us around but this is the rip off. She took us into an impressive next room and into a micro museum room then out into a courtyard. This lasted less than 5 minutes with the guide not speaking. then she said 'when you have finished in the yard the exit is in the corner.  This was totally unexpected and we felt we had been robbed.  If you have to go here do not take a guide.

reviews/0/text: Porta and Torre de Almedina is the main access to the historic city of Coimbra. The tower, one of the most imposing of the walls, ensured the defense of this narrow access. This gate is sometimes confused with the Porta da Barbacã, which is instead part of a second wall built to improve the defendability of the city.
reviews/0/title: Defense tower of the main entrance to the historic city
reviews/1/text: This was at the end of our walk. Wonderful to walk under, take pictures pretend you were around 1000 years ago.
reviews/2/text:
Torre de Almedina is the only left town gate out of three from the medieval era.
You're sure to pass it when going to/from the University square. It's an arched gate set between houses on an extremely steep street - just a pass by attraction.
reviews/3/text: At this arch and tower you will enter the old town and be in the most charming area of Coimbra where you will find cafes perched on steep steps, a Fado parlor, and the old cathedral.  Must see.
reviews/3/title: The Entrance to the Old Town
reviews/4/text: Just in the center of the city and near the cathedral. Even when it is a little small, take a look because is very well kept.
reviews/5/text: Arco de Almedina is the only surviving gate of the three that led to the citadel, rebuilt in the XI century by the famous Arab commander Al-Mansur. The tower was first used as a Town Hall, then the Town Hall moved to the monastery of Santa Cruz and the municipal archive was here. Rue de Kebra Costas, which leads through the arch to the old cathedral in translation means unbearable street. It was really not easy to pull the goods from the Marketplace up the hill over the slick, polished cobblestones.
reviews/5/title: Through the gate and up the Unbearable Street.
reviews/6/text: The arch marks the entrance to the old town and is a remnant of the old walls.  There's a steep slope up to it and an even steeper slope beyond it leading ever upwards.  The stone road is very slippery when wet so wear shoes or sandals with a good grip.  We were in Coimbra in the cool of February; I would imagine walking up here in the summer heat would be truly exhausting.  The tower by the arch has a small museum.
reviews/7/text: Nice gateway that separates the different levels of the town. It is in fact amazing how this city is layered.
reviews/8/text: The Torre de Almedina is only of interest in that it represents the opening to the historic centre of Coimbra. This is the starting point for any visit to the old town - in particular the Coooo do Champ -
reviews/8/title: Only interesting as a Gateway to the Old Town.
reviews/9/text: On the way up to the square, just before you go through the arch look left. Beautiful sculpture of female in shape of Portugese guitar. Masterpiece
reviews/10/text: We enjoyed the well-designed exhibit and the views from the tour. Not an afternoon’s worth, but a half hour well spent. Be sure to notice the medieval defensive device of holes in the tower floor used to pour boiling oil down on attackers.
reviews/10/title: Great little museum about the history of Coimbra as a walled city.
reviews/11/text: Loved walking around the old town imagining the comings and goings through the centurys.  This gate was set in the old walls of Coimbra and is in a really quaint area.
reviews/12/text: For a couple of euros entry into the tower museum, there is an interesting video giving details about various locations around the old city walls, a large wall-map with an aerial view of the city as it is now, and access further upstairs to an exhibit covering medieval towns in general, and some glorious views of Coimbra. The guy on reception was extremely helpful.
reviews/13/text: Many times the old city walls were destroyed for the cities enlargement or are imbibed in the buildings. In Coimbra it is also happened but fortunately the Almedina door was kept and still gives us the idea how those entrances were. Enjoy!
reviews/14/text:
This massive and tall tower, part of the fortified wall, marks the boundary between the narrow streets winding up the steep hillside of historical Coimbra and the downtown with beautiful XIX. century houses. Its name - Almedina - evokes the Moorish period of Portuguese history.

In front of the gate there is a sculpture, a poetic tribute to the Portuguese fado guitar - shaped like a woman.
reviews/15/text:
During Islamic rule of Coimbra, the town was fortified and walled. The Almedina Gate (also called City Gate or Arch Gate) was the main gate within the city walls and was at the lowest part of the city. It was the busiest and most important point of access for both the military and the public. Originally, the gate was between two turrets. The turrets were later joined by an arch with a fortified tower above it. 

The arch and tower are still present and have some significant historical value. But viewing the arch itself takes only a couple of minutes, and it isn't particularly impressive.
reviews/16/text:
Part of the old medieval wall. You will see it if you stroll Rua Ferreira Borges anyway, the main road in the lower town.....or go through the gate to access the Se Velha or the University....steep climb after the gate.

We did not bother to visit the museum in the tower.
reviews/16/title: Not really a Note Worthy Site
reviews/17/text: There's some history here. A wall. A gate. An uphill climb. I get it. It wasn't that hard. Why is everybody pushing it like it's the Taj Mahal?
reviews/18/text: This is an entry point through the old wall. It is steep and takes a sharp right angle to impede invaders. If you look up you can see where they used to pour the boiling oil.
reviews/19/text: Part of the ancient perimeter and one of the primary gates still exposed for travelers to see. Small alley with lots of shops leads up the hill to a 17th century church and the university. Great hike.
subcategory_ranking: #16 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: R. Dr. Guilherme Moreira 10, Coimbra 3000-210 Portugal
name: Capela de Sao Miguel
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Joanina Library & University of Coimbra VIP ACCESS!
ranking: #5 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #5 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: The visit of the Capela de São Miguel is included in the cost of the ticket for the visit of the University of Coimbra. At the entrance to the chapel the ticket is checked and access is limited to a few visitors at a time. Inside you can take pictures. The beautiful decorations and the baroque organ make the short visit very interesting.
reviews/1/text:
This magnificent chapel is on the campus of the Universidade de Coimbra on the courtyard between the Biblioteca Joanina and the clock & bell tower. Glorious tiled interior, baroque organ and Rococo side altars in gold & blue.

You can buy tickets for both the chapel and the Biblioteca Joanin.
reviews/2/text:
Two most beautiful attractions included in your Coimbra University ticket are this Chapel and Joanina Library. They stand one by another on the University square.
The Chapel dates back to 16 c and is beautiful decorated with Azulejos, painted ceiling, Portuguese "stairway to heaven" stepped altar and gorgeous organ - gift of King Joao V.
reviews/2/title: Beautiful Chapel by the stunning Library
reviews/3/text:
Just peeked in for a short visit and photos as they were closing when we arrived. 
This chapel was just next to the library on the University campus. 
Ornately decorated with lots of gold the ceiling and pipes were lovely.
reviews/4/text:
This chapel is next door to the more famous Bibloteca Joanina (Joanina Library) but do not neglect to go in.  This chapel is beautiful in its own right; loved the ceiling.
The current chapel was planned by Marco Pires between 1517 and 1522. The tile floor dates to 1613. The painting on the ceiling, by Francisco F. de Araújo, was completed in the late 1600s.  In 1684 Manuel Ramos built the pulpit. In 1733 the chapel received its organ. The organ, a gift of King John V of Portugal, is equipped with nearly 2,000 pipes.
reviews/5/text: This is a must see at the University, one of the few very old buildings on campus, a real treat for the eyes.  Is not open all the time.
reviews/6/text: This magnificent chapel  and the beautifully ornate library in the same building are a must when visiting Coimbra. In fact, this was the only reason we stopped in this city, and a very good reason it turned out to be!
reviews/7/text: Not as small as some folks think it is, but one thing is for certain, it's too small for the size of the organ on the wall, which looks totally out of place. Otherwise, wow, it's really pretty. Light, colorful and almost playful. I love that ceiling. The tilework is, as usual, high quality and lots of fun to decipher. You think based on the size that you can be finished in 5-10 minutes and some people do.  You cannot do it justice that way. There is too much to see and it's impossible to appreciate with a quick run-through, let alone take pictures. Speaking of pictures, once again, if you look at pictures on the internet, it does not give you a good idea of how inventive and interesting the design is and how really great it is. Even without the other sites on the University of Coimbra's campus, it would be worth visiting here. Go.
reviews/8/text: Sided by the "Biblioteca Joanina" and by the "Torre da Cabra", in the "Paço das Escolas" of the "Universidade de Coimbra", stands the absolutely beautiful "Capela de São Miguel". The actual chapel, dating from the 16th century, replaces a collapsed chapel from the 12th century. Its construction was commissioned by King Dom Manuel I and characteristics of the Manueline, Mannerist and Baroque styles are present at its portal, windows, central nave, ceilings and arches. Check its main altar, paintings, gilded sculptureworks, tiles, carpets and the famous ancient organ! If you miss it, you will regret forever! Enjoy!
reviews/8/title: The awesome chapel of the Universidade de Coimbra!
reviews/9/text: In the ticket to the visit to University for 7 euro you get the Chapel and the Palace from the Old University. Both attractions wotrh the money. The chapel is very nice, and you have all the time you need to spend there.
reviews/10/text: Part of the University tour. This small Chapel is representative for several styles of Portuguese architecture and dates from time of Reconquista. It is beautiful.
reviews/11/text: This is a beautiful chapel on the University of Coimbra campus. You can enter as part of the ticket you purchase to the library on campus.
reviews/12/text: It is included in the 12.5 Euro university visit. But I think few will really visit it if it is not included in the tickets. Just a normal chapel
reviews/13/text: A beautiful church inside the University. You can imagine history taking place in this small chapel where students and professors would go to ask for help for their exams.Worth seeing
reviews/14/text: This is a beautiful baroque chapel, decorated with azulejos tiles, an impressive ceiling and a golden organ. In the past it served as a shrine to the royal palace at the site. The church is still  being renovated, but you can visit and photograph it.
reviews/15/text: Well worth a visit. Able to photograph. inside. Visitors are restricted in the numbers permitted inside at a time, but the late afternoon was perfect.
reviews/16/text:
Regrettably the ornate organ was under repair and sheathed in netting so we only got a glimpse of its beauty. Nevertheless the exquisiteness all around more than compensated.

The high altar is awe-inspiring with its rich imagery and gilt. Gorgeous azulejos decorate the walls.   A ceiling that is lavishly embellished with light hues of patterns is breathtaking.

Impressive statuary is plentiful, all portraying holy themes in vivid colours.
reviews/17/text: Gorgeous tiled, painted, and decorated chapel, with an exuberant organ and many other nice features. Part of the "University of Coimbra" circuit ticket.
reviews/18/text: Beautiful old world church with gorgeous altar, magnificent walls, and organ and a significant amount of the blue tile work for which Portugal is famous.
reviews/19/text: To see the Chapel of St Michael, buy a ticket at the University ticket office, above the famous library, that includes a visit to: (a) the library, (b) the Chapel, and (c) The Science Museum. It cost 12.5 euros. The Chapel of St Michael at Praca Cortes de Coimbra, Coimbra 3040-250, Portugal is outrageously Ornate Baroque Church from the late 1600s. Sitting is forbidden. Photos with flash: forbidden. Tiled walls, carved wood guilt do-das galore, interesting statues of St. Catherine, Mary w baby Jesus etc.
reviews/19/title: Outrageously Ornate Baroque Church from the late 1600s
subcategory_ranking: #5 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

ranking: #12 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #12 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
This is certainly the most beautiful square in compact town of Coimbra.
It is set at the end of the central pedestrian street. Around the square are notable buildings - the amazing Santa Cruz Church and Monastery, Coimbra town hall and old historic residential buildings.
reviews/1/text: This is a very busy pedestrian plaza with cafes, the entrance to the Santa Cruz church, and the city hall.  Lots of activity all around and the starting point for the long walk dawn the shopping street.
reviews/1/title: In Front of the Church and City Hall
reviews/2/text: The most emblematic and important square of Coimbra. It is of course a "must" if you visit the city of Coimbra.
reviews/3/text: The name of the square comes from the episode that happened on May 8, 1834 in Coimbra, when the liberal troops took the city from the monarchist's control. There are many buildings from the 16th and 17th centuries. There is also the Igreja de Santa Cruz on the square and the town hall . There are also many nice restaurants and shops around the square. The square is located between the two main streets in Coimbra: Rua da Sofia and Visconde da Luz. Both are also full of souvenir shops, other interesting stores, and bakeries and Portuguese restaurants. The second one is for pedestrians only and is a very pleasant place to walk. It leads to Largo da Portagem, another very beautiful place in Coimbra. It's a very nice place to visit.
reviews/4/text: May 8 Square is named after the day in 1834 when liberal troops overthrew the monarchical power. There are two attractions on the square: the Church of Santa Cruz and the cafe of the same name to the right of it. Both are worth visiting. First of all, for the sake of the interior, both of them. There`s also City hall (left), but it is not so interesting.
reviews/5/text: This is a great square to walk around, have a coffee, people watch and just enjoy the beautiful buildings.
reviews/6/text: This square is one of the oldest in Coimbra but - unfortunately - it has nothing special to offer. The sculptures that you think you can see in the photograoh are so seriously eroded as not to be worth a photograph. Disappointing.
reviews/7/text: Beautiful public square with Santa Cruz church and Café Santa Cruz where you can relax and have a drink and eat a cruzadito (traditional cake) surrounded with beauty.
reviews/8/text: Marvellous example of a Portuguese church. Beautiful tiles. The square has a fountain and it worth visiting the cafe next to the church. Peak inside to see if their is tradition entertainment going on.
reviews/8/title: Atmospheric church and plaza in the centre of Coimbra
reviews/9/text: Privileged location, downtown, offers light, cathedral, museums, architectural and artistic restaurants and shopping.
reviews/10/text: The old church Santa Cruz is very pretty inside and the plaza infront of it is nice. If you go to this area be sure to check the resturant on the right of the church. It hasold world feel and a Free Fado Show. You do not want to miss it. There is also a nice walking street in the area. Go in the cafe and eat or have a drink and enjoy a reall nice show which is put on by people connected to the University.
reviews/11/text: What is great about this square is its authentic character: the buildings are old and not yet refurbished so the facades look antique. The Santa Cruz church itself has a manueline beautiful portal, partly crumbling but authentically ancient.
reviews/12/text: This square leads to many places of interest. The Santa Cruz Church is here and beside it the Santa Cruz cafe. From here you can go to the beautiful University of Coimbra, the Botanical Gardens and much more. The Baixa is adjacent to the square, a labyrinth with many shops and truly Portuguese. Of course there are lots of great restaurants nearby. For me this is a great place to start exploring Coimbra.
reviews/13/text: A very nice square where most people turn back and head to the Church of Santiago and the Back breaker walk to the old cathedral.  You can go around the back of the Santa Cruz church to see an unusual multi-domed and yellow gazebo.
reviews/14/text: At the end of a very nice and touristic street, you will find this lovely square where you can see a lots of people gathering and passing by. After seeing the church and a couple of boutiques, we took the road back through the down side on the way of commerce square with the small streets so try to enjoy as much as you can specially if you have a sunny day.
reviews/15/text: A must see, of course! Santa Cruz Church, Monastery and Santa Cruz cafe in the very same building as the Monastery- Schedule yours visit in between the Masses: you need access from inside the church to visit the points of interest.
reviews/16/text: Located at the start of 'The Baixa' or old downtown, the square has 5 streets running off it and a particularly ugly modern fountain in its centre.  Just off the square are lots of narrow streets containing a variety of shops, but especially shoe shops.  The Camara Municipal (city hall) and Santa Cruz Church are on the square.  If you want to sit for a while, relax and watch the goings on, there is the Santa Cruz Café which has an elevated exterior area with tables to drink your coffee and people watch.
reviews/17/text: This is one of the unofficial entrances to Coimbra's Old City. This spacious plaza/square houses the Camara Municipal, Igreja de Santa Cruz and the adjacent Café Santa Cruz as well as several antique buildings. There is a pleasant fountain and several concrete benches which are great to sit at and watch locals and tourists go by. There are several cafes and restaurants close by, some offer take away service, making this a nice spot to relax and enjoy a beverage or a small snack.
reviews/18/text: A square with a good outdoor space. Has several shopping streets and monuments nearby, nomeadamante the "Igreja de Santa Cruz". I recommend
reviews/19/text: A beautiful edifice only leads to a stunning church within. I was particularly impressed by the organ for its colour and grandeur. The tiling on the walls as you enter describes tales of faith and praise. The one thing the tourists are reluctant to observe are moments of quiet contemplation whilst sitting in the pews, you must try this.

reviews/0/text: We thoroughly enjoyed our stay in this lovely historic building. The rooms were comfortable and spacious and the service was first class. In addition we enjoyed wandering around the park and dinner at the bar. Thoroughly recommended.
reviews/0/title: Lovley hotel in a large park across the river
reviews/1/text: We had  a lovely stay in a this beautiful hotel , which has an interesting history.  The staff were all very friendly and helpful.  The pool was lovely and breakfast was very good, with an egg/omelette station.   Lovely gardens, would recommend
reviews/2/text: The hotel is a nicely restored  centuries old royal residence. The surrounding grounds are lovely. The service is great. The restaurant in house serves good food but like all European fine dining, it just takes forever. It is across the river from the old town. On a sunny good weather day we have a nice walk from the Coimbra University back to the hotel. It is a 2 to 3 kilometers walk but all downhill. I will suggest to take a uber going the other way. Uber is unbelievably cheap. My only critique is the room size. I t could  do with another 50 square feet. .Then it will be perfect.
reviews/3/text: That was a great experience..The hotel is an old palace, very well renovated and preserved, with a lot of corridors, rooms with art objects ( most of them old) and great gardens around the well-known lake, with  the  history of 1580 ( You can ask for the relative  book at the reception).We enjoyed our dinner at the gourmet restaurant of the hotel, very special dishes and selection of wines.
reviews/4/text: The place, surrounded by a golf camp, is quite nice and the building itself is quite elegant. However, it is not a must as other parts of the city and it is a bit far from the center. If you decide to walk around by the river and cross some bridges it is perfectly ok to come here
reviews/4/title: Unless you really want to go, it is not a must
reviews/5/text:
The hotel is charming. The gardens are beautiful, even though it’s not in its fullest grace. We staid in this hotel for a total of 4 nights. Our first stay was great, so we returned one week after, for my birthday, for another 2 nights. Unfortunately the second time was a bit disappointing. It’s not that something actually went wrong, probably we are just “spoiled” and they didn’t meet the standards we are used to. Even though we mentioned it was a special day we got no small “gift” or even birthday wishes. My husband asked if they could arrange some small cake so that my son ( 2 years old) could sing happy birthday after dinner, which they said they couldn’t, but we could order any dessert from the Menu, which we did. Still, no candle, birthday wishes or anything at all. No complimentary drink, small attention, nothing whatsoever... We are regular travelers and this the first time a hotel ( 5 stars) fails to acknowledge any of our birthdays, or other special dates. 
Still, the hotel staff is courteous and professional, the kitchen is great and the overall experience can be rated between excellent to very good. Unfortunately our specific expectations were not met.
reviews/5/title: Lovely place for a small break
reviews/6/text: We stayed 2 night in this pretty old fashioned hotel. Carpet in room was dirty and hotel urgently needs renovation. Staff was helpful but old style.
reviews/7/text:
This Hotel is very very nice!
Located across the River, 10-12 mins walk from Old Town
Has excellent service from all employees.
Food was very good
Welcome drink every day, pm
The Restaurant tasting menu was exquisite and must visit!
Need to reserve in advance, although they accommodate guests as a priority, it is a highly visited restaurant among locals.
Need to know the history beyond this hotel so read and get to know a bit and then visit their Lovely gardens and Fountain and figure why it is called Das Lagrimas!!
reviews/8/text:
My friend and I stayed here for two nights in October.  We received a five star quality welcome - the car was parked, the luggage taken in and an excellent check in service that included information about the hotel and the town.

We stayed in the older section of the hotel in Palace Room 2.  The room was spacious and nicely furnished and the beds were made up with quality linen and were very comfortable.  The only negative was the clothes cupboard - it was marked and worn and didn't fit in with the quality of the other furnishings.  The bathroom had a walk in shower which had great water pressure and plenty of hot water.  

We took advantage of the welcome drink we were offered and then dined in the Gastro bar.  The food was lovely and the service was excellent.  

The breakfast buffet offered a good selection and the food was delicious.

The grounds of the hotel are lovely and it is an easy 15-20 minute walk from the hotel into town.
reviews/8/title: Great place to stay in Coimbra
reviews/9/text:
So I read and reread all these reviews before booking as they seemed to either praise or sternly criticise. If you’re confused, maybe I can help.

The first impressions are great - large fancy gate, dramatic driveway and that famous facade. We were ushered to pull over and a doorman did park the car. One half of the grand stair case was blocked off - I assume for repairs? 

If you like antique then this is the place for you. The area we were told to visit while awaiting check in is meant to be a lounge but it was more like a museum. There’s historical and then there is museum like. We shrugged this off as we were in the “new section”. On the way to our accommodations we walked past man rooms in the main corridor - I can’t imagine these are great. 

We walked to the end of the corredor, turned and walked some more, and down another corridor... and then another (it’s a strangely long walk) until you reach the Spa section. In reality it’s the conference venue with rooms above. We were then greeted by a huge corridor of more rooms. Our room has a balcony overlooking the gardens and the pool. Sounds Luxe but it was a rather dirty balcony with worn furniture. The room itself had kitch writing on the walls, and the bathroom was a marble museum. 

We went to explore the bar area for their free welcome drinks. It’s also suitably old - and as we discovered - it maches the average age of the patrons. We are 36 years old for reference. It appears as though large tour groups come through there, I would guess most patrons are around 55-65. The gardens are also full of elderly couples taking a stroll.

Breakfast was also a little strange - not the greatest selection and always packed. Service was hit and miss. 

It is on a sports ground, and a convention centre. It’s about 15 minutes walk across the bridge to town. We were quite happy to do this but it’s not a fast stroll. 

Would I stay here again? No - it’s just a bit antique and we felt underaged. We didn’t really see a perk / it’s a walk from town, the gardens are interesting but for all of one stroll, and the service was quite average. The new section does not match the old (not even vaguely) and the strange collection of “art” along the corridor is just bizarre. 

Maybe this is your vibe - if so then great, but next time we will be staying elsewhere.
reviews/10/text: what a beautiful hotel stay we had! The staff was absolutely fantastic, friendly, professional and great attention to detail. The grounds are beautiful, too. The room was just fine.
reviews/11/text: Having spent 3 to 4 times more at other luxury hotels, we were very pleased with all the amenities for such an affordable price.  Great gardens, beds and service.  Only thing I couldn´t find was some hot water in which to soak.  All the pools seemed tepid and the only heat I could find was in the Turkish bath or sauna.  Still, a great property with charming history
reviews/12/text:
We had just one night in Coimbra but could not have spent it better !
It’s a bit tricky to get there from the highway but once inside the park and the property itself you feel vindicated.
The staff was forthcoming and friendly 
The room , with surprise upgrade , large enough with a good bed and well appointed bathroom
reviews/13/text: Loved our stay here.  From the selection of dining, to the historical setting of the hotel.  Our room was lovely and big and the views over the stunning gardens add to the whole experience.  Then the added bonus of walking through the incredible gardens and experiencing the "story" of Pedro and Ines, and the fountain of tears, or else just sitting around the lakes and enjoying the peace and beauty surrounding you .
reviews/14/text: We had a family trip to Portugal and decided to stay in Coimbra overnight. Wish we could have stayed longer. The room, the gardens, the service were excellent!
reviews/15/text: Recent stay at this interesting hotel.  Again all staff friendly , helpful and efficient.  Given this Hotel's five star rating, it was disappointing to find that  the "dump" overhead shower did not function. and the bathroom extraction system was very inefficient..  Our room was in the original part of the hotel which meant that you were faced with several up and down flights of  stairs to reach this room on the second floor, and although this added character it meant less able people with luggage or shopping would find it a bit of a struggle!.  The breakfast buffet was OK but not outstanding, but the Hotel grounds, gardens  and location were.
reviews/16/text: With it's "green florest" it takes one to Portugal's old times and see places where the lovers "Pedro and Ines" spended so many of their time, away from the court.
reviews/16/title: A place to enjoy from a weekend to a full holiday.
reviews/17/text:
We arrived from our lovely stay at the Ritz Carlton Penha Longa, a five star property where we enjoyed a beautiful and comfortable executive suite for about the same price per night we were going to be paying here. 

We had booked a suite that promised :

“This renovated suite has wooden or stone floors, a stone-walled bathroom.”

The idea of staying in an old castle was appealing... Hah! The sofa In the tiny sitting area that comprises a “suite” was basically like sitting on a block of cement.Furniture from home goods.

Floors were carpet, not wood or stone. Bathroom was ordinary. Bed was painfully soft and uncomfortable. Staff just keep repeating themselves about how we were upgraded and we were in the castle wing.
I hear the spa wing is even less appealing.
Their beautiful gardens aren’t lovely at all.
The whole place is run down.

Worst stay in our 14 day trip. We booked 5 stars and received 5 star rooms and service in every stop except Coimbra. 
Opt for a business hotel in the area, at least you will be comfortable.
reviews/17/title: Not worth it- at any price! Soft beds,rude staff
reviews/18/text: Outstanding old Palace with a modern wing including additional rooms and an indoor pool and impressive spa. Friendly and helpful staff and beautifully manicured gardens. Golf Driving range and small par 3 course on the property as well. Room 12 was an incredible suite in the old building.
reviews/19/text: Tremendous staff, very supportive with restaurant choices and plans for sights.  This is a fun hotel to visit with a long quite gate entry drive you feel important.   The grounds are superb and the hotel quite. It's a great property and perfect for 3 or 4 days.  You can see porto and other cities from this spot by train and coimbra is a great city.  You'll love it here
reviews/19/title: Perfect spot to stay in coimbra and for day trips north
subcategory_ranking: #18 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Rua Domingos Vandelli 2, Coimbra 3004-547 Portugal
description: Nas visitas guiadas, com a duracao de cerca de 50 minutos, os turistas poderao passar pela Igreja da Sagrada Familia, pela capela de Sao Miguel, pela biblioteca velha, pela sala dos azulejos ou pelos aposentos episcopais. O espaco pode ser visitado de segunda a sabado, das 10:00 as 12:00 e das 14:00 as 18:00.
name: Seminario Maior da Sagrada Familia
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Classic car city tour – Coimbra ride
photo/caption: Seminário Maior da Sagrada Família: uma jóia a descobrir
ranking: #32 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #32 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: Make the effort to visit the Seminario Maior if your time allows in Coimbra. The organ is wonderful, as too are the exhibits in the chemistry laboratory. Sometimes they organise events for small groups.
reviews/1/text: We stumbled upon this Seminario after walking through the nearby botanic garden.  In contrast to the crowded and rushed tours of the University, our tour here was relaxed, informative and quite enjoyable.  The Seminario has only been open to the public for a couple years and has not yet been discovered by the group tours; we were the only visitors when we arrived (around 11 a.m.) and thus were lucky enough to get what amounted to a "private" tour.  Our guide was excellent with a thorough knowledge of the building, its history and contents.   This was well worth the 5 Euros entry fee and was a highlight of our visit to Coimbra.
reviews/1/title: Excellent tour; see it before it is discovered by the tour groups
reviews/2/text: The seminary is slightly of the main route of most of the attractions of Coimbra. It is a beautiful building with a different interior artistical style than many of the other points of interest in Coimbra. The library, old and new chapel are highlights. But at €5 the entrance is a bit high (3 or 4 would be better) and the tour felt a bit rushed for us (35 - 40 min) . Also, if your tour happens to be at the same time as certain classes (in our case a Saturday at 12), you won't be able to visit all the rooms.
reviews/3/text: This is such a beautiful place, with history made over hundreds of years. Its library is priceless, with books from centuries ago. The Chapel, which is the heart of the building, is so rich of significance. You will love to walk in the garden, a calm oasis amidst the city bustle.  It's  definitely a must go place in the city of students, Coimbra, if you ever come to Portugal.
reviews/3/title: Beauty and peace amidst the city bustle
reviews/4/text:
In the seminary you can enjoy of a great view of Coimbra, while you have an interesting guided tour, with everything you can ask for, since the beautiful art that decorates the place, the history that you can feel between the walls and the spirituality of the previously instaled priests school that functioned on this "palace". You have the best guides you could ask for and for sure a smile on your way out!
A great complement to the University!
reviews/4/title: The most beautiful place in Coimbra!
reviews/5/text: Even though it is slightly overpriced (5€) for a forty minutes visit, I still think it is well worth the visit. The church is simply one of Coimbra's most beautiful, and its library, despite not being as grand as the Joanina, is still a beautiful place. A very off the beaten path and forgotten place, worthy of more attention
reviews/6/text: This is a great place to visit while in Coimbra, it is nice to get away from the University which is the main reason people visit the city. The building is full of history and gives great views of the city!. My guide was very knowledgable and made me feel very welcome. This really is worth a visit.
reviews/7/text: A beautiful and uncommon place to visit, close to the Coimbra's university and botanical. Every hour, during the morning, you have guided visits.
reviews/8/text:
Gostei de  toda a visita, muitas curiosidades desvendadas, guia( Diana) 5*.
O nosso grupo, em família, continha adolescentes, que vinham entusiasmados com a aprendizagem.
reviews/9/text: Impressionante. Visita guiada feita pela bibliotecária Diana, que foi extremamente simpática e elucidativa. O Seminário é interessantíssimo com imensa história e com uma biblioteca única.  A não perder!
reviews/10/text:
コインブラ大学の植物園から歩いて１０分くらいのところにある神学校です。２５０年くらい前に建てられたそうですが、なかなか美しい建物です。庭も綺麗で広々としています。

ガイド付きのツアーが出ており内部を見学できます（５ユーロ）。運悪く、出た直後だったので諦めましたが、なかなか良さそうでした。
reviews/10/title: ２５０年くらい前に建てられた神学校
reviews/11/text: Finalmente aberto ao público para visitas guiadas ,em boa hora ,o novo reitor do Seminário resolveu mostrar este EX-LIBRIS Nacional aos portiugueses e a quem nos visita ,saber vum pouco da história religiosa ,desde a construção aos nossos dias.A Capela ,com os tectos magníficos ,assim como a Sala São Tomás ,visita obrigatória.Nessa sala ,estão as fotos dos beneméritos da Instituição ,dos últimos 200 anos.
reviews/12/text: Tivemos uma agradável visita guiada no Seminário de Coimbra. Um prédio muito bonito que vale a pena visitar. Além das salas e da biblioteca tem uma bela igreja. Chamou atenção a temperatura fresca dentro do prédio, graças a altura do teto e espessura das paredes.
reviews/13/text:
Recomendo a visita e podem aproveitar para tirar, também algumas fotos à cidade de Coimbra, vista daquele excelente lugar. Muito Bom.
O Guia, Joel Arlindo, é conhecedor, bom conversador e simpático.
reviews/13/title: Agradável surpresa, 60 anos depois da primeira visita.Gostei da escada em caracol, da escada do gato e da Biblioteca
reviews/14/text: 오래된 역사를 가진 도서관입니다. 정원이 아름다우며 손댈 순 없지만 이곳에 소장된 도서들은 역사적인 가치를 지니고 있습니다.
reviews/15/text: Para todos os interessados não só em religião, mas também em história e em conhecer melhor a cidade de Coimbra, este é um monumento a não perder. Destaque particular para os tectos e a decoração opulentes e para a antiga biblioteca. Uma visita guiada que vale a pena.
reviews/16/text: É Um lugar cheio de historia a escola que formou os sacerdotes em Coimbra por mais de 250 anos: As escadas em caracol, a Capela de São Miguel, uma capela única com as relíquias dos 12 apóstolos, a espetacular Biblioteca Velha  e a Igreja da Sagrada Familia, uma jóia. É uma visita Imperdível em Coimbra.
reviews/17/text: Adorei a visita. Guia muito bem-disposto, disponível e simpático! Boas condições e ambiente agradável. Importante para conhecer a história de Coimbra!
reviews/18/text: Sendo habitante da cidade nunca tinha visitado o espaço mas vale completamente a pena. Desde a oportunidade de ver os refeitórios originais às escadas em caracol, passando por uma biblioteca antiga com mais de 8500 livros e a igreja com um tecto comparável ao da Capela Sistina. Impressionante... Recomendo imenso!
reviews/19/text: Entramos o portão e ficámos logo agrados: um belo e imponente edifício aparecia à nossa frente. É uma visita agradável e relaxante. Tem uma vista sobre a cidade de tirar o fôlego.
