address: Coimbra Portugal
name: Choupal National Forest
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Discovering Nature in Coimbra
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Rent a Bike Full Day from Coimbra
ranking: #29 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #29 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
A nice small forest, of mixed trees, old and young, with decent birdlife. This should be commonplace, instead of the horrible endless young eucalyptus plantations that destroy biodiversity and are a major hazard for the local population (death toll of fires is high in Portugal). 

Not a tourist attraction - just a nice place to walk just outside of the city.
reviews/1/text:
Try during the Week & not WeekEnds !
Avoid the crowds, enjoy the peace !
Relax, Rejuvenate !
Health Body & Mind
reviews/1/title: Take a Forest Walk & Health Body & Mind
reviews/2/text: I can recommend this forest to everyone who come to Coimbra! It's really amazing place, nature place where you can a bit escape from the city to relax and enjoy your time in natural place. Forest is really various with different plants, but I also liked to visit small village after the Choupal. It is located behind small water channel around the forest. Many ways to walk aronud and feel free :)
reviews/3/text:
Located on the north western outskirts if the city, Coupal is a wooded area which is mainly very popular with local joggers, but is also pleasant to go for a walk.
Not really something that I would put on a tourist itinerary.
reviews/4/text: In the past this was a great place ,trees ,greens shadows ....nowadays it's a walk out of city center,for a cool break.
reviews/5/text: A beautifuk forest that has not been preserved or maintained. Could be a great place but needs other type of infrastructure.
reviews/6/text:
You should come to this place only to leave the city relax and make 30min-1h running.
This is also used to make lunch with families, however they must bring their own food :P
reviews/6/title: For running inside a city little forest
reviews/7/text:
If you love to run this is the place, always fresh with those beautifull trees.

also the best place to play some pick-up basketball, the courts are not very good, but usually theres lots of other players there and you can get some interesting games.
reviews/8/text: It is near Coimbra , so if Uluru are a runner this is a perfect route to run. In the middle of the park there is a small cantina I think it opens from 9 to 8pm. There are also some places for picnic and to relax. I was there once a week and never regretted it.
reviews/9/text: Great place for a nature walk 5 minutes from the center of Coimbra. You can ear and see a vast number of bird species, including grey herons, tawny owls, common buzzards and one colony of black kites.
reviews/9/title: Great place for watching black kites
reviews/10/text: We had to wait for a train at Coimbra B station and decided to spend some time cycling in Choupal forest.  It is very close to the station so was quick and easy to get there.  We enjoyed the smooth cycling tracks and had coffee so much better than sitting at the station.  It feels much furhter from the city so a nice relaxing place to visit.
reviews/11/text: A trip to the north part of Portugal is very interesting, driving with a car over narrow roads with many u turns makes it wild.
reviews/12/text: between the rio Montego and a canal, a beautiful place to come to rest and admire nature... there is a cafetaria hidden among the trees where one can drink a coffee, and lovely walks all around
reviews/13/text: Natureza no seu melhor. Zona agradável. Bom para passear com os mais pequenos. Espaço limpo e fácil de chegar. Recomendo
reviews/14/text: apetecia escrever zero, mas em boa verdade não consigo. é vergonhoso ter corrido várias páginas  com a pergunta - «qual a área da mata nacional do Choupal em Coimbra» e não ter um valor correcto. vergonha.
reviews/15/text: Parque algo escondido muy cerca de Coimbra. Muy geande y con arboles espectaculares. Lugar de calma donde pasear o hacer deporte
reviews/16/text: Um ótimo local para caminhadas e exercícios,  próximo à estação Coimbra-B. Não longe do centro histórico.  Seja à  margem do Mondego ou nas trilhas em meio ao bosque, uma ótima opção,  principalmente em dias de calor
reviews/17/text: Abbiamo noleggiato le bici al parco del Rio Montego e pedalando lungo la riva sinistra, di fronte alla città di Coimbra, siamo arrivati al bosco. È stato bellissimo seguire i sentieri, attraversare i ponticelli, immersi in una natura rigogliosa di flora e fauna. Gli scoiattoli saltellavano sugli alberi e il fiume scorre ai lati. Bellissimo, un’area attrezzata, curata e sorvegliata.
reviews/17/title: A spasso con la bici nel bosco
reviews/18/text: Parque da cidade Coimbra a não perder. Ambiente calmo e relaxante adequado para passear com crianças.
reviews/19/text: Grande espaço verde da cidade de Coimbra ,aonde se pode fazer variadas atividades desportivas,ou se preferir só passear e sentir o silêncio da natureza.

name: Penedo da Saudade
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Tour Coimbra - 1 Day from Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Coimbra and Bussaco Private Full Day Sightseeing Tour from Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Coimbra and Bussaco Private Full Day Sightseeing Tour from Lisbon
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Aveiro Private Tour | Coimbra + Moliceiro Tour
ranking: #15 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #15 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: One of the places I liked the most of the city of Coimbra. If a little bit far from the center of the city and you have a great view from this point. Very green and relaxing.
reviews/1/text: When you approach it looks much like a cemetery, but the best translation of Penedo da Saudade would be Rock of Longing.  It is where students leave stone tablets to their course year to commemorate their time spent at the University of Coimbra.  It is possible to park at the top, near the statue of Joao de Deus, and then enter Penedo da Saudade, which is on a hill, and walk along the various pathways, viewing the stone tablets.  You may well encounter some former students there to reminisce their time spent at the university.  There are some very good views to be had over the south of the city.
reviews/2/text: Sunset here is amazing, you will have a great view of the city. It's easy to get there by foot and is a great place to get to know more about the students that used to live in Coimbra.
reviews/3/text: Interesting garden with a great view over the new part of the city. Memories of former students of the Univeristy are engraved on marble in form of poems.
reviews/4/text: It is really different, I have seen this for the first time. It is totally worth visiting. The beauty of this place is it is located in top of the Coimbra. The scenery is beautiful. I would recommend you to visit there and feel the history.
reviews/5/text: Penedo da Saudade is the name of this relatively small garden that has good views over Coimbra. However, the views are not the main feature here, where it has become a tradition for students groups over the years to place plaques describing their enduring love for the University City. Some are over three hundred years old, others very recent. It makes for an interesting feature well worth seeking out
reviews/5/title: An Original Tradition, With Great Views
reviews/6/text: Hard to translate it's name, you will find yourself involved in huge roots and tablets written by old students of the city,shwing their love for her and the will to one day return
reviews/7/text: A little bit outside of town but worth the walk. If you visit the botanical garden this is only another 10 minutes walk. We visited on a cloudy Friday afternoon and there was no one there. Great for photos and to have time to translate some of the stones. You can keep going and going so don't turn around too soon. There is even a toilet on site.
reviews/8/text: A transcendent panoramic of the city, with a glamorous light and poetry of its inscriptions and sculptures.
reviews/9/text:
sadly I went here on a rainy day so didn't had much time.
but the little we have seen was beautiful.
this garden has its name due to the students writing their songs and letters in the garden.
Also the garden provides a beautiful view to the city.
there is a passage which can take you close to the stadium and the shopping centre, good luck on finding it :)
please vote if you like the photos and this review
reviews/10/text:
A lovely small park located at the highest point in Coimbra.
The 100 meter climb is worth it.
Great views.
Full of stone placques celebrating university life.
reviews/10/title: Great view and worth the 100m climb
reviews/11/text: Decided to explore this based on a suggestion from  a local. It was a long walk for me to get there, but once I did, I was really glad I came. Come prepared with a translation app so you can understand what is written on the stones. The view is beautiful and the park is peaceful. It really only takes about half an hour to wander through, but is a lovely way to spend a sunny afternoon.
reviews/11/title: Ahi also way to while away an hour
reviews/12/text: In this place you can appreciate the views to one part of the city. It is a beautiful little garden with lots of history. It's very close to other attractions so you can just take a look when passing by.
reviews/13/text: Definitely the best view of Coimbra! Just right by the university, and filled with the poems from poets, writers and anonymous students!
reviews/14/text:
Penedo da Saudade is a small "park" i would call it like that in the middle of the city.
Many people heard about it, but not many people been there.
It is worth the visit for a moment.
Great view for "Ponte Europa" and the other side of the city and also is a little lung in the city...trees and spaces to sit, good facilities (toilets)...
It is a place very connected to Coimbra Culture.
It has places called classrooms with poems written of old students of the city.
Its like going on time...go with someone who can translate because they are beautiful...
Go there for an hour or two...
reviews/15/text:
Nostalgia Rock in the City of Coimbra.
You can see this as one of the highest points or Hill in the city of Coimbra, and the students from the University of Coimbra used this place to let their feelings have their way.
So this place was used to show the home-sickness of the students after they have finished there degree in the University and had to return back to their families, so allot of students or groups placed there something like a grave stone with their nostalgia carved on, so this place was called the “Penedo da Saudade” – Nostalgia Rock”.
This place is very famous and visited by allot of coaches, with mostly Portuguese retired persons on it.
When you are going to visit this place, take also a walk around, starting in the small park in front, so you can also enjoy the surrounding area from the city, this with view among them you have the Football Stadium / Dolce Vita shopping centre.
Gps: N – 40º 12.303”    W – 8º 24.915”
After your visit you are about 100 meters away from the Memorial of Sister Lucy, our next review.
Also you are a few minutes away from the Botanic garden, and Praça da republica.
reviews/16/text: It's an iconic place of coimbra also.. all the stories that Coimbra tells, penedo da saudade is one of them, all the poems written there and the atmosphere.. good to go for a walk with girlfriend.
reviews/17/text: Walking around this hillside you can feel the nostalgia of the generations of students who've come back to leave messages here.  Sitting on one of the stone slabs at sunset was a perfectly romantic setting at the end of a daytrip to Coimbra, whether you have someone to translate the poems or not.  Beautiful!
reviews/18/text: Is a interesting place over the years the students that passe by Coimbra dedicate poems to the loved one , you can see around dated from years ago poems of love  writen and displayed on stone  betwen the flowers and the garden. The students have the habit of taking the guitars at night and serenade to their lovers.
reviews/18/title: nice garden with a nice view..
reviews/19/text: You must visit this with some Portuguese translator, since there´s plenty of "signs" with interesting messages to read. Also a nice view to the new Stadium.
reviews/19/title: An excellent view to Coimbra´s Stadium

address: Coimbra Portugal
name: Rua Ferreira Borges
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Visit by Coimbra
ranking: #27 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #27 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: One of the important streets in town, a place for a stroll to enjoy the architecture and the sites.  Some places to eat and drink along the way.
reviews/1/text: Major pedestrian street loaded with nice stores and restaurants. The Jewish quarter was located here before the inquisition.
reviews/2/text: In the heart of Coimbra, the area is alive with families, music, shops, and many restaurants. Fun just to stroll and people watch.
reviews/3/text: This street will take you toward the center of town and quite a few of the historic structures, plus some places to eat and drink.  Pleasant.
reviews/4/text:
Rua Ferreira Borges is a classic European pedestrian shopping street.
It spreads between two main squares on its ends - Largo da Portagem and 8 May square.
The street is not that long and pleasant to walk. I usually rate such streets average (3 stars), but this one has some very nice and eye catching architecture along it.
reviews/4/title: Nice shopping street between two square
reviews/5/text: It's the main shopping street where you will find lots of casual places to eat and drink some with outside terrace seating.  Some shops for souvenirs or your needs.  No place to buy groceries or even snacks.
reviews/6/text: This is just in the center of the city and is the most important street. It is a pedestrian street. Obviously a "must".
reviews/7/text: Rua Ferreira Borges is an artery in the city of Coimbra that, despite having had other names over the centuries, still has the same layout since medieval times. It was the first cobbled street in the city. It was the main shopping street for a long time, having the best bookstores, pastry shops, stores, offices and offices. Currently, it is one of the main arteries of Baixa de Coimbra. Connects Largo da Portagem to Rua Visconde da Luz. As its layout has not undergone major changes, it still maintains today several houses from the 17th and 18th centuries. Many old and very beautiful mansions. A walk along Rua Ferreira Borges is a must for a visit to the city.
reviews/7/title: Still an important point in the city
reviews/8/text: thi is the very photogenic main shopping street. start at the base, the main plaza near to to riverside and head eastward from there.  we took some really great photos here,  great for people watching, as well as shopping and lovely restaurants and cafes.
reviews/9/text: This paved road with no traffic allows you to wander up to a number of churchs and shops. Look up to see the main buildings and also visit the side streets.
reviews/10/text: Lovely modern shops all along this old town! It was a lovely stroll and the sardine shops really impressed me! I picked up even a pair of Portuguese earrings in gold..much enjoyed!
reviews/11/text:
Running basically from the stunning church of Santa Cruz and the Town Hall, over the hill and down to the River and the Santa Clara bridge, this shopping street is full of character.

Full of a variety of retailers, including clothing, gift/souvenir shops, cafes and bakeries it’s a nice stroll to take in the sights and people of this pretty city.
reviews/12/text: this is suppsoed to be coimbra's high street but sadly most of the shops are closed and gives it a sad feelling, the city hall should really make this more dynamic and attract different kinds of businesses.
reviews/13/text:
Rua Ferreira Borges is located in old town Coimbra, we didn't have any trouble finding parking.  I was wondering why after 2 on a saturday parking is free, it is vecause they stores close mostly from 2 to 4 or 5 then reopen.
Not something we are used to.
reviews/13/title: Old Coimbra with a modern twist
reviews/14/text: Just as you leave Santa Cruz Church, visiting it is almost a must, you find Rua Visconde da Luz and Rua Ferreria Borges that make up a busy pedestrianised street, full of shops and dotted with some buildings from the "belle epoque" that leads to a square, full of animated terraces, facing the bridge. But there are some points of interest around, beside. Should you take the Almedina Arch instead of walking down all the street up to Largo da Portagem, once you cross the Arch, a series of narrow streets, always uphill, would lead you to the oldest part of the city, where there are two cathedrals. The university is also outstanding, but look for the oldest buildings, not the modern ones which aren´t interesting.  There is plenty more too see in this city, but in case you only have a few hours to spend, I think you can have a general view with these tips.
reviews/15/text:
A landmark for Coimbra, it has a wide range of shops to visit, coffee shops to rest and enjoy some the traditional sweets. 
It is a fantastic place to buy gifts, clothes, things for the house. You will find a little bit of everything.
reviews/16/text: This is one of the quaintest streets in medieval Coimbra and well worth the visit and stroll down beside the shops and restaurants.  Locals and visitors alike will always find something to their liking, whether just window browsing or else admiring the architecture and quaint look to the street
reviews/17/text: Good for walking with kids because there are no cars. A lot of traditional shops with nice prices. Worth a visit for sure.
reviews/18/text: Where the locals of Portugal live when living outside of tourist area.  Very close to the action of old town but yet has the neighborhood feel of the locals.  One of the few areas with parks and trees in the city.  Its the neighborhood alternative to Ave de Liberdade.  Loved it!
reviews/19/text: Once Rua Ferreira Borges was the street in the old Baixa (downtown) where the expensive shops were located.  Now many of them have closed down or moved to the 2 new large shopping centres in the city.  There are some buildings of architectural interest, but little else.  It connects Praça Oito do Maio and Largo da Portagem, both of which are very much worth a visit, but my advice would be to travel from one to the other via the windy old streets lower down in the Baixa.

name: Sao Sebastiao Aqueduct
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Bussaco Palace and the University of Coimbra Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Private Tour to University of Coimbra and an ancient Roman city
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Classic car city tour – Coimbra ride
ranking: #28 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #28 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: Our buses parked near this aqueduct when we visited the university.  This game me an opportunity for photos of this well-preserved historical treasure.
reviews/1/text: You will find this old and picturesque aqueduct at the Pope's traffic circle and near the Botanical Gardens.  It is a bit shocking at first because it is so high.  Leads to the elevated city at the University.
reviews/2/text: My wife and I just happened upon the Aqueduct while walking to the University through the Botanical Gardens. The Aqueduct is in very good condition and worthy of a photo opportunity!
reviews/3/text: The area in general is really nice with a lot of gardens and the university really close. The aqueduct is really long and well preserved.
reviews/4/text: Either a ruin or a restored object. In any case, it fits well into the urban landscape and successfully complements it. Since the town is small, it is impossible to pass by sooner or later. If you do not know about it in advance, it will be a good find
reviews/5/text: Nice to walk under this on the way into the Botanical Gardens, it has a striking position that is well preserved.
reviews/6/text: This is easily seen from various view points around the old town, in particular the view point close to the Roman Temple to the terrace of the Cathedral
reviews/7/text: Nice they're still here after all this time but after Segovia in Spain they're a but underwhelming.  But at least they are still there and haven't been smashed down
reviews/8/text: The Sao Sebastiao Aqueduct at Praca Joao Paulo II, Coimbra 3000-227, Portugal is imposing, makes you think about the Roman past, and is a pleasure to walk under and along.
reviews/9/text:
We saw this site on the way to the Jardim Botanico...but don't go out of your way. Not a key feature in Coimbra.

You can also see it from the plaza Largo Don Dinis without walking down the hill.
reviews/10/text: This impressive structure was right near our apartment and crossing under the arches led to the botanical garden and the university campus. It was a picturesque land mark for finding our way home from restaurants and fado bars of the old town.
reviews/11/text: If you are in the centre of Coimbra it is hard to miss this impressive aqueduct which runs for over a kilometre. However, there is a misconception supported by a number of reviews that it is Roman. In fact it was built during the reign of D. Sebastio, hence the name, and designed by his architect Filipe Terzi during the period from 1570 onwards. Whilst it was built on the site of the old Roman aqueduct, it is not of that period. Nevertheless it is well worth checking out.
reviews/11/title: A City Centre Feature, But Not Roman
reviews/12/text: The aqueduct looms over the street very close to our hotel, and was beautifully lit at night. A fascinating glimpse of the past.
reviews/12/title: Right in the centre - history abounds
reviews/13/text:
Lovely old aqueduct well preserved and sweeps in an impressive arc and well worth seeing.
Not isolated but has roads and traffic carrying on as normal.
reviews/14/text:
an older Roman aqueduct has been completed in the 16th century, and today is in a good shape
one km of arches, leading you to the University
in Portugal it's not a big surprise to find n aqueduct, the Romans managed to build a good infrastructure

take care where you park the car, please look to the attached photo
reviews/14/title: iWas there, an aqueduct in the middle of the city, why not
reviews/15/text: Amazing to see the aqueducts in this area.  They were very well preserved and even look usable today.  Great shots of many long arches
reviews/15/title: did not know these were even here
reviews/16/text: Located at the entrance to the Botanical Garden it is easy to find.  Another fine example of the Romans building things to last.
reviews/17/text: The aqueduct was near our accommodations, so we saw it every day.  It's rather large and next to the botanic garden.  You can't miss it, though there are no touristic places nearby
reviews/17/title: Interesting if you're in the area
reviews/18/text:
Not really a separate site.
But you pass by it as you are walking near the University of Coimbra.
Very well preserved.
reviews/19/text:
It's astounding how old these systems are and how well preserved. Spend some time and you can see the aqueduct in several locations spread across Coimbra, Portugal.

It's definitely worth seeing!
reviews/19/title: Amazing ruins of Roman Aqueduct preserved in Coimbra, Portugal

address: Coimbra Portugal
name: Ponte Pedro e Ines
photo/caption: Ponte Pedro e Inês  |   Coimbra, Portugal
ranking: #13 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #13 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: Surprised to find this beautiful pedestrian bridge when walking back to our hotel from city center.  The railing is made of multi-colored glass panels. It allows the walker to avoid heavy car traffic.
reviews/1/text: This is the pedestrian bridge over the river, a good place to take some photos of the river and the city without being buzzed by traffic.  Safe.
reviews/2/text: This bridge offers pedestrians safe passage over the Mondego River into the heart of the historic district. It is a great place to photograph the river & views of the University buildings on the hill-top during the day and at night.
reviews/2/title: Safe passage across the Mondego River into the heart of the historic district...
reviews/3/text: For me it was just a normal bridge and nothing more. It connects both sides of the park which is worth it.
reviews/4/text: The multi colored glasses are nice. The graffiti are not nice. It is a nice pedestrian bridge that could be more clean.
reviews/5/text: A spectacular multicolored bridge provoked us to cross the Mondego River and walk along the other bank to the Santa Clara Bridge to return to the center of Coimbra. It can be seen that the bridge is relatively new. It was built in 2006 by engineer Antonio Adam da Fonseca (several bridges in Portugal) and cool Sri Lankan-British architect and designer Cecil Balmond (Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza, Casa da Musica, Porto, CCTV building in Beijing). The bridge cost almost 5 million euros and was built with the money of one of the programs of the European Union. The main feature of the bridge is its bend. in the middle part. The idea is not new, Santiago Calatrava likes to exploit it. The bridge is named after King Pedro I the Hard and Ines de Castro, his favorite, who became his posthumous wife. Ines was killed here in Coimbra. It's funny, but a day ago we were standing near their sarcophagi in the monastery of Alcobaca. And now on this colorful bridge. Perhaps their love had the same bright colors.
reviews/5/title: Bridge of the cool British architect in honor of the colorful love of Pedro and Inês.
reviews/6/text: I went to the bridge at sunset to get some photos. Many of the colorful tiles have graffiti on them but it's still beautiful.
reviews/7/text: Coimbra is a lovely town but it is a pitty to see that they (i guess) lack of money to maintain buildings, parcs and bridges. Specially this bridge that has been suffered a lot from vandalism.
reviews/7/title: Nice and convenient bridge but bad maintained.
reviews/8/text: This is a great bridge to both look at and cross. The multi coloured glass sides add an interesting dimension to it.
reviews/9/text: This is a much better way to cross the river than the automobile bridge down river. Great views of the University.
reviews/10/text: A 15 minute walk down the river from down town/lower town gives you a great view of the city built on a hill. You can really see the very steep steps, the botanical garden and in our case a superb sunset and thunderstorm in the distance. We did not cross the bridge, walked half way across and spent 30 minutes enjoying the breeze and views
reviews/10/title: Great spot to view Coimbra from
reviews/11/text: Ponte Pedro e Ines is a modern pedestrian bridge that provides a fabulous view of the old city. If you enjoy walking it's definitely a good activity while in Coimbra
reviews/11/title: Cross the bridge to enjoy a fabulous view of the old city
reviews/12/text: We walked across this bridge while we were visiting Coimbra. The stroll was pleasant and there were very nice views of the river and the city. Midway is a great place to get good photos of the city. The park nearby is also pleasant and shaded, making it a nice thing to do on a hot afternoon. If you are in the area, check it out.
reviews/12/title: Easy walk to cross the river - good views
reviews/13/text: The coloured glass panels on the bridge are aging and fading but is is a pleasant and quiet crossing as it is only for pedestrians. We did see a couple of cyclists but they were respectfully slow. Nice views from on the bridge - and it reaches both sides!
reviews/14/text: It can be a long walk. But you will enjoy the views. Especially during the sunset. It can be gorgeous. This is my favourite place in Coimbra.
reviews/15/text: As soon as I saw the bridge on my way to Conimbriga, I told the taxi driver that going back i would like to stop at the bridge.  The bridge reminded me of Millenium bridge in London but an artsy version.  The design was based on the affair of of Crown Prince Pedro and Lady in Waiting Ines. Ines was murdered by the order of King Alfonso.
reviews/16/text: Not a 'destination' as such but a way to get a unique perspective on the city. If you walk then you've nothing to lose; if you're short of time you could miss it.
reviews/17/text: I wasn't very taken with the coloured glass panels oj the side of this bridge, and thought that something more fitting could have been designed to commemorate Pedro and Ines.
reviews/18/text: I would start off at the tourist information centre and across the street, you can run past all these great little handicraft stalls and coffee places, all along the river. Then it was up and over this bridge. On the other side, there is a rowing club, kids park and a walk along the river back to the main bridge and tourist info centre. It makes for a great 15-20 minute loop that you can keep repeating and is very safe. Bring money, so that at the end of your run you can have a coffee and peruse the handicrafts.
reviews/19/text:
This was my favourite area of Coimbra. There is a great park either side of the bridge and the bridge itself is beautiful.

A really fascinating architectural design with a kink in the middle.
reviews/19/title: Beautiful bridge- nicest area of Coimbra
subcategory_ranking: #13 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Rotunda das Lages Parque Verde do Mondego, Coimbra 3040-255 Portugal
name: Exploratorio - Centro Ciencia Viva de Coimbra
photo/caption: Exploratório: Aberto de terça-feira a domingo
ranking: #31 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #31 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: A good place to spend some time while in Coimbra but not very good for those who do not know Portuguese.
reviews/1/text: The Exploratorio is one of the best attractions for families to do together in Coimbra. It has a permanent exhbition related to the human body which is interesting for kids and adults alike, with a lot of information and experiments to try out, in a useful but limited attempt to provide some interactive entertainment to the visitors. It also has a 360º cinema room with nice films of around 30 minutes to watch: this time we saw a wonderful movie about Escher, the Dutch graphic artist. And finally it has rotating temporary exhibitions which are usually very interesting. Currently there is a very unusual and complete exhibition of tarantula spiders and scorpions which are a wonder to see and share with kids. And the price is quite small for such a variety of things to see.
reviews/2/text: This is a great place to spend some time with kids out of the rain or of the sun. It is a hands-on science museum, where kids (and grownups) do experiments to try to understand certain things, from how the body works to how sound and light travel among other issues. There is a planetarium and also some outdoor activities.
reviews/3/text: When rainy take your kids here, very nice museum for kids. they can do an touch everything while learning. The expo was on the human body. The only thing I did not like was the fact that everything was in portuguese and no english. so for non portuguese tourists it is hard to understand.
reviews/4/text:
Either for visitors or for locals, this is one mandatory places to go with kids (I would say from 3 and above).
It's part of a network of Life Science Centers, being the first of its kind in Portugal, has now new facilities in a new location. Despite losing part of the garden and botanical interest it has definitely won in extra space, location and conditions.
After walking in the city park and Parque Verde, cross the walking bridge and spend a few hours in Exploratorio.
reviews/4/title: For a morning/afternoon with the kids
reviews/5/text: Passamos 5 horas no exploratório e nunca tivemos um momento chato. Como sempre a experiência interativa permanente, apesar de achar que ainda há muitas atividades que estão avariadas, o que demonstra algum desmazelar. Adoramos os filmes 360º e o workshop de construção. Foi uma tarde super divertida. Obrigada a todos os funcionários que são EXCELENTES e tornam toda a experiência em magia.
reviews/6/text: Um espaço muito agradável e que nos permite aumentar os nossos conhecimentos na área das ciencias, excelente local a visitar com crianças
reviews/7/text:
É lamentável parte das coisas não funcionarem. Há investimento mas falta manutenção 
Interessante para crianças de todas as idades
reviews/8/text:
Muitas actividades disponíveis ao fim-de-semana para toda a família. Tem sempre sessões de filmes projectados a 360.º com diferentes temáticas. 
Muito divertido para  os mais novos. 
Tem uma cafetaria muito boa!
reviews/9/text: Visitamos a exposição do corpo humano, já que durante a semana só esta e a dos insectos estão abertas ao público. A funcionária que nos acompanhou era muito prestável e simpática, no entanto alguns dos aparelhos (principalmente os mais "tecnológicos") não funcionavam. Não recomendo, já que o facto de alguns aparelhos não funcionarem estraga toda a experiência. Não recomendo. Uma desilusão! A não repetir.
reviews/9/title: Seria muito mais interessante se os aparelhos funcionassem
reviews/10/text: Centro ciência viva muito completo e interativo. A área do corpo humano é extensa e criativa. A zona dos pintainhos a sair da casca, similar ao Museu da ciência de Valência, mas com o pormenor dos bancos que nos permitem relaxar e assistir ao fenómeno do nascimento! Apesar da dimensão, não fica nada atrás de outros museus da ciência europeus. Parabéns!
reviews/11/text:
Habia dos pabellones. Uno para el cuerpo humano y otro para bichos. Cada uno tenia su entrada. Se pueden sacar conjunta y ser mas economico(además también dan la posibilidad de comprar la entrada para Portugal do pequeñito)
La visita al pabellón del cuerpo humano era entretenida, si vas con niños mejor porque para ellos es bastante entretenido e interactivo. (te explican las partes y funciones del cuerpo humano mediante pruebas, juegos y actividades. Todo está explicado en portugués, no dan la opción de otro idioma)
La visita a la parte de los bichos no nos gusto nada. (Por mi... no hubiese entrado. No merece la pena)
reviews/12/text: Súper recomendable para ir con pequeños, les encanta, linda experiencia, los niños disfrutan mucho. Vale la pena, y muy bien ubicado, fácil estacionar
reviews/13/text: 과거의 앞서가던 시절, 포르투갈이 가지고 있던 기술력과 과학을 전시해 둔 곳입니다. 디자인, 건축 등을 전시했으며 오디오 투어가 좋습니다.
reviews/14/text: Visita obligada con niños en Coímbra . Bien estructurada la visita y con un montón de opciones para registrar por nuestros sentidos
reviews/15/text: São várias as visitas que já aqui fizemos, várias as exposições e mesmo quando são as mesmas não deixam de surpreender!
reviews/15/title: O nosso centro de ciência viva preferido
reviews/16/text: É um espaço muito bem estruturado, para o desenvolvimento científico dos jovens,onde podem aprender as inovações científicas mais actuais, mas também interagir. Actualmente, está neste Centro de Ciência Viva, uma espectacular e IMPERDÍVEL Exposição do TITANIC, que estará até Dezembro deste ano. É uma Audio Visita, muito bem estruturada e explicada ao pormenor, desde a sua concepção, construção e a viajem de inauguração e única. Excelente. Recomendo vivamente a sua visita até Dezembro.
reviews/16/title: ESPAÇO ONDE SE PODE APRENDER MUITO - CRIANÇAS, JOVENS E ADULTOS.
reviews/17/text: Visita de aprendizado para quem está apreendendo sobre o corpo humano. Ensina de maneira didática, divertida e juvenil.
reviews/18/text: De casualidad encontramos este centro de la ciencia a las afueras de Coímbra. Es muy adecuado para acercar a los niños a la ciencia ya que es muy interactivo y están todo muy bien explicado. Además tiene un cine y Max con una película muy interesante. Muy recomendable para acudir con niños ya que el tiempo se les hace corto.
reviews/19/text:
Les expériences sont très variées et beaucoup de domaines sont évoqués.
Mes enfants ont 3 et 6 ans et chacun a apprécié sa visite.
Malheureusement, tous les textes ne sont qu' en portugais...
subcategory_ranking: #31 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Coimbra Portugal
name: Praca do Comercio
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Jewish History of Coimbra
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Coimbra's Historical Highlights
ranking: #21 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #21 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: We had a meal here, but should have wandered a few feet up hill to the main shopping street, which is more inviting.  This is an open paved square, quite large with old buildings around.  A few restaurants, not very good, are set up with umbrellas.  Oppressive in the heat.
reviews/1/text: The street from the river to get here is a great walk. Not long just puts you in this City. This square very nice.
reviews/2/text: This big open square has a few restaurants with tables and umbrellas set up. But this is not the lively and interesting part of downtown.  Walk up hill to the next block and you will find a long pedestrian street with more food options.
reviews/3/text: A very sad square, empty of people on a Friday afternoon, just a couple of boring restaurants, few shops.  An historic church but no life.
reviews/4/text:
A plain square right in the middle of the city. It comes awake with the stories of what went on in the square. Framed by buildings of the day a must for visitors.
T
reviews/5/text: Another important square of Coimbra. It is really active with a lot of restaurants but not very wide.
reviews/6/text: Praca do Comercio is located inthe heart of the city. It is Coimbra’s largest square. Praca do Comercio took its name due to the intense commercial activity that took place there. Surrounded by 18th-century apartment buildings and businesses, it’s not a monumental square , but over the centuries it was literally the “market square” where the people of Coimbra did most of their shopping. Now it is a quiet place to relax at an outdoor cafe.  In a corner is the church of Sao Tiago, one of Coimbra’s oldest monuments. On the opposite end is another church, Igreja de Sao Bartolomeu, which dates from the 10th century but was much altered in a baroque style in the 1700s. The square is lovely and the atmosphere is magical. It’s reached via steps from Rua Ferreira Borges, downtown’s main pedestrian street.
reviews/7/text: The name of the triangular square of Commerce speaks for itself. Initially, it was a shopping square, when Coimbra grew and began to grow in breadth. Several street names that start from the square bear the names of works or products sold in the square. For example, Rua Azeiteiras is a street of olive oil. The square begins with the squat church of San Tiago, and ends with the church of San Bartolomeu. To whom divine supervision was not enough to conduct an honest business, the Pelourinho (pillory) was intended. Now they sell, eat and drink here. Fun place...
reviews/7/title: Fun place... But with churches and pillory.
reviews/8/text: This is a bit of a hike from the train station, we took at taxi. It is a great place to hang out and have a glass of tine and watch people go by.
reviews/9/text: Like so many squares in Iberia, the "Praça do Comercio" is only interesting in that it represents a typical example of mediterranean architecture.
reviews/10/text: A prime location to people watch.  Everyone, business execs, shoppers, students, all make their way to and through the center of the praca.  Just sit back, have a glass of wine and watch the fun.
reviews/10/title: Sit In The Winter Sun And Have A Cupo de Vinho.
reviews/11/text: This square is not as commercial as the next street over. There are some nice restaurants and local craft shops. The church in the square is also nice to visit.
reviews/12/text: You can find different shops and coffee shops.. It s easy to have a relax time while sipping you coffee. There is sometimes big screen TV show performances.
reviews/13/text:
the place is waiting for tired tourists, walking from Saint Bartholomew church from Santiago church or vice versa
you could rest, eat, drink or shopping in that area
look to the buildings from 17th and 18th centuries
reviews/13/title: iWas there, resting ij the middle of history
reviews/14/text: Praca do Commercio in Coimbra Portugal is a lovely district for shopping and there are many restaurants too.  You are able to sit in the shade of an umbrella and get a coffee, beer and a piece of pie of your choice for a few euros and watch the world go by.
reviews/15/text:
The plaza is a good place to sit, relax, have a cup of coffee (a duplo, please) and perhaps a pastry.  Do not expect gourmet food, although the coffee is good.  It is a bit touristy (if a tour bus arrives, it is a lot touristy), but it has good views and there is usually a breeze.
We did not think of it as a destination, but as a rest from shopping or a respite from walking, because it is at the end of a wonderful shopping street where we bought cork products and pottery.
reviews/16/text:
What a beautiful city...so inviting. It's somewhere that our coach tour stopped for a lunch break, but the time ... well it will never do this city justice. We could have stopped for a lot longer and I am rather sure we would have all enjoyed looking around more. 

We ate, we explored a little and took photos. The stores were terribly quaint with some amazing shopping opportunities. I would have enjoyed staying here exploring for much longer than I was able to.
reviews/17/text: Whilst on a tour we stopped here for a look round and a lunch break. It's a nice area to wander around with a good mix of shops and restaurants. We found the shops selling souvenirs and clothing made out of thin cork most interesting as was the cake shop in the square selling king size meringues filled with cream.
reviews/18/text: Nice square 'in between the climbs' upstairs. Nice terraces and always something to be seen or to be done.
reviews/19/text: This square starts at the base of the shopping street.  It has some nice restaurants and is a beautiful spot.  We loved it.
subcategory_ranking: #21 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Largo da Feira dos Estudantes, Coimbra 3600-213 Portugal
name: Se Nova Catedral de Coimbra
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Coimbra and Aveiro small group tour from Porto with river cruise
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Bussaco Palace and the University of Coimbra Private Tour
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Guided tour of the University and city of Coimbra.
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Lisbon to Porto Private Tour stoping in Coimbra and Aveiro
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Private Tour to University of Coimbra and an ancient Roman city
ranking: #20 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #20 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
The Se Nova Cathedral - the New Cathedral stands very close to the University square on the Coimbra hilltop.
It dates back to 17c being much younger than the old Se down the hill from 12 c. Beautiful Baroque facade hides magnificent lavish interiors like in most Portuguese churches.
There's an entry fee (they call it donation) of 1 Euro - symbolic, but inappropriate imo - let the people decide if to give, religious places should be free for everyone.

Pro TIP: right from the entrance turn left where you'll find the ticket booth for the Coimbra University. This will spare you double walking from the University square and back, as there're no tickets sold at the square.
reviews/0/title: Buy your University tickets here around the corner
reviews/1/text: All cleaned up and sparkling, ready for the Saturday wedding that was taking place.  Because of the wedding we could not go inside, but it sure did look spiffy.
reviews/2/text: Very beautiful church in the university area. Sad that everything was full of cars and it was impossible to take a proper photo.
reviews/3/text: This cathedral is located in the square near the University of Coimbra. Its construction began in 1598 by the architect Baltazar Alvares and was completed 100 years later. In 1772 the Marquis of Pombal ordered the transfer of the Episcopal See of Coimbra from the Old Cathedral to this one built as a Jesuit church. There are four figures of Jesuit saints on the facade of the church. In the upper part of the facade, completed in the 18th century, there is a Baroque decoration. The transept and presbytery are decorated with huge, gilded altars, built at the turn of the 17th and 18th centuries. The choir stalls from the 17th century and a magnificent baptismal font from one of its side chapels were brought from the Old Cathedral. Church with two bell towers and a dome, really worth seeing.
reviews/4/text: Most visitors after having visited the Old University buildings walk down the hill to the Old Cathedral and to downtown. Many walk by the New cathedral without entering it but, in my opinion, it is worth to spend some time visiting this church and paying attention to some very good mannerist and baroque decorative elements. Enjoy!
reviews/5/text: This wasn't my favorite cathedral that I saw on my trip but it's worth a visit. The architecture and decor is very pretty.
reviews/6/text: This building dates from the eighteenth century and, as such, has no particularly pronounced style (it is not Baroque).
reviews/7/text: Another example of a fine church. Loved the cherubs right at the top of the dome. Stand underneath the dome and look up to see them
reviews/8/text: The construction of the new Cathedral of Coimbra began in 1598, and ended 100 years later. The impressive cathedral stands out in its architecture, which has greatly influenced churches in the Portuguese colonies in the world. The church has two bell towers behind the façade, and a dome, and it creates inspiration in its ornate interior.
reviews/9/text: This cathedral had unusual carved features. Make sure you go through the left side door to see the collection of religious artifacts. Some are very old and interesting.
reviews/9/title: A lovely cathedral with plenty to see
reviews/10/text:
Originally a modern Jesuit church, it has a beautiful rich facade with statues in niches and soaring pinnacles. In hue of white it looked wonderful against the deep sky azure.

Inside is magnificently ornate. The choir is gorgeous with a multitude of gilt around the lovely hand carved wood. 

From the rear the vista along the nave is inspiring. Culminating in the exquisite high altar. At the back a decorative organ is in the traditional elevated placement. Additionally, side chapels are lovely.
reviews/11/text: The New Cathedral of Coimbra nearly blinds a visitor with the opulence of its altars. On balance, worth a look.
reviews/12/text: This Cathedral, located in the University district, is worth a 5- 10 minute jump in and jump out.  The altar is lovely but the rest of it is underwhelming, especially if you have visited some of the other churches in the Northern region of Portugal.
reviews/13/text: Large and spacious inside with soaring vault and dome. Lavish gilded altarpiece. Costs 1 euro to see. Worth 10 to 15 minutes if you in the University area....unless you have been "churched out".
reviews/14/text: This cathedral is very close to College of Jesus and Coimbra University. It is a fine cathedral and free entry, so worth having a look inside.
reviews/15/text:
Located near the historical University of Coimbra, the "New Cathedral" is a beautiful building.
We visited both the church as well as the cloister.
Minimal cost to visit and was well worth a look.
reviews/16/text: As you probably know, there is a hill dominating Coimbra where many of the buildings of its venerable university stand. As there is a mixture of valuable old buildings intermingled with the new ones, it´s not unlikely that you might overlook some interesting spots in this area which are a bit "hidden" among other buildings. One of the outstanding landmarks is the new cathedral. The rather classical lines in its facade, especially the lower parts of it might be a bit misleading, as once you enter the temple, the interior is absolutely baroque, despite some classical estructural elements. That evolution in styles is apparently a consequence of the long time it took its construction. This temple might not be the most inspiring compared to other marvelous ones I had the chance to see in my stay in Portugal, but its serene monumentality is quite remarkable.
reviews/17/text: I actually prefer the old cathedral over the "new" one.    As I stepped in the church, I paused to let my eyes adjust and the lady at the desk yelled at me to pay 1 Euro.    I looked inside briefly and left.  Didn't feel very welcome.
reviews/18/text: We walked up the hill from Se Velha de Coimbra on the way passing my saints on the corner of the trail. The outside of the New Cathedral didnt  look too impressive.There is a nice white marble statute. On entry you pass into a shop where you have a choice of visit church and cloisters, etc. We opted for church and cloisters. The church is very nice in side with lots and lots of gold everywhere. The walk in the cloisters goes around a nice garden and a monument. It would have been better if it wasnt raining.
reviews/19/text:
Stunning 'new' cathedral.
Well worth a visit with stunning iconography anf stuary.
Some lovely pictures.
Serene atmosphere.
subcategory_ranking: #20 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Parque de Santa Cruz - Jardim da Sereia, Coimbra 3000-019 Portugal
