name: Praca da Republica
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Classic car city tour – Coimbra ride
ranking: #26 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #26 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: We came here for drinks before dinner a couple of times.  It is a huge open square with a lot of space.  Used by student groups during the day,  used for food and drink in the evening.  I can be a little noisy.  Go for a spot in the shade.
reviews/1/text: This is a big open square downtown, a place you will surely pass through.  Just beyond are some good places to eat and drink, and some shopping.
reviews/2/text: We had a drink here and watched a gaggle of students do a cheer thing.  The Praca is huge and open and many of the bars around have tables  on the sides.  The tree-lined avenue runs off down the hill to the old city.
reviews/3/text: This is another famous square of Coimbra but for me, one of the least beautiful. The park next to it is nice, though.
reviews/4/text: The park has many shady trees and features an unusual entrance. It features a large statue and a fairly ordinary water feature.
reviews/4/title: A large monument and shady trees
reviews/5/text:
This Town Square is located near the university with several options for food and drink and Parque de Santa Cruz - Jardim da Sereia can be found just across the street. 
Tourist Bureau was also located in this square. 
Looks like a popular spot for the students to hangout.
reviews/6/text:
Where the fun starts.
If you are looking for places to eat and walk and/or just to take a drink. This is the place to go.
If you're looking for cultural activities, the TAGV coffee and theater will not disappoint you. 
Perfect for every occasion. Either it's a date, a outing with your buddies or a "me" time alone. The "Praça da República" has everything your looking for
reviews/7/text: We arrived a couple of days ago, parked on the street while we  organised our accommodation. Little did we know that all parking around the square is meter parking. This square is leafy, and has a feeling of open space, coffee was good and the tourist information was ok, offering sound information. Plenty of buses depart from here, so park in a safe spot and walk to enjoy the many beautiful monuments, and parks in Coinbra.
reviews/7/title: Staying in Coinbra, and great location to see the university.
reviews/8/text:
Great large open space with cafes. restaurants and statuary.
Good for watching the world go by while having a drink or snack.
reviews/9/text: A large square with bars and cafes, some are open early for a coffee.  The old gate and the adjacent walls have interesting tile work.
reviews/9/title: Interesting and close to our hotel
reviews/10/text: Several bars in the area, just go bar hopping and enjoy. Live music in the Irish Bar, but try out the clubs as well. Just do as the locals do, have a small beer and then wander from bar to bar.
reviews/11/text:
As a student city Coimbra has many choices of things to do, bars and clubs in other areas, but most students have their social life going on around the square.
Starting drinking in the Square, and continuing to do this for hours, before going to clubs is normal. 
So, if you are very young and do not mind standing drinking, you will like the nightlife of the "Square".
As a square think it was supposed to have more benches and trash bins.
reviews/12/text: It is another remarkable historic place at this Portuguese city. It is recommendable to check the buildings and its urbanistic plan.
reviews/13/text:
Praça da República is a square surrounded by bars and cafés.  There are also 2 pizza restaurants and a language school.  It's close to the university and Botanic Gardens and is a nice place to spend some time relaxing when exploring the city.  One of the cafés has tables and chairs in the centre of the square which is nice for a panoramic view.  It's very busy in the evening with university students during term time.
Some of the buildings need a lick of paint.
reviews/13/title: Large Square With Numerous Cafés and Bars
reviews/14/text:
This is the best place to chill, enjoy a drink or go out in Coimbra 
Cafe Academico is a good place !!
reviews/15/text: This square is located on the opposite side of the old city. There are numerous bars and cafes surrounding the square, most of which were frequented by the local student population. Tourists do not make it to this side of town - too bad as the square offers several nice places to relax while enjoying a snack. It is also the entranceway to the picturesque Jardim da Sereia.
reviews/16/text: This is a great meeting point, but basically that's it as there is nothing in the Praça other than cobblestones.
reviews/17/text:
If you're looking for a place to start the night, Praça da República will sure provide you with enough options, being one of the centers of the city's night life. 
During the day it's a lovely place to drink something and relax, as it is quite close to almost everything a visitor should be looking for. 
I'd recommend going to the close by Jardim Botânico (botanical garden) or the Jardim da Sereia (mermaid Garden) that actually got it's name from a statue of a male mermaid, a triton. What I'm sad to report is that the head of such statue has been robbed, still a lovely place.
reviews/18/text:
The Praça da República was not always the official name of the place, the name initially was Praça D. Luís. The change of name has to see with the change of the political regime on the 5th of October 1910.
This location is located above the “Public Market” and only a few steps away from the University of Coimbra, and from there it is only a few steps away from the “Old Town of Coimbra” were there is allot to see, you can easily spend a whole day on and around this location, also the “Parque da Sereia or Parque de Santa Cruz is on this location.
Mostly filled with allot of students during the evenings.
reviews/19/text: Coimbra es una ciudad preciosa. Pasamos un día y una noche allí y puedo decir que tiene una casco antiguo muy bonito junto con la biblioteca Joanina en la Universidad histórica.
subcategory_ranking: #26 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Largo Marques de Pombal, Coimbra 3000-272 Portugal
name: Museu da Ciencia
ranking: #22 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #22 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: It's part of your ticket price when you visit the Univ of Coimbra to see the library. Pop over. It's around the corner from the central part of campus.
reviews/1/text: A ticket to visit the university includes not only the Chapel of San Miguel, the Joanin Library and the Faculty of Law, but also the Museum of Science. However, it is located in another building at a distance. We had only 40 minutes left and it was traditional for tourists what to watch and what to sacrifice. We chose zoology instead of chemistry. Still, the scarecrows are somehow more visible. What can you say about the museum? Of course, this is not the German Museum in Munich, which is the best I have yet seen in this area. Connecting history and modernity is not easy. For example, the Japanese in Odaiba focused on modernity and it was also not too organic. The Museum in Coimbra is more about the past. At least its zoological part and tool rooms. It's not the proverbial interactivity, but the lack of an educational part, an explanation of the principles of operation of tools, animal habitats, etc. Science, it's about this. In other words, I didn't have enough science in the science museum. I think this is the strength of the Munich experience.Maybe we didn't have enough time... In any case, the museum may not be the most spectacular, or rather, not the most brilliant part of the university, but it is definitely the most useful. It's better than looking at the spines of books on the shelves in Joanin's library. Strictly speaking, this is the only university.
reviews/1/title: Maybe not the most brilliant, but the most useful part of our visit.
reviews/2/text: Well, a little disappointed because i thought that would be more interesting, but if in Coimbra and have free time a nice place to see.
reviews/3/text: Excellent museum for science lovers, specially physicists and ophthalmologists, as it has a great emphasis on this part of the sciences.
reviews/4/text: The museum is really an old faculty of science. The display of Physics related objects from the XVIII and XIX century is very interesting. The exhibition on light was OK but nothing extraordinary. The Biology collection a bit outdated in the way is displayed as it does not teach much
reviews/5/text: In the 18th century there were big changes in Portugal under Pombal  Secretary of the State of Internal Affairs of the Kingdom.He  implemented ideas of the "Enlightenment", and at the museum of sciences in Coimbra one can apreciate that. THe museum is very intresting, especially for those  who like sciences, history, nature and old machines
reviews/6/text: The Science Museum of Coimbra is part of the University and library tour. The museum is certainly interesting, especially in the interactive activities it offers, and the display of all the physics instruments. Kids will love it!
reviews/7/text:
Set in a beautifully ornate building it provides a great display of scientific instruments, glassware and more.

We walked into a most impressive lecture and demonstration hall with tiered seating and gorgeous wooden features. 

Laboratory benches of traditional dark wood  with many drawers, presses and complete with water taps and sink, were great to see. 

Navigational equipment consisted of an  armillary sphere and sextant. Exhibits of glassware included graduated cylinders, round bottomed flasks and ancillary tubes. 

A fabulous Periodic Tables of the Elements is displayed on high, which given its vintage, is of necessity incomplete.
reviews/8/text: I highly recommend this museum. We got entrance as a part of our tour through the Coimbra University. Observe physics equipment used for experiments and education through the times. Physics seems like it was a lot more fun back in the days. There is also an impressive collection of taxidermied animals and the process of studying them.
reviews/8/title: Learn something new and marvel at the equipment and animals
reviews/9/text: We did it as part of the visit to the Science museum. If you have children they will love all the interactive parts in the science area. For some of you the old lecture theaters will bring back memories.
reviews/10/text: Very interesting guided tour if you have a bent for science. Most unique section to me was the collection of historic scientific instruments from the 18th and 19th centuries in the Physics Museum. I have not seen anything like it in any US or European Museum. The other collections offer a short walk through botany, mineralogy, medicine, zoology and natural history that would be good for children since not overwhelming.
reviews/10/title: Important Broad Ranging Science Collection - Museu da Ciencia
reviews/11/text: Some interesting items are on display, you cannot really compare it with a regular science museum, but it is worth having a look inside.
reviews/12/text: Visiting cabinet of biology and physics is a trip to previous century - while stuffed animals are interesting but in rather bad shape, cabinet of physics show different experiments to demonstrate basic physical laws. Definitely worthwhile to visit.
reviews/13/text: After more than 30 minutes looking for the entrance, a young man found us wandering around and led us to the entrance. there was a long queue so we just left without visiting.
reviews/14/text: Did I really pay to go in this place? They should close it down until it's fully dusted. And throw in someplace to sit down.
reviews/15/text: This is a large collection of specimens and scientific equipment to be seen. There are two buildings with different collections. Very interesting.
reviews/16/text: If you have the time go visit this museum which as a old time like feeling which is interesting and amusing
reviews/17/text: This museum is a must go for people interested in scientific collections and study material of the natural sciences of the late 19th and early 20th century. It is enjoyable to experience with what material past scientists had to work with
reviews/18/text: This is an amazing museum, it's perfect for kids: there is so much to see and to learn! You could easily spend half a day there! Don't miss out on it!
reviews/19/text: Half the exhibits don’t work, the half are as exciting as drying paint. Truly awful science museum. How can anyone rate this with 5 stars? Have you ever been to a science museum?
subcategory_ranking: #22 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Paco das Escolas - Foyer da Biblioteca Geral Universidade de Coimbra, Coimbra 3000-447 Portugal
address_obj/street1: Paco das Escolas - Foyer da Biblioteca Geral
name: Sala dos Capelos
ranking: #19 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #19 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: Built as a throne room in the royal palace of Coimbra, this imposing hall became the hall of the main academic ceremonies of the university (hence the name Great Acts Room) which was moved here in 1544. The Sala dos Capelos can be visited following the path that goes from the Sala das Armas to the Sala do Exame Privado through the windows open on it. Beautifull and showy, on the red walls there is an interesting gallery of oil paintings of the Portuguese kings. One of the highlights when visiting the university
reviews/0/title: One of the highlights when visiting the university
reviews/1/text: You are at the former Throne Hall of the ancient "Paço Real da Alcáçova", the royal palace of the Portuguese kings while Coimbra was their capital city! "Sala dos Capelos", most commonly known as "Sala dos Grandes Atos", was named after the "capelos" - the ornamented caps used by the doctors of the "Universidade de Coimbra" on solemn occasions. Here, the most important ceremonies of the University take place! Enjoy!
reviews/1/title: At the former Throne Hall of the Paço Real da Alcáçova in Coimbra!
reviews/2/text: It is the only place in the 12.5 Euro which is worthwhile to a pay. The Aula is very magnificent, and besides the Aula, there is a balcony viewing the whole campus town.
reviews/3/text: Especially delightful (and humbling) for those of us who defended our PhDs in less splendid surroundings. Be sure to visit while seeing the incomparable Coimbra library nearby.
reviews/4/text: From the balcony looking down, the room is quite imposing, especially for the graduating students to defend their work in front of the professors. The painted ceiling and the chandeliers added to the time honored process.
reviews/4/title: A room to defend the thesis
reviews/5/text:
Very formal and well worth the short visit. A good reminder of the honor and esteem due advanced studies and this building accords it. The Sala Grande is interesting, formal and majestic and can be seen from an upper level and obviously it is still used.

Other rooms, including the Arms Room, tie this building to Portugese royalty.

I seem to remember that this building had guards inside.
reviews/6/text: This is a monumental hall, full of history, solemnity and significance. To tell the truth, when I entered this magnificent room I felt a sort of anti climax, as I came just after seeing the Library, but you know, the latter is so unique that everything you see after it seems a bit colourless. Maybe if you´re visiting all the spots in the universitary complex, inverting the order of your visits can change that perception radically. Anyway, this place is very remarkable and full of history.
reviews/7/text: Turn a corner and here you find the most impressive panelled chamber of great height with wonderful paint and panelling, still not quite sure what this is used for but one can imagine it is for special formal occasions at the university.
reviews/8/text:
We went to this attraction because it was included in our tour around the Coimbra University.
In this room is where some of the most important people defended their final paperwork to become "doctors" or during their masters.
Still nowadays it is used for this purpose. 
This is a room full of history and power.
This is a must do if you are in coimbra
reviews/9/text: Grand hall lined with red carpet and featuring portraits from University Rectors through the ages. Nice panoramic view from upstairs.
reviews/9/title: Grand hall with portraits of Rectors
reviews/10/text: After visiting the library and the St. Michael's Chapel, get inside the adjacent building and wander around and you will find gorgeous lecture halls like this one and eventually an outdoors walkway overlooking the old cathedral.
reviews/10/title: One of the Exquisite Lecture Halls
reviews/11/text: This was where the King held meetings. The room is decorated with paintings of kings and queens of Portugal. It is where all PhD defenses take place at the University of Coimbra. It is absolutely medieval: the candidate sits in a small chair and table with a table lamp and the committee members sit in front with their feet at the level of the candidate's eyes also with a table lamp. It confers a very ceremonial atmosphere to the defense.
reviews/11/title: A royal room for PhD defenses
reviews/12/text: I observed a student and her mentors questioning her through the Ph.D. defense with the head of school and public onlookers. This is a grant old hall and every ph.d defense takes place here unless the docket is too crowded. Great spectacle.
reviews/12/title: Every PH.D. defense takes place here
reviews/13/text: Um sítio grandioso, cuidado, e é sempre uma honra estar no local onde a língua portuguesa foi falada pela primeira vez.
reviews/14/text: Os acessos estão a precusar de restauro, mas como  toda a universidade está em obras, penso que também aqui as farao. A não perder as vistas do varandim.
reviews/15/text: Le château n'a rien de royal. Pas grand chose à visiter à part quelques fresques murales représentant des nobles ou ecclésiastiques à la mine peu accueillante.
reviews/16/text: Sala dos Capelos je velkolepý sál, kde studenti skládali zkoušky. Kdysi byl součástí královského paláce a dodnes se zde prý předávají tituly či obhajují závěrečné práce. Sál je zdobený portréty bývalých panovníků a universitních rektorů, strop se skládá ze zajímavě poskládaných barevných dřevěných panelů. Není možné vstoupit přímo do sálu, ale mohli jsme si ho prohlédnout z několika otevřených oken v prvním patře.
reviews/17/text: Fa parte della visita dell'Università, e richiama Sala Grande dos Actos, in pratica dove si svolgono le lauree e gli eventi. Si vede dall'alto ed è attorniata dai ritratti dei Re.
reviews/18/text: A sala tem quadros dos vários reis de Portugal. O mobiliário acompanha a decoração e é uma sala bastante apelativa.
reviews/19/text:
El palacio tiene algunas estancias visitables interesantes pero nada alucinante. La más bonita es la sala dos capelos pero el resto se ve muy rápido.
La entrada se puede comprar en la página web o en la taquilla que está en el museo de ciencias. El pack conjunto de biblioteca + capilla + palacio + museo son 12,5€.
subcategory_ranking: #19 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Avenida Emidio Navarro, Coimbra 3000-150 Portugal
name: Largo da Portagem
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Jewish History of Coimbra
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Coimbra's Historical Highlights
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Discovering the charms and places of Coimbra
offer_group/offer_list/3/title: Coimbra's Historical Highlights: A Self-Guided Audio Tour
offer_group/offer_list/4/title: Walking Tour of Coimbra Heritage Site
ranking: #17 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #17 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: This very pretty square is near the commercial center of town.  We enjoyed lingering here and looking around for a place for a cold drink.  Lots of people around.
reviews/1/text: This square, located at the level of the Rio Mondego in front of the Santa Clara Bridge, is the center of the city and the starting point for tourists to enter and climb the historic part of Coimbra. The fact of being the access point to the city is also confirmed by the fact that in the past taxes were paid here for incoming goods. The presence of historic buildings such as the Hotel Astória and the Edifício do Banco de Portugal em Coimbra confirm the economic and vital centrality of this square in Coimbra. While the crowded tables of the bars and their large sun umbrellas fill a large part of the square, in the center of the green area with grass stands the statue of an important politician born in Coimbra, Joaquim António de Aguiar.
reviews/2/text: My favorite part on Coimbra. Wide area that narrows to a great street to walk. Wonderful area. Full of life with River behind. Our hotel is at the end closet to the river.
reviews/2/title: My favorite part of the City
reviews/3/text: There are a number of fine historical buildings around this square just off the river. The statue of Joaquim Antonio ei Aguiar was added in 1914.
reviews/3/title: A lovely square just off the river
reviews/4/text: This is a pleasant little park in the downtown area of town with a statue in the middle and some important buildings around.  Some good places to eat and drink around.
reviews/5/text:
Largo da Portagem square stands on the other side of the main pedestrian Rua Ferreira Borges street, opposite the 8 May square on the other street end.
It is open to the Mondego river which was used to bring goods to town and collect customs duties here, hence the name. In front of the square is the Santa Clara bridge.
Around the square are notable edifices like Bank of Portugal and historic Astoria hotel, while the central green space adorns Joacim Aguiar monument.
reviews/6/text: We were here at night when so many of the buildings were illuminated and it was lovely, just lovely.  Cafe seating in the middle and a big statue.  Some gorgeous architecture and then there is the river.
reviews/7/text: One of the most iconic places of Coimbra and a "must" if you visit the city. This was my first stop coming from the train station.
reviews/8/text: Largo da Portagem is rather a small square opens to the river and Santa Clara Bridge. At the center is a statue of Joaquim António de Aguiar , erected in 1913. You can see see here some of the most beautiful buildings in Coimbra , like the iconic Astoria Hotel and the local headquarters of the Bank of Portugal. There are also cafes and restaurants. A really beautiful and nice place.
reviews/9/text: The name of the square is translated as Toll Square. It is clear that this is a medieval name associated with the collection of customs duties from ships unloaded in Coimbra for trade. Fees are no longer charged, although the Bank of Portugal building is available. Another notable building is the beautiful Hotel Astória, built in 1926. The center of the composition is a monument by the local sculptor Costa Mota, installed in honor of the famous liberal politician of the XIX century Joaquim Antonio de Aguiar, a native of Coimbra. Three times the Prime Minister of Portugal is depicted at the time of signing decrees on the nationalization of church assets in 1834, for which he received the nickname "Mata-Frades" - " Killer of monks"
reviews/9/title: A beautiful square where customs duties are no longer taken.
reviews/10/text: Surrounded by older buildings and with plenty of cafe tables the only drawback is proximity to major roads and the accompanying traffic din. Like so much of the World what was once delightful is a little bit spoiled by the motor car.
reviews/10/title: Can be busy and noisy but a bit picturesque too
reviews/11/text:
Plenty of restaurants , shops and boat tour right across the street .
Good food and drinks at a reasonable price. We didn't feel rushed at all at the restaurant.
reviews/11/title: Great place to hang out and elax
reviews/12/text: The Monument Largo da Portagem, dedicated to a Portuguese politician (Joaquim Antonio de Aguiar), is located at the entrance to the city, with the inscription on the lawn: Coimbra. There are many shops and restaurants in this area, and it is very nice to walk here day and night (I prefer at night), especially along Rio Mondego.
reviews/12/title: A nice place to walk around
reviews/13/text: We spent some time in this area, lots of shops and cafes.  My wife visited the many cork purse places and found one she loved. Worth the visit, especially for souvenirs.
reviews/14/text: You will notice that some of the building in Coimbra are in need of repair or are not the clean.  This area, right by the river, is quite baroque in style, and thus sticks out as compared to that around the corner.  The shops vary... most are full of touristy stuff, but interspersed are some nice boutiques and pastry shops.  It is a very small section of the city.
reviews/14/title: Ornate and very well kept part of the city
reviews/15/text: Largo da Portagem translates to an open area being the entrance to the City and that is exactly what it is. Shiny white marble and stone on a sunny day, with various roads leading off, plus restaurants and shops around the edge. The perfect place to start a visit. The statue on the central pedestal is of a famous politician.
reviews/15/title: An Impressive Entry Point Into Coimbra
reviews/16/text: Located right at the river this is a great place to start exploring the city. There are shops and restaurants around the square.
reviews/17/text: I’ll say this is the start point of city centre depending on which way you look at it. Since we were coming from walking across the bridge. We walked through the city centre to the other side and walked around and checked out the gift shops. Place was busy full of tourist and locals and couple restaurants. Nice place was impressed.
reviews/18/text:
It is always illuminating to visit an old city of culture. The Largo da Portagem, surrounded by the river on one side and by narrow streets on the other side, is worth a slow walk.
On top of the hill, the buildings of the University, are impressive. This is also worth a visit (on foot, a lot of stairs, but you can go with public transportation, or with a lift).
reviews/18/title: A visit to an old european city
reviews/19/text:
Excellent place from which to start exploring Coimbra as easy access to lifts higher levels.
Gardens and statue of Joaquim Antonio de Aguiar to admire.
subcategory_ranking: #17 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Praca do Comercio, Coimbra 3000-116 Portugal
name: Igreja Santiago
ranking: #24 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #24 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: An interesting Romanesque church that dates from the 12th Century.  Amazingly old.  The best thing in the Praca do Commercio.
reviews/1/text: Really nice and well preserved church just in the center of the city. It is amazing mostly in the outside, architecture is really special.
reviews/2/text: Very nice façade and very nice romanesque details in the building. It is in the middle of the city so it is easy to visit
reviews/3/text: If you are Catholic this is a refuge if you are looking for a quiet place in your holiday to meditate and spend some time with the Lord.  They have exposition and adoration of the Blessed Sacrament everyday, and the entrance to this church is on the side door beside the steps leading up to the pedestrian mall.  We would have missed it were it not pointed out by a nearby restaurant server.  Highly recommended!!
reviews/4/text: Enter by the side door and you are presented with a very old and simple church with a refurbished rood.  Beautiful golden coloured sandstone that's been around for centuries. Still in use for prayer as it was when we visited.
reviews/5/text:
A favorite church in Portugal....simplistic...contemplative...entry through side entrance through a hung curtain...because of the silence and the people praying before work, I could not bring myself to take any interior pictures of the interior out of respect.

Take a break from touring and sit here for a bit.
reviews/5/title: Must See - Contemplative...the Focus is on Simplicity...not Ornate Distractions
reviews/6/text: I never feel I should have to pay to enter a church.  We could find no one that knew anything about a mass schedule or if they even do mass in this church.  Very disappointed.
reviews/7/text:
While many of the churches in Coimbra has been restored, this one stands out in it's simplicity.  The sign outside said church said St. Tiago Church - but it is one in the same.  Interesting sign inside says
"In this Church we have continuous adoration before the Blessed Sacrament.  Please respect the silence"     Place was totally silent and very peaceful
reviews/8/text:
During a stop in Coimbra for lunch, it was insisted upon us to stop in to the old church. 

It’s old. It’s incredible that it’s still standing. There’s an interesting outdoor courtyard on the second level. 

That’s about as excited as I can get about Igreja Santiago after seeing the incredible, ornate churches in Porto.

If you have an extra couple euros burning a hole in your pocket and many hours to kill, certainly drop by. Otherwise, skip it and spend more time at the University.
reviews/9/text:
Nice old building in the city centre
Architecture was well preserved

A must see

From outside can get the good vibes
reviews/10/text:
this is a small old church in the centre of coimbra.
to enter the church you will have to go through a door on the side, close to the stairs as the main door is closed.
it does not have much inside that will wow you but again not all churchs can have gold and statues.
it is worth a quick visit.

please vote if you like the photos and this review
reviews/11/text:
the Commerce Square begins and ends with a very old church to each point
one of those two is Saint Tiago church, which has been built in 12th century, with some similarities with Se Velha (the main entrance)
the interior is sober and quiet; the wood make the place warmer

for me it was interesting to find an orthodox icon in that church, an usual presence in Portugal
Romanesques style church, very well preserved despite of those 8 centuries of history
reviews/12/text: Two friends and I visited the Igreja Santiago during our stay in Coimbra in October.   At first we thought it was closed but then discovered that the entrance on the side was open.   The church is small but very historic and in a location that made it a nice stop while enjoying the city.   Definitely worth a few minutes of your time if your are in the area!
reviews/13/text: The church appears to be closed but there is a side door that is ajar.  Don't be timid, give it a push and then pull aside the curtain into a beautifully preserved Romanesque intimate place of worship.  It is down a side street from the main commercial street off a plaza with restaurants.
reviews/14/text: The restrained and stony Romanesque facade is massive and the interior is thus seemingly sealed off from the noisy to and fro of the world outside.  Step quietly because there will often be people in prayer or meditation here.  Every sound seems to be amplified  and to resonate throughout the hard stone interior.   We were able to take photos, but quietly, please.  Easily accessible from the Praça  do Comércio.
reviews/14/title: Take a moment and step inside
reviews/15/text:
The trail to Santiago de Compostela picks up here for the pilgrims on the Camino Portuguese.

The church is small and solemn. It's beautiful in its simplicity.

I would definitely come back!
reviews/15/title: Quiet chapel of Santiago in Combria, Portugal
reviews/16/text: Loved visiting this church, which is located in a a very old quarter, with quaint restaurants and Fado bars.
reviews/17/text: Igreja Santiago (Santiago Church) is located a corner of Praça do Commerçio and is accessed by descending  the steps from Rua Ferreira Borges or from the windy, narrow  streets of the Baixa.  The church, albeit small, is well worth a visit to view its Romanesque architecture and they sometimes have exhibitions on display.  On one visit I saw an exhibition of torture implements from the Inquisition there.
reviews/17/title: Easy to Pass By Without Noticing
reviews/18/text: Located at the far end of Praca do Comercio, this small chapel for those serious about worshiping. The sign on the side door asks the person entering to shut the door behind them (so as little noise from the outside permeates). The interior is austere - dark and cold yet cozy and mystical. It is a small structure. Whenever I would visit there were just a couple of parishioners. Silence is expected.
reviews/19/text: This is no historic building as such: it is a church (small) with a religious purpose: silence and respect are demanded and expected. You cant avoid the history and you leave with a great sense of awe
subcategory_ranking: #24 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Rua General Humberto Delgado 207 211, Coimbra 3030-327 Portugal
name: Alma shopping Mall
ranking: #39 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #39 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text: A practical place to shop for the things you need.  Located outside the city center, best reached by private car.
reviews/1/text: A good sized shooping mall in Coimbra. Free parking. Multi-screen cinema on the third floor, operated by NOS, so you can check the film schedule on the NOS website. Most films (except local and childrens) are in english with portuguese subtitles (€7 per ticket). Good value Brasilian resturant on Floor 4 (all you can eat buffet for €8). Auchan supermarket on floor 0.
reviews/2/text:
Alma Shopping is the new name for Dolce Vita Mall as there has been a change of owner.
It's an attractive shopping centre on 4 floors, with a supermarket, 'Jumbo, a music school and other shops on the bottom floor and a multiplex cinema and food hall on the top floor.  The middle 2 floors house a variety of shops.
reviews/2/title: Not Really A Tourist Attraction, but a Good Shopping Centre
reviews/3/text:
At first I thought Dolce Vita Coimbra would be like any other mall... but boy was I wrong!

The first couple of floors are populated by miscellaneous stores dealing in clothes, perfumes and jewelry. Unconventional, but when you think about it it makes sense; people need clothes! Also noticed some stores selling outdated stuff like paper books, but that is surely temporary.

The topmost floor has a small, but interesting selection of fast food restaurants. A Burger King right next to a KFC? I applaud your boldness, Dolce Vita! There’s also a cinema there, but no IMAX. The only flaw in this otherwise perfect shopping centre.

As you might’ve realised by now, Dolce Vita Coimbra is the kind of place where empires are built and babies are made. That’s why they sell condoms in the bathrooms! Babies are expensive!

Highly recommended.
reviews/4/text:
The Dolce Vita Shopping is one of the three big shopping malls located in Coimbra.
You see it when visiting the “Penedo de Saudade”, this shopping Mall is in size the second one after the “Forum” shopping Mall, and the smallest one is the Coimbra shopping Mall, but anyhow also nice to pass some time and to shop.
You have 4 levels of underground car-parking and allot of shops were you can spent some money.
The shopping is also let us say part of the Football stadium of Coimbra.
After visiting the city you can pass there to have a nice cup of coffee or to eat something, nice place and recommendable for a visit.
reviews/5/text: Inserted in the stadium, this is a great and colorful mall. Lots of parking space, cinemas, supermarkets, stores, kids areas. It as frequent spectacles and activities on the central open space. It was considered the most innovated mall in Europe so take a look around
reviews/6/text:
A good choice of big brands.
There is a big supermarket downstairs that you can buy everithing inclueds some pastry, coofee for a very smal price.
Also there is a cinema, but it is not open before 1.30 pm.
reviews/6/title: Big mall in the heart of coimbra
reviews/7/text: encontra-se numa localização bastante boa para quem quer circular por coimbra, com uma loja auchan, várias lojas, mas com uma zona de restauração bastante fraca, praticamente com tudo de junk food que existe...
reviews/7/title: bom para compras, terrível para comer
reviews/8/text: Junto al estadio de fútbol, aparcamiento gratuito, varias plantas con supermercado Alcampo, cine, tiendas  y restaurantes
reviews/9/text: Lojas variadas e de qualidade e bom sitio para comer. Sala de cinema em otimas condições. Tem esplanada e bons acessos
reviews/10/text: Fomos lampa vi as avaliações aqui e me surpreendi, adoramos o shopping. Lugar muito legal para as crianças brincarem , lojas boas , praça de alimentação com variedades . Bom lugar
reviews/11/text: Muitos estacionamento, variadas lojas para todos os tipos de gosto, supermercado, cinema e vários restaurantes. Tem uma atração interessante para crianças até aos 12 anos e todo o shopping apresenta um aspecto moderno e sofisticado.
reviews/12/text: Um belo shopping, com vários níveis, ao lado do estádio em Coimbra. Um excelente local para compras e para comer, pela grande quantidade de lojas, restaurantes e lanchonetes de marcas famosas, além de um supermercado. Boas Compras.
reviews/13/text: O nome do local agora é “Alma Shopping”, não mais “Dolce Vitta Mall”. Bom centro comercial com várias opções de lojas.
reviews/14/text:
コインブラ大学周辺は小さな個人商店が多いので、おそらくコインブラの街では一番大きなショッピングセンターだと思います。
アクセス的には旅行者にはちょっと不便ですが、お買い物好きな方にはおすすめです。
reviews/14/title: コインブラでは大きなショッピングセンター
reviews/15/text: Centro Comercial em Coimbra, onde pode comprar desde o pronto a vestir, aos electrodomesticos e restauração.
reviews/16/text: O shopping é um bom lugar para conhecer, bastante amplo e diferente possui várias lojas e restaurantes. Ir caminhando é bom para curtir a vista no Penedo da Saudade ou então a orla do rio Mondego.
reviews/17/text: Esta al lado del estadio de Coimbra. Buen aparcamiento, supermercado Jumbo, restaurantes, cines, tiendas de ropa, y cosas para niños. Muy moderno, wifi. Lo recomiendo.
reviews/18/text: Vou fazer uma avaliação por estabelecimento. Hoje decidimos jantar no Pateo, provar a francesinha, que é especialidade da casa.. não é má, já como pior, além de os guardanapos virem sujos das mãos da funcionária, a francesinha é servida com as batatas ao redor de um prato pequeno onde basta tocar no pão que cai uma batata, do que eu sei e não sou especialista, as batatas servem á parte para se poder desfrutar melhor do pão tendo espaço para o cortar. O preço é acessível.
reviews/19/text: É um shopping pequeno mas, com bastante oferta de bons produtos. Lojas de roupas, sapatos e bolsas, brinquedos, livraria, casa, etc. Área de alimentação diversificada!!! Gosto muito.
subcategory_ranking: #39 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Rua de Sobre Ribas 49, Coimbra 3000-395 Portugal
description: The Misericordia de Coimbra Museum opened its doors to the public on the 12 of September 2000, during the commemorations of the 500 years of the founding of the Misericordia of Coimbra, by order of king Manuel I. The museum occupies part of the former College of Wisdom, an university college that belonged to the Order of the Regular Canons of Saint Augustin. The building was constructed between 1593 and 1604, in manneirist style, according to the project of the italian architect Filipe Terzi. The building is enlisted in the UNESCO World Heritage List.
name: Misericordia de Coimbra Museum
photo/caption: Fantástica vista sobre Coimbra a partir do Museu da Santa Casa da Misericórdia
ranking: #33 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #33 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
Great place, quite small with interesting objects (kings', church's, writing materials of ancient times, set of portraits, 2 pianos which you can play). Overall it's a very relaxed atmosphere despite it being a museum. A neat garden and an 88 windy steps tower with just an awesome view over the city. 
However if you love the history - ask for Pedro's excursion tour (available only on weekends). He is a true gem with the knowledge and story telling skills. You will enjoy it!
reviews/1/text: A great bite-sized attraction without the tour groups. Climb the narrow twisty stairs to the top of the tower to enjoy a great view of the Coimbra in solitude. I found the staff helpful in filling in the blanks in the long history of this place.
reviews/2/text: Great tour, lovely in depth explanation! Much appreciated the tour guide’s knowledge of the museum and the city of Cumbria!
reviews/3/text:
We stumbled across this little museum in the back streets of Coimbra. The receptionist was incredibly welcoming and very informative about what to see. The chapel is lovely, less ornate than others we had seen but the great difference is that you can go almost anywhere, right up to the altar, up to the organ so you really get to see the detail. There is an impressive nativity scene which has been donated by a local. The views of Coimbra from the bell tower are incredible, so well worth the narrow 138 steps up!

We even got to play the pianos! Definitely worth seeking out.
reviews/4/text:
We had a fabulous visit.
It is a do not miss in Coimbra.
We spent a half of day fascinated by the wonderful artifacts!
Call ahead and see is Pedro Peixoto is working -he is a walking history book and makes the museum come alive!
A great guy with lots to share!
reviews/5/text: Pedro , who collected our tickets also volunteered to take us for a personal tour . We saw the 18 century Pipe organ up close n climb up the 88 steps of the tower . The view was magnificent . Thanks Pedro 😊
reviews/6/text: Tour the church, with silver casket , the museum of the closed order  and the cloisters . Well worth the hill walk
reviews/7/text:
Visita muito bem acompanhada pelo guia.
Museu bem estruturado ao nivel de peças , indicações,etc.
Voltaria a visistar
reviews/8/text:
Verrassend Museum naast de architectonisch fraaie Faculteit van Psychologie en Educatie . Voorbij de formele portrettengalerij tref je een collectie bijzondere piano's en een door een Nederlander gerestaureerd compleet kerkorgel aan, waarop je mag spelen.
De studenten die je begeleiden vertellen enthousiast over de historie van gebouw en de aanwezige collecties. En als toetje kun je de 2e publiek toegankelijke toren van Coimbra beklimmen die fraai uitzicht over de stad geeft.
reviews/9/text:
Os guias Pedro e Helena são excelentes!
Espaço carregado de história e que permite aos visitantes algumas experiências inesquecíveis, como por exemplo ver o interior de um órgão de igreja e um scriptorium medieval. 
O Claustro é lindíssimo e a torre permite obter vistas soberbas sobre a cidade de Coimbra.
reviews/9/title: Excelente! Local a visitar em Coimbra!
reviews/10/text:
In das Museum sind wir durch Zufall geraten. Es hat sich als Perle in der Museenlandschaft Coimbras entpuppt: Die beiden Museumsmitarbeiter, ausgebildete Historiker, haben uns durch die Räume geführt und dabei mit viel Sympathie und Freude an ihrem Museum die Geschichte des Hauses und die Bedeutung für Stadt und Land darlegen können. Ein Highlight ist das Orgelspiel in der anliegenden Kirche, das uns vorgeführt wurde. Danach durften wir selbst ausprobieren, ein einmaliges Erlebnis.
Der Ausblick vom Torre do relógio erlaubt einen intimen Blick auf die Stadt, die Universität und den Fluss.
reviews/11/text: Открытый в 2000 году в честь 500-летия Santa Casa Miseicordia (благотворительное религиозное учреждение),  он имеет предметы, связанные с братством. Маленький и скучный
reviews/12/text:
Local agradável, acolhedor, de muita paz e uma bela história.
E a torre tem uma vista magnífica! Fiquei imaginando ao entardecer..
reviews/13/text: Sorpresa inaspettata. Per soli 2Euro , Pedro, responsabile del museo, ci ha guidato lungo le stanze, la cappella e fin sulla torre del campanile per una vista unica sulla città. Super raccomando
reviews/14/text: Un magnifique cloître, un orgue rare, une vue splendide du haut de la tour et surtout l'accueil, la gentillesse et la disponibilité de Pedro : tous les ingrédients d'un excellent moment ! Une visite commencée presque par hasard mais dont on ressort avec le sentiment d'avoir passé un moment spécial ! A recommander !
reviews/15/text:
Foi, no ano passado, que tive a oportunidade de visitar, pela primeira vez, este espaço.
Com uma visita aprofundada sobre o espaço, pude ter uma visão mais abrangente sobre o que pude visitar: a história da instituição, a origem das peças inseridas no museu, os acontecimentos ocorridos nos últimos tempos e as pessoas mais influentes, para o antigo Colégio de Órfãos de São Caetano.
É de reforçar o trabalho, a simpatia e boa disposição da equipa da Santa Casa da Misericórdia, que revela o seu empenho para fazer elevar o nome da instituição que representam.
reviews/15/title: Museu da Santa Casa da Misericórdia
reviews/16/text: Nous sommes arrivés par hasard dans le musée en passant par la fac de psychologie dont le cloître est à voir et nous n'avons pas été déçus. Pour seulement 2€ nous avons eu une visite très intéressante, pleine de détails de Pedro qui est extrêmement sympathique et disponible et qui nous a même permis de jouer de l'orgue dans la charmante petite chapelle. Une de ses amies guide a ensuite joué spécialement pour nous un menuet de  Beethoven. La vue depuis le mirador vaut aussi le détour. Bref, nous recommandons chaleureusement la visite!
reviews/17/text:
Ein von aussen etwas unscheinbares Museum. Die ehemalige Kirche ist sehr schön ausgestaltet. Ein Museum zum Anfassen: die Kinder dürften nicht nur Klavier und Flügel,  sondern auch die Orgel (die einzige deutsche Orgel in Coimbra) spielen.
Die Mitarbeiter haben sich sehr viel Zeit genommen die Exponate zu erklären und sind auf alle Fragen eingegangen. 
Vom Turm des Museums hat man einen fantastischen Ausblick Auf die Stadt.
reviews/18/text:
Nous sommes rentrés dans ce musée un peu par hasard. Quelle expérience inoubliable. Nous avons eu droit à une visite privée. 
Et la vue de la Tour vaut le détour.
reviews/19/text: Dieses Museum befindet sich ganz in der Naehe des historischen Doms Se Velha. In diesem Museum kann man lediglich ein paar Gewaender sowie eine Crypta/Kirche sehen. Ansonsten nur ein paar alte Fotos. Es wird auch hier ein Eintrittsgeld von 2 Euro erhoben. Bei Vorlage des Schwerbehindertenausweises ist der Eintritt frei.
subcategory_ranking: #33 of 108 things to do in Coimbra

address: Largo Padre Estrela Ferraz, Coimbra 3000-318 Portugal
name: Igreja de Santo Antonio dos Olivais
ranking: #30 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
ranking_subcategory: #30 of 108 things to do in Coimbra
reviews/0/text:
Some Franciscan friars arrived and settled at a small hermitage outside Coimbra dedicated to Saint Anthony of Egypt.
Saint Anthony began here his franciscan life after leaving the Canons Regular of St. Augustine.
reviews/0/title: Magnificent ancient blue and white tiles on the side walls
reviews/1/text: There is some kind of chamr to the Igreja de Santo Antonio dos Olivais, though old it is clearly a beautiful structure.
reviews/2/text: Coimbra has so many wonderful Churches and the St. Anthony of the Olives is no exception.  Fantastic architecture, beautiful carvings make this a deserved destination whether just for visiting or for quiet contemplative prayer
reviews/3/text: Located in the Coimbra suburb of Santo Antonio dos Olivais, the church is small, reflecting that it is after all a parish church.  It is well worth a visit and there is a graveyard alongside with numerous mausoleums.
reviews/4/text:
Igrejia S. António dos Olivais.
This church is situated outsider of the historical part of Coimbra really on a place you would not expect such a nice viewing church.
To enter you have to walk up by the nice staircase.
Once on the inside you will see the great views made out of “Azulegos” or hand painted tiles on the two side walls, something like you not will see very often, it is more like the entrance from the “São Bento” Railway station in Porto.
We are live already for 14 years in Portugal, and this is the first time that we take some time to visit this place, and we never had imagined that we would see such nice things on a place we passed almost every week.
Beside the church you have two small cemeteries where you can have an idea from how they burry there dead relatives, some normal underground and some above in “Jazigas” or small houses.
So we do hope that our visit to the historical part of Coimbra was some help for you.
Hans & Lucy.
reviews/5/text: It is perfect. Very relaxed, with a beautiful view on the neighboring hills. Quite far from the center of the city and on a hill, take e.g. bus no. 7 or 7T.
reviews/6/text:
Igreja linda, foi onde Santo Antônio se ordenou. 
Igreja antiga que vale muito a pena ser conhecida, principalmente por católicos praticantes.
reviews/7/text: Um momento de Graça. Assitir uma missa na Igreja de Santo Antonio dos Olivais no dia de Santo Antonio é realmente um momento único. A missa foi linda e no sermão fiquei sabendo que neste ano de 2019 faz 800 anos que, em Coimbra, depois de um encontro com os Franciscanos, que Fernando ingressou na Ordem e assumiu o nome de Antonio, pelo qual é conhecido mundialmente. Uma Igreja muito bonita, com uma imagem de Santo Antonio maravilhosa. Depois da missa ainda teve a Procisão pela ruas da Freguesia. Um encantamento.
reviews/7/title: Missa no dia de Santo Antonio
reviews/8/text: 인상적인 포르투갈풍 교회입니다. 기존의 성당 양식이 아닌 아기자기하면서도 뭔가 전설을 품고 있는듯한 양식이라 산책하며 보기 좋아요.
reviews/9/text: É uma igreja muito bonita, conservando vários aspectos arquitetônicos bastante antigos. Também tem um presépio muito bonito
reviews/10/text: Por aqui passou (e não foi só de passagem) Santo António, santo português. Igreja simples, com bonitos azulejos.
reviews/11/text: Situata leggermente fuori dal centro di Coimbra, la chiesetta è piccola ma ben tenuta. All'interno la decorazione è praticamente solo in azulejos e a gestire la comunità francescana c'è un italiano, quindi per chi volesse saperne di più, basta avvisare prima del proprio arrivo e verrete accolti come se foste a casa vostra. Inoltre in caso "prenotiate" la vostra visita avrete modo anche di vedere alcune sale interne che altrimenti non avreste modo di vedere :)
reviews/12/text:
chiesa pittoresca, molto bella in esterna con il cimitero a lato e la sua grande scalinata esterna.
molto suggestivo l'interno
reviews/13/text: Igreja com uma qualidade e conservação superior, local de culto e de encanto, com excelentes pontos de interesse e  com um ambiente tranquilo e acolhedor.
reviews/14/text: Para bons momentos de contemplação recomento Igreja de Santo Antonio dos Olivais. Mas no dia do Santo, vale a quermesse tambem
reviews/15/text: Igreja franciscana de visita obrigatória,pelos seus ruiquíssimos azulejos,que "forram" todo o interior da igreja,assim como a escadaria monumental de entrada em lajes de pedra,com as 12 estações da cruxificação de Jesus Cristo,muito bem representadas ,em 12 retábulos renascentistas.
reviews/15/title: AS 12 ESTAÇÕES DA PAIXÃO DE CRISTO
reviews/16/text: Situada al lado del cementerio, con una escalinata de subida, pequeña y agradable. Sin ostentaciones.
reviews/16/title: Iglesia pequeña, sin riquezas excepto la personalidad de los sacerdotes.
reviews/17/text: Bons acessos, local maravilhoso, uma pérola de Coimbra, acesso por escadaria com os passos do senhor, em pequenas capelas com imagens em tamanho natural. Interior revestido com azulejos em azul e branco
reviews/18/text: Outro ponto turístico tradicional de Coimbra.Tem uma constituição arquitetônica invejável e bem típica de Portugal.Dentro tem altares maravilhosos com madeiras entalhadas e detalhes em ouro.
reviews/19/text:
A escadaria de acesso ladeada por 6 capelas da Paixão e morte de Cristo são merecedoras de destaque especial pela sua arquitetura. 
Um convento de franciscanos foi aqui construído no início do séc. XIII. A atual Igreja foi remodelada no período barroco. No interior destacam-se os azulejos com cenas da vida de Santo António, bem como as pinturas dos tetos e do altar.
